Ambient.name: Ambient
Ambient.description_short: Emphasizes texture and tone over traditional musical structure, aimed at evoking a particular atmosphere or mood.

Ambient Americana.name: Ambient Americana
Ambient Americana.description_short: Made using traditional [Genre457] and [Genre166] instrumentation, typically to evoke a pastoral atmosphere.

Dark Ambient.name: Dark Ambient
Dark Ambient.description_short: Emphasizes an ominous, gloomy, and dissonant atmosphere.

Black Ambient.name: Black Ambient
Black Ambient.description_short: Incorporates elements such as guitars, synthesizers, harsh or whispered vocals, raw production, or other elements associated with [Genre189] and [Genre31103].

Ritual Ambient.name: Ritual Ambient
Ritual Ambient.description_short: Dark, disturbing, ritualistic, and occult atmosphere, often taking inspiration from various existing ritual practices around the world.

Space Ambient.name: Space Ambient
Space Ambient.description_short: Flowing and relaxing synthesizer-based music derived from [Genre10035], often oriented around imagery of outer space.

Tribal Ambient.name: Tribal Ambient
Tribal Ambient.description_short: Combines the theory and atmosphere of [Genre84] with traditional instruments and sounds from around the globe.

Blues.name: Blues
Blues.description_short: Originated toward the end of the 19th century in African American communities in the United States, particularly the Deep South; drew on traditional [Genre10015] and [Genre294]; highly influential to the whole of Western popular music.

Acoustic Blues.name: Acoustic Blues
Acoustic Blues.description_short: Developed out of [Genre294] and [Genre10015] to become the most prominent early form of [Genre131].

Acoustic Chicago Blues.name: Acoustic Chicago Blues
Acoustic Chicago Blues.description_short: Unplugged [Genre131] made in the Chicago region, primarily during the 1930s and 1940s.

Acoustic Texas Blues.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
Acoustic Texas Blues.description_short: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

Jug Band.name: Jug Band
Jug Band.description_short: Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.

Piedmont Blues.name: Piedmont Blues
Piedmont Blues.description_short: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic [Genre328]-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

Boogie Woogie.name: Boogie Woogie
Boogie Woogie.description_short: Early, uptempo [Genre131] featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note bassline.

Country Blues.name: Country Blues
Country Blues.description_short: Various styles of [Genre131] originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

Delta Blues.name: Delta Blues
Delta Blues.description_short: One of the earliest forms of [Genre131], named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

Hill Country Blues.name: Hill Country Blues
Hill Country Blues.description_short: Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to [Genre132].

Electric Blues.name: Electric Blues
Electric Blues.description_short: Major development in sound and reach of [Genre131] when it became possible to amplify the instruments of small combos.

British Blues.name: British Blues
British Blues.description_short: Heavily influenced by the burgeoning United States [Genre131] scene, particularly [Genre291].

Chicago Blues.name: Chicago Blues
Chicago Blues.description_short: Heavily inspired by old-time rural blues, transferring it into a small band setup, while maintaining the rough and gritty edges of its ancestry.

Electric Texas Blues.name: Electric Texas Blues
Electric Texas Blues.description_short: Originating in (but not limited to) Texas; includes [Genre6] influences like [Genre624] rhythms and sometimes the addition of a horn section.

Swamp Blues.name: Swamp Blues
Swamp Blues.description_short: Originated in Baton Rouge, Louisiana in the 1950s, with a laid-back and relaxed sound that takes influence from [Genre10074] and [Genre10478].

Fife and Drum Blues.name: Fife and Drum Blues
Fife and Drum Blues.description_short: Rooted in martial [Genre54547] music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

Jump Blues.name: Jump Blues
Jump Blues.description_short: Emerged in the late 1930s with influence from [Genre6] styles such as [Genre624] and [Genre315], featuring fast tempos and raucous performances.

Piano Blues.name: Piano Blues
Piano Blues.description_short: Played either solo or with the piano as the lead instrument of a small combo performing slow or mid-tempo blues ballads, as opposed to the commonly fast-paced [Genre10180].

Soul Blues.name: Soul Blues
Soul Blues.description_short: Shares similarities with [Genre235] and incorporates the eponymous soulful inflections of [Genre10014], [Genre238] and soul into the vocals.

Classical Music.name: Classical Music
Classical Music.description_short: Part of a broad generalization about the structure and function of music throughout history across the globe, describing traditions distinct from [Genre10448] and popular music.

Buganda Royal Court Music.name: Buganda Royal Court Music
Buganda Royal Court Music.description_short: Highest traditional and refined musical forms of Buganda, reserved for the Kabaka (the king of Buganda).

East Asian Classical Music.name: East Asian Classical Music
East Asian Classical Music.description_short: Covers all the forms of pan-East Asian [Genre27640] sharing origins in [Genre31570].

Chinese Classical Music.name: Chinese Classical Music
Chinese Classical Music.description_short: [Genre27640] of China, encompassing royal court music.

Baisha xiyue.name: Baisha xiyue
Baisha xiyue.description_short: Mainly performed for funeral ceremonies of the Naxi ethnic group in the Yunnan province in China.

Chinese Literati Music.name: Chinese Literati Music
Chinese Literati Music.description_short: Music of the Chinese literati; primarily played on the guqin and invoking emotional restraint, self-cultivation, and introspection.

Dongjing.name: Dongjing
Dongjing.description_short: Chinese Taoist ritual music from the Nakhi (Naxi) people, historically performed around Yunnan and Sichuan.

Yayue.name: Yayue
Yayue.description_short: Incorporates folk and religious traditions of [Genre46918]; literally translated as 'elegant music'.

Gagaku.name: Gagaku
Gagaku.description_short: One of the oldest forms of [Genre31594], based on the pentatonic Yo scale, characterized by an elegant sound that is typically solemn, slow-paced, and resonant.

Heikyoku.name: Heikyoku
Heikyoku.description_short: Semi-classical bardic tradition in Japan analogous to the troubadour music of medieval Europe.

Honkyoku.name: Honkyoku
Honkyoku.description_short: [Genre31594] performed solo on a bamboo flute shakuhachi.

Jiuta.name: Jiuta
Jiuta.description_short: Originally created by solo performers singing and playing [i]shamisen[/i], but since the late 18th century increasingly often performed by [i]sankyoku[/i] ensembles ([i]shamisen, koto[/i] and [i]shakuhachi[/i] or [i]kokyu[/i]).

Jōruri.name: Jōruri
Jōruri.description_short: Consists of a singing narrator (tayū) with shamisen accompaniment.

Meiji shinkyoku.name: Meiji shinkyoku
Meiji shinkyoku.description_short: Meiji-era compositions, using a distinctive, brighter scale, usually performed with two kotos.

Nagauta.name: Nagauta
Nagauta.description_short: [Genre31594] used in Kabuki, a form of theatre oriented to dance-drama.

Noh.name: Noh
Noh.description_short: Played by an hayashi ensemble, consisting of a fue (flute), a kotsuzumi (shoulder drum), a ōtsuzumi (hip drum), and a taiko (stick drum).

Shōmyō.name: Shōmyō
Shōmyō.description_short: Japanese Buddhist chant that utilizes the [i]yō[/i] scale.

Sōkyoku.name: Sōkyoku
Sōkyoku.description_short: Gained popularity during the Edo period, played with a koto or a guzheng and sometimes accompanied by shamisen and/or shakuhachi.

Danmono.name: Danmono
Danmono.description_short: [Genre32606] composed for koto, a thirteen-string traditional instrument.

Kumiuta.name: Kumiuta
Kumiuta.description_short: Typically performed by a single singer playing koto or less often shamisen for accompaniment, often with lyrics adapted from classical poetry.

Aak.name: Aak
Aak.description_short: [Genre31619] that dates back to the early 12th century.

Dang-ak.name: Dang-ak
Dang-ak.description_short: [Genre31619] that dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

Hyang-ak.name: Hyang-ak
Hyang-ak.description_short: One of the most common and oldest surviving forms of Korean court music.

Jeong-ak.name: Jeong-ak
Jeong-ak.description_short: Also known as [i]proper music[/i]; dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

Gagok.name: Gagok
Gagok.description_short: Vocal songs derived from [Genre31619] backed by a small orchestra of [Genre37243] ("aristocratic or proper music").

Vietnamese Court Music.name: Vietnamese Court Music
Vietnamese Court Music.description_short: Traditional court music of Vietnam, specifically that of the Nguyễn dynasty.

Vietnamese Opera.name: Vietnamese Opera
Vietnamese Opera.description_short: Classical musical theatre and its associated form of [Genre31626], related strongly to [Genre20191].

Inkiranya.name: Inkiranya
Inkiranya.description_short: Influential drumming style originating in Burundi carried out by a percussion ensemble.

Kete.name: Kete
Kete.description_short: Traditional percussive style played at special occasions in the courts of high ranking Asante chieftains.

Maqāmic Music.name: Maqāmic Music
Maqāmic Music.description_short: Originating in the Middle East and founded upon [i]maqāmāt[/i] scales, encompassing an extensive and diverse cultural and musical legacy that spans from Morocco to Southeast Asia.

Arabic Classical Music.name: Arabic Classical Music
Arabic Classical Music.description_short: Arabic [Genre27640] tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around [Genre30528].

Andalusian Classical Music.name: Andalusian Classical Music
Andalusian Classical Music.description_short: [Genre30786] tradition that had its beginnings in Al-Andalus, the medieval Islamic Iberian peninsula, which later spread and developed in the Maghreb.

Iraqi Maqam.name: Iraqi Maqam
Iraqi Maqam.description_short: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific [i]maqam[/i] modes.

Sawt.name: Sawt
Sawt.description_short: Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a [i]maqam[/i] system.

Azerbaijani Mugham.name: Azerbaijani Mugham
Azerbaijani Mugham.description_short: Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan’s history.

Persian Classical Music.name: Persian Classical Music
Persian Classical Music.description_short: Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.

Shashmaqam.name: Shashmaqam
Shashmaqam.description_short: Modal suite that brings together lyrical and instrumental songs, poetry, and dance shared by [Genre31922] and [Genre30427].

Sufiana kalam.name: Sufiana kalam
Sufiana kalam.description_short: Classical music from Kashmir, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

Turkish Classical Music.name: Turkish Classical Music
Turkish Classical Music.description_short: Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.

Turkish Mevlevi Music.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
Turkish Mevlevi Music.description_short: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

Twelve Muqam.name: Twelve Muqam
Twelve Muqam.description_short: Uyghur muqam suite of 12 different muqam performances, originating in Southern Xinjiang.

Minyue.name: Minyue
Minyue.description_short: Modernized composition for Chinese instruments on the basis of [Genre25511], incorporating aspects of [Genre183].

Pìobaireachd.name: Pìobaireachd
Pìobaireachd.description_short: Art tradition which originated in the Scottish Highlands, usually associated with the Great Highland bagpipes.

South Asian Classical Music.name: South Asian Classical Music
South Asian Classical Music.description_short: Meta-genre that covers the diverse forms of [Genre27640] from South Asia.

Carnatic Classical Music.name: Carnatic Classical Music
Carnatic Classical Music.description_short: Culture shared by the Dravidian cultures in South India separate from regional folk genres.

Konnakol.name: Konnakol
Konnakol.description_short: Traditional song utilizing [i]solkattu[/i], syllablic patterns to mimic instrumentation.

Hindustani Classical Music.name: Hindustani Classical Music
Hindustani Classical Music.description_short: North Indian traditional music (including parts of Pakistan, Afghanistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Bhutan) with roots reaching back to the 12th century CE.

Dhrupad.name: Dhrupad
Dhrupad.description_short: Ancient style of classical Hindustani vocal and instrumental music.

Kafi.name: Kafi
Kafi.description_short: Sufi vocal style popular in Pakistan, differentiated from [genre10036] by its small ensemble size and simple arrangements.

Khayal.name: Khayal
Khayal.description_short: Predominant vocal style, often with a significant amount of improvisation.

Klasik.name: Klasik
Klasik.description_short: Encompassing the various styles of Afghan [Genre27640], which diverged from the North Indian styles.

Qawwali.name: Qawwali
Qawwali.description_short: [Genre54056] in India and Pakistan using the [i]raga[/i] and [i]tala[/i] templates of [Genre10480].

Shabad kirtan.name: Shabad kirtan
Shabad kirtan.description_short: Religious Sikh [Genre10472] backed by specially selected ragas and taal.

Tarana.name: Tarana
Tarana.description_short: Vocal composition with Persian or Arabic syllables and phonemes.

Thumri.name: Thumri
Thumri.description_short: Hindustani classical style based on North Indian folk literature.

Odissi Classical Music.name: Odissi Classical Music
Odissi Classical Music.description_short: Traditional dance and classical music from the Odisha region of Eastern India.

Southeast Asian Classical Music.name: Southeast Asian Classical Music
Southeast Asian Classical Music.description_short: Formal music developed in Southeast Asian countries (Burma, Cambodia, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, East Timor, Brunei Darussalam) usually in form of gong-chime orchestras such as gamelan, kulintang and pi phat.

Burmese Classical Music.name: Burmese Classical Music
Burmese Classical Music.description_short: Traditional court music of Myanmar, developed from Southeast Asian, Hindu and Chinese influences.

Gamelan.name: Gamelan
Gamelan.description_short: Originated in the island of Java; played by an ensemble typically consisting of metallophones and gongs, sometimes augmented with drums, flutes, and human voices.

Balinese Gamelan.name: Balinese Gamelan
Balinese Gamelan.description_short: Broad classification grouping various forms of [Genre21370] with native roots in Bali.

Gamelan angklung.name: Gamelan angklung
Gamelan angklung.description_short: Takes its name from the angklung, an instrument made of bamboo tubes.

Gamelan beleganjur.name: Gamelan beleganjur
Gamelan beleganjur.description_short: Loud, chaotic, highly percussive, and with heavy tempo changes.

Gamelan gender wayang.name: Gamelan gender wayang
Gamelan gender wayang.description_short: Performed with two/four metallophones made out of bronze keys with suspended bamboo tube resonators connected to them.

Gamelan gong gede.name: Gamelan gong gede
Gamelan gong gede.description_short: Ceremonial style characterized by a simpler and more melodic approach with clearer and more stable progressions compared to other Balinese orchestras.

Gamelan gong kebyar.name: Gamelan gong kebyar
Gamelan gong kebyar.description_short: Free compositional techniques and rapidly changing dynamics.

Gamelan jegog.name: Gamelan jegog
Gamelan jegog.description_short: Played entirely on marimba-like instruments made from bamboo which widely differ in size.

Gamelan selonding.name: Gamelan selonding
Gamelan selonding.description_short: Ensemble consists of four to six musicians playing metallophones made out of iron in a seven-tone scale.

Gamelan semar pegulingan.name: Gamelan semar pegulingan
Gamelan semar pegulingan.description_short: Originated in the 16th-17th centuries; features a soft, delicate, and ethereal sound.

Gamelan degung.name: Gamelan degung
Gamelan degung.description_short: Sundanese [Genre21370] performed by a small orchestra of bronze gongs and metallophones.

Javanese Gamelan.name: Javanese Gamelan
Javanese Gamelan.description_short: Broad classification grouping [genre21370] genres native to Javanese culture.

Gamelan sekaten.name: Gamelan sekaten
Gamelan sekaten.description_short: Javanese ceremonial [Genre21370] played with large instruments, strictly unaccompanied by vocals.

Solonese Gamelan.name: Solonese Gamelan
Solonese Gamelan.description_short: Style originating from Surakarta; known for its subtle and more delicate sound.

Malay Gamelan.name: Malay Gamelan
Malay Gamelan.description_short: Developments of [genre21370] that are performed by Malay native groups, mostly established by the Pahang and Terengganu royal courts of the Malay Peninsula.

Kacapi suling.name: Kacapi suling
Kacapi suling.description_short: Sundanese music played by an ensemble consisting of one or two kacapis (zithers), one suling (flute), and occasionally a set of kendangs (drums).

Kakawin.name: Kakawin
Kakawin.description_short: Form of Indonesian poetry written in Kawi, performed melodically using a structured pattern of long and short syllables.

Kulintang.name: Kulintang
Kulintang.description_short: Southeast Asian gong-chime ensemble consisting mainly of gong-chimes of various sizes, with the addition of larger gongs, various drums, and occasionally xylophones and non-percussion instruments.

Mahori.name: Mahori
Mahori.description_short: Thai and Khmer traditional orchestra combining xylophones and gong-chimes of [Genre25902]/[Genre27200] with strings of [Genre43762] ensemble.

Malay Classical Music.name: Malay Classical Music
Malay Classical Music.description_short: Traditionally played in the royal courts of the several Malay kingdoms, empires and sultanates that existed throughout history.

Pinpeat.name: Pinpeat
Pinpeat.description_short: Orchestra of wind and percussion instruments having its origins in the Khmer Empire era.

Saluang klasik.name: Saluang klasik
Saluang klasik.description_short: Played by a duo or a trio of musicians, including a [i]saluang[/i] (a kind of end-blown bamboo flute) player and a traditional singer.

Talempong.name: Talempong
Talempong.description_short: Gong-chime ensemble focused around the [i]talempong[/i] kettle gong.

Tembang Sunda Cianjuran.name: Tembang Sunda Cianjuran
Tembang Sunda Cianjuran.description_short: Sung free-verse poetry in Sundanese language, usually by a solo vocalist, accompanied by a mellow-sounding [Genre27315] ensemble.

Thai Classical Music.name: Thai Classical Music
Thai Classical Music.description_short: Emerged from the royal courts of Central Thailand around the 13th century, based on a traditional Thai sound-scale of seven tempered notes.

Fon leb.name: Fon leb
Fon leb.description_short: Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with [Genre25902] instruments and a pair of female choreographers.

Khrueang sai.name: Khrueang sai
Khrueang sai.description_short: [Genre25183] emphasizing string instruments while also incorporating other kinds of instruments to enrich the sound.

Piphat.name: Piphat
Piphat.description_short: Led by wind and percussion instruments, with ensembles ranging from 6 to 10 instruments.

Tibetan Buddhist Chant.name: Tibetan Buddhist Chant
Tibetan Buddhist Chant.description_short: Ritual vocal music of the Tibetan Buddhist faith characterized by its low pitch, droning repetitiousness, and frequent use of overtone singing.

Western Classical Music.name: Western Classical Music
Western Classical Music.description_short: Broad range of art music associated with the aristocracy that originated in Europe around 500 AD.

Art Song.name: Art Song
Art Song.description_short: Vocal music with text often set to [Genre141], typically for single vocalist with instrumental accompaniment, distinguished by its design for concert recital and high artistic demands requiring classically trained musicians.

Elizabethan Song.name: Elizabethan Song
Elizabethan Song.description_short: Monophonic style developed in Renaissance England that is typically composed in strophic form for one to several vocalists with instrumental accompaniment ranging from solo lute to chamber ensemble.

Lied.name: Lied
Lied.description_short: Form of song arising from 19th century German [Genre184], usually for solo vocalist & piano with a text derived from poetry.

Mélodie.name: Mélodie
Mélodie.description_short: French form typically with a greater emphasis on emotional restraint, refinement, subtlety, and concision.

Orchestral Song.name: Orchestral Song
Orchestral Song.description_short: Classical song for solo voice or voices with orchestral accompaniment.

Bagatelle.name: Bagatelle
Bagatelle.description_short: Brief composition with an unpretentious, playful sound.

Ballet.name: Ballet
Ballet.description_short: Western art music, often [Genre22197], written to accompany classical dance productions of the same name.

Ballet de cour.name: Ballet de cour
Ballet de cour.description_short: Earliest form developed by the French royal court and characterized by its artistic diversity, regimented structure, grand spectacle, and overt political elements.

Comédie-ballet.name: Comédie-ballet
Comédie-ballet.description_short: French form of musical drama from the 17th century that combines operatic singing, classical dance, and theater.

Opéra-ballet.name: Opéra-ballet
Opéra-ballet.description_short: Principally French style of musical drama that combines operatic singing with classical dance, usually with small [Genre22197] accompaniment.

Baroque Music.name: Baroque Music
Baroque Music.description_short: Constant rhythmic flow, or a steady motion throughout, generally focusing on a single melodic idea and including some form of counterpoint.

Zarzuela barroca.name: Zarzuela barroca
Zarzuela barroca.description_short: Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.

Baroque Suite.name: Baroque Suite
Baroque Suite.description_short: Collection of varied dance pieces, usually in the same key, structured on the music of European courtly dances.

Brazilian Classical Music.name: Brazilian Classical Music
Brazilian Classical Music.description_short: Originated in the late 19th century, taking the European music that had been brought to the country by colonists and brought in parts of [Genre542].

Valsa brasileira.name: Valsa brasileira
Valsa brasileira.description_short: Brazillian [Genre29770] characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.

Byzantine Chant.name: Byzantine Chant
Byzantine Chant.description_short: Liturgical chant of Christian churches following the Orthodox rite.

Cantata.name: Cantata
Cantata.description_short: Vocal style for solo singers with instrumental & [Genre10255] accompaniment comparable to [Genre31254], though often smaller in scale, more songlike, and with less focus on dramatic narrative.

Canzona.name: Canzona
Canzona.description_short: Song-like structures and a contrapuntal texture technique known as imitation.

Capriccio.name: Capriccio
Capriccio.description_short: Typically short and loosely structured, characterized by spontaneity, humor, and technicality.

Chamber Music.name: Chamber Music
Chamber Music.description_short: [Genre183] performed by a small ensemble, usually only a few performers.

String Quartet.name: String Quartet
String Quartet.description_short: Small scale composition for an ensemble that consists of two violins, one viola, and one cello, with complex interplay and multiple (usually four) movements.

Character Piece.name: Character Piece
Character Piece.description_short: Broad instrumental genre, usually for solo piano, written to evoke an extramusical concept or mood.

Nocturne.name: Nocturne
Nocturne.description_short: Intimate piece meant to evoke associations with the night.

Choral.name: Choral
Choral.description_short: Choir-sung classical works covering periods from medieval music (an early form being [Genre10399]) up to present day.

Choral Concerto.name: Choral Concerto
Choral Concerto.description_short: Composition for unaccompanied choir, set to sacred texts of Eastern Orthodox tradition.

Choral Symphony.name: Choral Symphony
Choral Symphony.description_short: Combines symphonic [Genre22197] forces & structure with vocal parts for choir.

Mass.name: Mass
Mass.description_short: Composition for choir, with or without instrumental accompaniment, that sets to music text from the liturgy of the Eucharist, principally from the Latin rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

Requiem.name: Requiem
Requiem.description_short: Musical setting commemorating the deceased with text usually derived from the Roman Catholic mass of the dead.

Cinematic Classical.name: Cinematic Classical
Cinematic Classical.description_short: Orchestral compositions generally associated with soundtracks to modern high-budget films, games, and other non-live media.

Epic Music.name: Epic Music
Epic Music.description_short: Often associated with [Genre82] production, heavy percussion such as taiko drums, [Genre10255] vocals, and orchestral instrumentation to create a bombastic style commonly linked to movie trailers.

Spaghetti Western.name: Spaghetti Western
Spaghetti Western.description_short: Epic, cinematic sound evoking imagery of the Wild West, featuring a [Genre80]-inspired guitar tone while taking inspiration from the melodies and harmonies of traditional [Genre20941].

Classical Period.name: Classical Period
Classical Period.description_short: Refers to the phase in [Genre183] history occurring from roughly 1750 to 1820, characterized by its emphasis on clarity, simplicity, and balance.

Divertissement.name: Divertissement
Divertissement.description_short: Straightforward tuneful music historically written to serve as light entertainment for events or as interstitial movements within larger theatrical works.

English Pastoral School.name: English Pastoral School
English Pastoral School.description_short: Early 20th-century English classical composers turning to English folk and pastoral influences.

Étude.name: Étude
Étude.description_short: Composition written to both showcase & sharpen a particular playing or compositional technique, often requiring great skill from its performers.

Fantasia.name: Fantasia
Fantasia.description_short: Free-form, improvisational, and with contrasting sectional writing, sometimes based on preexisting melodies and generally meant to evoke a sense of imaginative exploration.

Fugue.name: Fugue
Fugue.description_short: Contrapuntal composition and technique for a fixed numbers of musical voices; following the imitations of one main theme.

Impromptu.name: Impromptu
Impromptu.description_short: Composition written to sound like a spur-of-the-moment improvisation.

Light Music.name: Light Music
Light Music.description_short: Instrumental, typically through-composed style performed by an orchestra or small ensemble, with simpler arrangements and an emphasis on strong melodies.

Madrigal.name: Madrigal
Madrigal.description_short: Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles of two to eight persons.

Medieval Classical Music.name: Medieval Classical Music
Medieval Classical Music.description_short: Composed during the Medieval period lasted approximately from the 5th to the late 15th centuries.

Ars antiqua.name: Ars antiqua
Ars antiqua.description_short: Mainly sacred European medieval music from the period of 1170 to 1310, featuring the birth of measuring time in music and the use of polyphonies for four voices.

Ars nova.name: Ars nova
Ars nova.description_short: Period (around 1310-1380) that succeeded [Genre20923], mixing the sacred with the secular.

Ars subtilior.name: Ars subtilior
Ars subtilior.description_short: Emerged in the final period of late medieval music (around 1380-1420) and continued to use the technique of isorhythms but with added complexity.

Contenance angloise.name: Contenance angloise
Contenance angloise.description_short: Distinct style of [genre21012] developed in fifteenth-century England.

Medieval Lyric Poetry.name: Medieval Lyric Poetry
Medieval Lyric Poetry.description_short: Lyric poetry from Medieval Europe, roughly from the 11th to the 14th century, most prominently the troubadours of southern France.

Plainsong.name: Plainsong
Plainsong.description_short: Monophonic chanting in the context of Roman Catholic and modern Anglican liturgy.

Ambrosian Chant.name: Ambrosian Chant
Ambrosian Chant.description_short: Liturgical chant practiced in parts of Italy and Switzerland, characterized by stepped melodic progression.

Canto beneventano.name: Canto beneventano
Canto beneventano.description_short: Extinct plainchant tradition of Southern Italy characterized by lengthy melodies, extensive use of repetition, and a steady, undulating progression.

Canto mozárabe.name: Canto mozárabe
Canto mozárabe.description_short: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

Celtic Chant.name: Celtic Chant
Celtic Chant.description_short: Extinct tradition of Catholic liturgical chant developed by the Celtic Christians of Britain, Ireland, and Brittany.

Gallican Chant.name: Gallican Chant
Gallican Chant.description_short: Extinct plainchant tradition originating from the region of Gaul (now modern-day France).

Gregorian Chant.name: Gregorian Chant
Gregorian Chant.description_short: Liturgical, monophonic chant that accompanied Mass and other rituals in Western Christianity.

Sarum Chant.name: Sarum Chant
Sarum Chant.description_short: Latin [Genre10356] tradition of Salisbury, England, characterized by its unadorned simplicity.

Old Roman Chant.name: Old Roman Chant
Old Roman Chant.description_short: Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to [Genre10399], though often more musically ornate.

Modern Classical.name: Modern Classical
Modern Classical.description_short: Multitude of different compositional approaches beginning in the 20th century that deviate significantly from the previously-held tenets.

American Gamelan.name: American Gamelan
American Gamelan.description_short: Mid-20th-century style, influenced by arrangements, instrumentation, rhythms, timbres, and tunings of Indonesian [Genre21370].

Expressionism.name: Expressionism
Expressionism.description_short: Originating between the abandonment of tonality at the conclusion of the period of [Genre184] and the creation of twelve-tone composition.

Futurism.name: Futurism
Futurism.description_short: Radical and militant attitude, rejection of [Genre183] and traditional criteria of craft, non-conformity, and a fascination with machines.

Impressionism.name: Impressionism
Impressionism.description_short: Originated in late 19th to early 20th century France as a reaction to [Genre184], placing a greater focus on depicting atmosphere and mood rather than fixed concepts.

Indeterminacy.name: Indeterminacy
Indeterminacy.description_short: Leaves elements of composition, performance, or both up to chance.

Microtonal Classical.name: Microtonal Classical
Microtonal Classical.description_short: Eschews the traditional twelve-tone scale of [Genre183], utilizing intervals outside of its bounds.

Minimalism.name: Minimalism
Minimalism.description_short: Developed in the United States in the 1960s; recognized for its repetitive nature and use of static harmony.

Holy Minimalism.name: Holy Minimalism
Holy Minimalism.description_short: Style informed by [Genre10269] that emphasizes slow sustained rhythmic values, soft dynamics, and silence to produce a contemplative and reverential atmosphere.

Musique concrète instrumentale.name: Musique concrète instrumentale
Musique concrète instrumentale.description_short: Acoustic, through-composed [Genre27640] that relies heavily on unconventional instrumental techniques.

New Complexity.name: New Complexity
New Complexity.description_short: Dense, difficult, and rigorously academic approach to [Genre201] composition which emerged in the 1980s.

Post-Minimalism.name: Post-Minimalism
Post-Minimalism.description_short: Seeks to push [Genre10033]'s linear composition style forward, and takes in influences from genres such as [Genre6], [Genre10448], and others.

Totalism.name: Totalism
Totalism.description_short: Adds complex rhythmic structures and emphasis on surface energy to [Genre10033].

Process Music.name: Process Music
Process Music.description_short: Compositions centering musical processes, both audible and inaudible.

Serialism.name: Serialism
Serialism.description_short: Compositional method in which pitches are grouped into sets (tone rows) to determine the order and frequency of their use.

Integral Serialism.name: Integral Serialism
Integral Serialism.description_short: Application of twelve-tone technique in early [Genre199] to as many compositional factors as possible (in an attempt to apply total serial control).

Sonorism.name: Sonorism
Sonorism.description_short: Techniques and forms that emphasize texture and timbre.

Spectralism.name: Spectralism
Spectralism.description_short: Compositional practice involving analysis, manipulation, and transformation of sound spectra.

Stochastic Music.name: Stochastic Music
Stochastic Music.description_short: Composition featuring guided indeterminism, where the following state is only partially determined by the preceding state.

Motet.name: Motet
Motet.description_short: Extremely diverse form of vocal music, usually written as a style of [Genre21012] for [Genre10163] soloists or choir.

Neoclassicism.name: Neoclassicism
Neoclassicism.description_short: Return to the more formal and less expansive structures and forms, beginning shortly after World War I as a reaction to what some composers perceived as excesses of [Genre184].

Opera.name: Opera
Opera.description_short: European tradition which combines drama and distinctive vocal style in the context of [Genre183], usually performed as a theatrical work on stage.

Ballad Opera.name: Ballad Opera
Ballad Opera.description_short: English reaction to the Italian [Genre190] styles with a satirical sense of humor and scores borrowing from [Genre10448] and popular music.

Grand opéra.name: Grand opéra
Grand opéra.description_short: French style characterized by its enlarged scope and sense of grandeur, with bigger orchestras and casts, and ornate sceneries and costumes.

Monodrama.name: Monodrama
Monodrama.description_short: Mostly modern style written for a single virtuoso singer with accompaniment, often shorter in length and with a more philosophically introspective or abstract libretto.

Opera buffa.name: Opera buffa
Opera buffa.description_short: Lighthearted and amusing counterpart to [Genre21386]; developed in Naples in the first half of the 18th century.

Opéra-comique.name: Opéra-comique
Opéra-comique.description_short: French style of [Genre190] characterized by the use of some spoken dialogues to connect major arias and sung parts, as well as a more restrained approach to recitatives.

Opera semiseria.name: Opera semiseria
Opera semiseria.description_short: Popular in the early and middle 19th century, containing appeals to emotion of [Genre21386] as well as some comedy elements present in [Genre29104].

Opera seria.name: Opera seria
Opera seria.description_short: Italian [Genre190] popular among European nobility and royalty throughout most of the 18th century, typified by its exaggerated dramatic flair and interspersed with dry recitative.

Operetta.name: Operetta
Operetta.description_short: Light opera interspersed with spoken dialogues, being usually satirical and/or humorous in nature and centered around romantic plots and dancing scenes.

Kalon'ny fahiny.name: Kalon'ny fahiny
Kalon'ny fahiny.description_short: Fusion of music from the highlands of Madagascar and western [Genre10321].

Romantische Oper.name: Romantische Oper
Romantische Oper.description_short: Early 19th century Germanic style of [Genre190] influenced by [Genre39541] and legends with a focus on fantasy, emotivity, heroic figures, and nationalism.

Singspiel.name: Singspiel
Singspiel.description_short: German form of [Genre190] distinguished by the prominent usage of spoken dialogues mixed with lyrical or folklore arias/ballads.

Tragédie en musique.name: Tragédie en musique
Tragédie en musique.description_short: French [Genre190] genre developed by [Artist109286] and [Artist1046230] in the second half of the 17th century, consisting of alterations made to the coeval Italian format to better fit the French language and please an audience more accustomed to the [i]ballet de cour[/i].

Verismo.name: Verismo
Verismo.description_short: Developed in Italy around the turn of the 20th century and favored melodramatic realism, a rejection of [i]bel canto[/i] standards, and declamatory singing.

Zarzuela.name: Zarzuela
Zarzuela.description_short: Spanish dramatic genre where spoken scenes are mixed with passages sung in operatic or popular styles.

Género chico.name: Género chico
Género chico.description_short: Light, small-scale musical comedy with mild social commentary, populist themes, and catchy melodies.

Zarzuela grande.name: Zarzuela grande
Zarzuela grande.description_short: Romantic musical comedy akin to [Genre10321] developed during the mid-19th century.

Zeitoper.name: Zeitoper
Zeitoper.description_short: Short-lived scene in Weimar Germany, often having satirical plots and allusions to popular music.

Oratorio.name: Oratorio
Oratorio.description_short: Composition for vocal soloists, choir, and orchestra, often making use of a comprehensive textbook of contemplative nature.

Concert Band.name: Concert Band
Concert Band.description_short: Music for large ensemble of woodwinds, brass, and percussion.

Concerto.name: Concerto
Concerto.description_short: Multi-movement classical works for orchestra and one or more soloists.

Concerto for Orchestra.name: Concerto for Orchestra
Concerto for Orchestra.description_short: Mostly modern form in which virtuosic solo passages are alternately played among different portions of the orchestra.

Concerto grosso.name: Concerto grosso
Concerto grosso.description_short: Oldest form developed during the [Genre423] era in which the body of the music is alternately shared between a small group of soloists and a larger orchestra.

Sinfonia concertante.name: Sinfonia concertante
Sinfonia concertante.description_short: Fuses symphonic compositional structure and instrumentation with parts written for concertante soloists.

Symphonic Mugham.name: Symphonic Mugham
Symphonic Mugham.description_short: Introduces elements of [Genre51189] into the structure of the composition, played on a full western orchestra.

Symphony.name: Symphony
Symphony.description_short: Large-scale [Genre183] works for orchestra, typically with four movements: 1) allegro, almost always in sonata-allegro form 2) a slow movement 3) scherzo or minuet 4) finale, typically allegro or rondo.

Tone Poem.name: Tone Poem
Tone Poem.description_short: Programmatic work, usually in a single movement, that is entirely based on external non-musical themes, ideas, tales, etc.

Overture.name: Overture
Overture.description_short: Typically single-movement form akin to the [Genre22152] written as the prelude to a larger work or in association with a programmatic concept.

Passion.name: Passion
Passion.description_short: Musical re-enactment of the suffering and crucifixion of Christ, typically based on one of the four canonical Gospels.

Prelude.name: Prelude
Prelude.description_short: Brief work with an improvisatory feeling, usually for keyboard, that serves either as a standalone piece or an introduction to a complimentary work of music.

Franco-Flemish School.name: Franco-Flemish School
Franco-Flemish School.description_short: Musical movement centered in the Low Countries, known for its intricate polyphony, emotional expression, and influence on European sacred and secular music from the 1440s to 1550.

Ricercar.name: Ricercar
Ricercar.description_short: Early instrumental genre, usually for solo lute or keyboard, written either as a brief introductory work or imitative contrapuntal piece.

Romanticism.name: Romanticism
Romanticism.description_short: Expressive and emotional qualities, especially in terms of melody.

New German School.name: New German School
New German School.description_short: Mid-19th-century Romantic movement experimenting in harmonics and form and engaged in social issues.

Serenade.name: Serenade
Serenade.description_short: Light, tuneful, and relatively straightforward music historically associated with outdoor entertainment for evening gatherings.

Sonata.name: Sonata
Sonata.description_short: Broad instrumental genre for one to three soloists that has changed significantly throughout its history, now typically a suite of four or fewer contrasting movements, at least one of which is written in sonata form.

Spanish Classical Music.name: Spanish Classical Music
Spanish Classical Music.description_short: Incorporation of [Genre31875] within the context of [Genre183], particularly characterized by the use of the classical guitar.

Theme and Variation.name: Theme and Variation
Theme and Variation.description_short: Main theme followed by a number of variations on the theme.

Toccata.name: Toccata
Toccata.description_short: Virtuoso piece, usually for solo keyboard or plucked string instrument, characterized by its free rhythm, rapid fingerwork, and contrasting sectional writing.

Country.name: Country
Country.description_short: American genre derived from Southern and Appalachian forms of [Genre31697] and later [Genre5] and [Genre36] influences, with a focus on the life and culture of rural America.

Alt-Country.name: Alt-Country
Alt-Country.description_short: Arose in the 1980s and 1990s, performed by artists with roots in [Genre116] and [Genre103] who were disconnected from the mainstream [Genre166] industry.

Gothic Country.name: Gothic Country
Gothic Country.description_short: Evokes the Southern Gothic literary genre through morbid lyrical themes and melancholic sounds that emphasize its [Genre31697] and [Genre332] influences.

Bluegrass.name: Bluegrass
Bluegrass.description_short: Born in the Appalachian region of the United States during the late 1930s, characterized by fingerpicked banjo along with other traditional instruments.

Progressive Bluegrass.name: Progressive Bluegrass
Progressive Bluegrass.description_short: Modernization with varied influences including [Genre6], [Genre26677], [Genre5], and other forms of [Genre166].

Jamgrass.name: Jamgrass
Jamgrass.description_short: Emphasizes instrumental jamming and extended performances with many outside influences.

Traditional Bluegrass.name: Traditional Bluegrass
Traditional Bluegrass.description_short: Driving tempos, acoustic stringed instrumentation, and high vocal harmonies, adhering to the stylistic roots of the [Genre172] genre.

Bluegrass Gospel.name: Bluegrass Gospel
Bluegrass Gospel.description_short: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in [Genre306].

Contemporary Country.name: Contemporary Country
Contemporary Country.description_short: Incorporates both heavily [Genre36]-influenced styles, and the more pop-averse movement of [Genre36881].

Bro-Country.name: Bro-Country
Bro-Country.description_short: 21st century style with an often party-oriented sound and lyrical content, taking strong influence from [Genre67], [Genre11] and [Genre36].

Neo-Traditionalist Country.name: Neo-Traditionalist Country
Neo-Traditionalist Country.description_short: Emerged in the late 1980s as a reaction to the increased dominance of [Genre309], moving instead towards a [Genre169]-rooted sound that centered the [Genre558].

Country & Irish.name: Country & Irish
Country & Irish.description_short: Developed in Ireland; combines North American [Genre166] with [Genre21170] influences, often in the form of traditional Irish songs that have been adapted into country numbers.

Country Boogie.name: Country Boogie
Country Boogie.description_short: Uptempo style built around the [Genre10180] rhythm, with strong beats and prominent electric guitar leads, made popular in the 1940s.

Country Folk.name: Country Folk
Country Folk.description_short: Emphasises [Genre304] instrumentation as well as influences from contemporary [Genre558] traditions, such as a gentler disposition and prominent lyrical storytelling focus.

Country Pop.name: Country Pop
Country Pop.description_short: Combination of [Genre166] with [Genre36] to appeal to a larger audience.

Countrypolitan.name: Countrypolitan
Countrypolitan.description_short: Emphasizes [Genre36]-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of [Genre166] instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

Urban Cowboy.name: Urban Cowboy
Urban Cowboy.description_short: Melds [Genre166] and 1970s L.A. soft [Genre36], sometimes leaning towards [Genre417].

Honky Tonk.name: Honky Tonk
Honky Tonk.description_short: Upbeat style that retains much of the common instrumentation of [Genre304], as well as featuring prominent guitars (especially the steel guitar), strong backbeats and lyrics commonly about the working-class life.

Bakersfield Sound.name: Bakersfield Sound
Bakersfield Sound.description_short: Heavily based on electric instrumentation and a defined backbeat.

Truck Driving Country.name: Truck Driving Country
Truck Driving Country.description_short: Concerns the lifestyle of professional truck drivers, often drawing from [Genre121] and [Genre349] musically.

Nashville Sound.name: Nashville Sound
Nashville Sound.description_short: Production style characterized by smooth vocals over a relaxed ensemble of guitars and rhythm section, and variously incorporating elements from other styles of [Genre166] and [Genre36].

Progressive Country.name: Progressive Country
Progressive Country.description_short: Blend of traditionalist [Genre166] styles with elements of [Genre5], [Genre209], and other countercultural genres; characterized by realistic, self-reflective lyrics and non-traditional songwriting and production elements.

Outlaw Country.name: Outlaw Country
Outlaw Country.description_short: [Genre5]-influenced reaction to mainstream [Genre309] trends, featuring rebellious personas, darker lyrics, and [Genre307]-inspired outlaw imagery.

Traditional Country.name: Traditional Country
Traditional Country.description_short: Closely aligned with [Genre31697] and [Genre131] roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of [Genre169] and [Genre309] in the 1950s.

Close Harmony.name: Close Harmony
Close Harmony.description_short: Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.

Country Gospel.name: Country Gospel
Country Gospel.description_short: Incorporates the harmonies and Christian themes of [Genre10014].

Country Yodeling.name: Country Yodeling
Country Yodeling.description_short: Vocal technique of [Genre354], brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of [Genre304].

Western.name: Western
Western.description_short: Reflects and portrays the lifestyles of cowboys and other settlers of the Western United States through both [Genre10448] and popular song.

Western Swing.name: Western Swing
Western Swing.description_short: Blend of [Genre304] string instrumentation with the driving rhythms of [Genre6] and regional dance traditions, often prominently featuring fiddle and steel guitar.

Dance.name: Dance
Dance.description_short: Rooted in [Genre417] and developed largely within [Genre31431]; emphasizes rhythm and is generally produced for play by DJs at clubs, parties, or festivals.

Alternative Dance.name: Alternative Dance
Alternative Dance.description_short: Incorporates rhythms and synthesizers from [Genre31431] within the context of [Genre116] and related styles; predominantly popular in the 1990s.

Grebo.name: Grebo
Grebo.description_short: Short-lived English subculture and associated music; raw, futuristic, sample-heavy form of [Genre418] with a dirty guitar sound.

New Rave.name: New Rave
New Rave.description_short: High energy mid-2000s style combining the tight and punchy grooves of [Genre61021] with synths and four-on-the-floor rhythms from genres like [Genre322] and [Genre21082].

Dance-Pop.name: Dance-Pop
Dance-Pop.description_short: Simple, yet catchy melodies and throbbing beats inspired initially by [Genre417] and later various [Genre463] styles.

Bubblegum Dance.name: Bubblegum Dance
Bubblegum Dance.description_short: Playful, childlike style with a [Genre112]-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.

Disco polo.name: Disco polo
Disco polo.description_short: Polish [Genre459], originally established from contemporary wedding / feast songs and [Genre321].

Freestyle.name: Freestyle
Freestyle.description_short: [Genre319]-influenced; developed in Latino communities in New York and Miami in the 1980s, especially dominated by [Genre26221] and its Latin influences.

Latin Freestyle.name: Latin Freestyle
Latin Freestyle.description_short: Displays a heavy influence of [Genre519] alongside the [Genre417], [Genre11], and [Genre319] influences of [Genre20937].

Funk melody.name: Funk melody
Funk melody.description_short: Light and melodic take on [Genre21335], developed alongside [Genre57803].

Romanian Popcorn.name: Romanian Popcorn
Romanian Popcorn.description_short: Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and "staccato" pluck grooves.

Tecnorumba.name: Tecnorumba
Tecnorumba.description_short: Blend of the themes and singing style of [Genre26259] with the most commercial forms of [Genre463], [Genre91], and [Genre25846].

Township Bubblegum.name: Township Bubblegum
Township Bubblegum.description_short: Synth-heavy [Genre459] style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.

Disco.name: Disco
Disco.description_short: Combines the lush orchestration of [Genre10346] and bass grooves of [Genre255] with a four-on-the-floor rhythm.

Boogie.name: Boogie
Boogie.description_short: Continuation of the [Genre417] sound with increased influence from [Genre255], [Genre26521], and [Genre31829] and a slower tempo, often featuring drum machines and filter modulated synthesizers.

Electro-Disco.name: Electro-Disco
Electro-Disco.description_short: Disco instrumentation is largely - if not entirely - replaced by synthesizers and augmented with futuristic elements such as the vocoder.

Hi-NRG.name: Hi-NRG
Hi-NRG.description_short: Emerged in the late 1970s and quickly became the most popular form of [Genre31431] in the LGBT club scenes of San Francisco and New York, characterized by its uptempo, high-energy sound.

Italo-Disco.name: Italo-Disco
Italo-Disco.description_short: Produced primarily in Italy and is characterized by the use of synthesizers, drum machines, and sometimes vocoders to create a mechanical, [Genre82] version of [Genre417] with futuristic atmosphere.

Spacesynth.name: Spacesynth
Spacesynth.description_short: Highly melodic, often instrumental futuristic strain, formed under the heavy influence of [genre21688], [genre10035] and, later, early [genre29254].

Doskpop.name: Doskpop
Doskpop.description_short: Grew out of the Amiga [Genre61973] in the late 1980s with the imitation of [Genre10452] in the context of the restrictions and aesthetics of [Genre58813].

Red Disco.name: Red Disco
Red Disco.description_short: Continuum of various eclectic forms, derived mainly from late [Genre26628], but also [Genre321], [Genre592] and [Genre29254], and developed in the Soviet Union in the mid-to-late 1980s.

Space Disco.name: Space Disco
Space Disco.description_short: Emerged in Europe in the mid-to-late 1970s, characterized by layers of oscillating synth, space-oriented sound effects, and a futuristic sound inspired by contemporary sci-fi media.

Euro-Disco.name: Euro-Disco
Euro-Disco.description_short: European style that moved away from the genre's [Genre231] and [Genre235] roots, speeding up the tempo and adding [Genre82] instruments like synthesizers and drum machines as a backing for more melodic [Genre396]-influenced vocals.

Mutant Disco.name: Mutant Disco
Mutant Disco.description_short: Danceable basslines, syncopated grooves, and angular guitar riffs, characterized by a spirit of experimentation and integration of disparate sounds.

Nu-Disco.name: Nu-Disco
Nu-Disco.description_short: 21st-century trend mixing modern, polished [Genre82] production with the aesthetics, structures, and lively, organic beats of 1970s and 1980s [Genre417].

Electronic Dance Music.name: Electronic Dance Music
Electronic Dance Music.description_short: Broad category for subgenres mainly derived from [Genre417], featuring [Genre82] sounds, synthesizers, drum machines and varying BPM ranges.

Artcore.name: Artcore
Artcore.description_short: Combines an eclectic mix of [Genre31431] genres with the instrumentation and melodic stylings of genres like [Genre42898] for a maximalist and emotional sound.

Balani Show.name: Balani Show
Balani Show.description_short: Emerged in the late 1990s in Mali; peaks at around 170BPM and prominently features looping, cut-up balafon samples.

Balearic Beat.name: Balearic Beat
Balearic Beat.description_short: Variety of relaxed, laid-back music that originates from the Balearic Islands off the coast of Spain, and particularly the club scene in Ibiza.

Bérite Club.name: Bérite Club
Bérite Club.description_short: Originated in the underground club scene of Paris in the mid-to-late 2010s, drawing on a variety of international club styles for its combination of prominent and erratic drum programming with freezing and looping chopped-up samples.

Breakbeat.name: Breakbeat
Breakbeat.description_short: Umbrella of affiliated [Genre31431] styles broadly featuring prominent syncopated drum patterns (called breakbeats) that emerged from [Genre25191]'s initial influence, not including styles directly related to [Genre86] and [Genre143].

Acid Breaks.name: Acid Breaks
Acid Breaks.description_short: Incorporates prominent "squelching", resonant low pass filter sounds typical to [Genre464], and often other "trippy" effects into intense, syncopated, broken rhythms in the tempos of 110-150 BPM.

Baltimore Club.name: Baltimore Club
Baltimore Club.description_short: Drew on the "booty bass" syncopation of [Genre326], combined with [Genre85] rhythms around 130 BPM and chopped up vocal samples as found in [Genre29836].

Big Beat.name: Big Beat
Big Beat.description_short: Popular in Britain during the late 1990s, driven by edited breakbeats and prominent basslines.

Breakbeat Hardcore.name: Breakbeat Hardcore
Breakbeat Hardcore.description_short: Originated from the combination of sampled breakbeats and energetic rhythms with the "rave" influences set by early-1990s [Genre91] and [Genre464], including upbeat "stab" riffing and sample-based production.

Darkside.name: Darkside
Darkside.description_short: Dark atmosphere and fast rhythms; served as a forerunner of [Genre86].

Hardcore Breaks.name: Hardcore Breaks
Hardcore Breaks.description_short: Revival of [Genre25191] which emerged in the 2000s, bringing in modern influences and production techniques.

Breakbeat Kota.name: Breakbeat Kota
Breakbeat Kota.description_short: Indonesian style that slows down the syncopated rhythms of [Genre36004] to moderate tempos around 130 BPM.

Jungle Dutch.name: Jungle Dutch
Jungle Dutch.description_short: Combines the high-pitched synth leads of [Genre29430] with the frantic "tribal" rhythms of [Genre36174].

Florida Breaks.name: Florida Breaks
Florida Breaks.description_short: Developed during the mid-1990s, combining major influences of [Genre11] derivatives such as [Genre326] and [Genre319] along with elements of 1990s [Genre31431] genres like [Genre463] or [Genre91].

Funky Breaks.name: Funky Breaks
Funky Breaks.description_short: Merging popular 1990s breaks styles like [Genre10119] with major [Genre255] and [Genre235] elements.

Nu Skool Breaks.name: Nu Skool Breaks
Nu Skool Breaks.description_short: Developed in the late 1990s and early 2000s; takes elements from [Genre86], [Genre10477], and [Genre91].

Progressive Breaks.name: Progressive Breaks
Progressive Breaks.description_short: Derivative of [Genre10193] that incorporates its lush, melodic synth leads and atmospheres into [Genre85]'s syncopated and broken rhythms.

Psybreaks.name: Psybreaks
Psybreaks.description_short: Uses [Genre10122]-derived sound design, such as squelchy sounds and psychedelic effects.

West Coast Breaks.name: West Coast Breaks
West Coast Breaks.description_short: Combines the earlier breakbeats of [Genre11] and early [Genre85] or even [Genre326], with various 1990s [Genre31431] genres like [Genre93] and [Genre91].

Broken Beat.name: Broken Beat
Broken Beat.description_short: Syncopated rhythm patterns arrived at through [Genre86] programming techniques; originally developed by artists hailing from [Genre91], [Genre463], drum and bass, and [Genre11] backgrounds.

Bubblegum Bass.name: Bubblegum Bass
Bubblegum Bass.description_short: Originated in the early 2010s, exaggerating the cutest and most feminine parts of 2000s [Genre36] and combining them with bouncy, plastic synths over rhythms and sounds derived from a variety of contemporary club styles.

Bubbling.name: Bubbling
Bubbling.description_short: Originating in the Netherlands in the late 1980s, fusing sped-up [Genre302] with Dutch Antillean music and contemporary Dutch rave.

Budots.name: Budots
Budots.description_short: Originated from the southern Philippines; notable for its distinct high-pitched synth hooks.

Coupé-décalé.name: Coupé-décalé
Coupé-décalé.description_short: Bass-heavy and minimal style of Ivorian popular dance music, drawing heavily from [Genre27667] and Congolese rhythms.

Cruise.name: Cruise
Cruise.description_short: Fast-paced Nigerian dance music, utilising chopped, often humorous, samples.

Dariacore.name: Dariacore
Dariacore.description_short: SoundCloud-based scene developed in the early 2020s, combining prominent vocal samples and distorted, dense production with influences from a wide range of [Genre31431] genres, often incorporating musical and visual references to popular media and internet culture.

Deconstructed Club.name: Deconstructed Club
Deconstructed Club.description_short: Emerged in the 2010s as the hybridization of diverse [Genre31431] genres with an abrasive [Genre38714] sound.

Dek Bass.name: Dek Bass
Dek Bass.description_short: Prominent heavy, sustained bass tones, percussion derived from [Genre622], and often high-pitched sound effects or samples; commonly played at extreme volumes in DJ/sound system competitions.

Digital Cumbia.name: Digital Cumbia
Digital Cumbia.description_short: Mixes an [Genre82] sound into traditional [Genre10047] through influences from [Genre463], [Genre302], [Genre135], and [Genre638].

Drum and Bass.name: Drum and Bass
Drum and Bass.description_short: Fast, syncopated breakbeat patterns (often sampled or programmed) with prominent basslines, commonly within the 160-180 BPM range.

Atmospheric Drum and Bass.name: Atmospheric Drum and Bass
Atmospheric Drum and Bass.description_short: Prominent in the mid-1990s, uses faster, de-emphasized breakbeats, and places a greater focus on melodic elements such as slow, warm basslines and atmospheric melodies inspired by [Genre84] and [Genre553].

Dancefloor Drum and Bass.name: Dancefloor Drum and Bass
Dancefloor Drum and Bass.description_short: Emerged in the late 2000s as a more accessible and polished style with melodic, prominent synth leads derived from [Genre258] and punchy, often synthesized drums.

Darkstep.name: Darkstep
Darkstep.description_short: Hard, uptempo and uses heavy breakbeats, [Genre38714]-influenced sound design, and horror movie samples to create a sinister, claustrophobic atmosphere.

Crossbreed.name: Crossbreed
Crossbreed.description_short: Harsh and dense mixture of [Genre249] with [Genre272] developed in the late 2000s.

Skullstep.name: Skullstep
Skullstep.description_short: Repetitious, aggressive, off-beat rhythms often programmed using distorted, harsh, and noisy percussion that usually resembles clangy "pots and pans", machine gun-like snares.

Drumfunk.name: Drumfunk
Drumfunk.description_short: Focuses on complex drum beats made to emulate live recordings.

Drumstep.name: Drumstep
Drumstep.description_short: Dancefloor-friendly, loud, and heavy combination of the drum programming and tempo of [Genre258] with the half-time rhythm and midrange LFO wobble of [Genre31624].

Dubwise Drum and Bass.name: Dubwise Drum and Bass
Dubwise Drum and Bass.description_short: Implementing [Genre144] and [Genre150] influences, usually vocal dubs, delay effects, and reggae instrumentation, with the clean production and rhythms of post-2000s styles.

Footwork Jungle.name: Footwork Jungle
Footwork Jungle.description_short: Combining [Genre30431]'s archetypal percussion, skittering drum fills, handclaps, and syncopated rhythms, with [genre86] drum programming and breakbeats, merging the two into unconventional, frantic drumming and dense, off-kilter rhythms.

Halftime.name: Halftime
Halftime.description_short: Offshoot of [Genre86] (mainly [Genre261]) characterized by off-kilter rhythms playing at around 80-85 BPM (half of normal DnB pace), influenced by [Genre638], [Genre29689], [Genre32535], and [Genre11].

Hardstep.name: Hardstep
Hardstep.description_short: Very compressed and sparse drumming, extensive use of kick drums and gritty, minimalistic production style with emphasis on simple, deep, modulated bass patterns.

Jazzstep.name: Jazzstep
Jazzstep.description_short: Combines the rhythm and speed of [Genre86] with the melodies, composition, and instrumentation of [Genre6].

Jump-Up.name: Jump-Up
Jump-Up.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1990s, characterized by loud "wobbling" basslines, simpler drum loops, and a light-hearted and warm sound.

Jungle.name: Jungle
Jungle.description_short: Developed in the early 1990s from [Genre25191], featuring rapid, chaotic-sounding breakbeats and strong basslines; known as the forerunner of most [Genre86] styles.

Ragga Jungle.name: Ragga Jungle
Ragga Jungle.description_short: Developed in the early 1990s in London, combining [Genre143] breakbeats with heavy influence from [Genre589].

Liquid Drum and Bass.name: Liquid Drum and Bass
Liquid Drum and Bass.description_short: Atmospheric and melodic genre that developed in the early 2000s; utilizes polished and smooth production, simpler structures, and originally sampled [Genre255] and [Genre235].

Sambass.name: Sambass
Sambass.description_short: Combines [Genre86] tempos and drum patterns, in addition to its [Genre255] and [Genre235] influences, with various styles of [Genre542].

Minimal Drum and Bass.name: Minimal Drum and Bass
Minimal Drum and Bass.description_short: [Genre86] which strips down the sound as far as it can go without wholly ceasing to be drum and bass.

Autonomic.name: Autonomic
Autonomic.description_short: Mechanical, machine-like, "autonomic" rhythms that take primary influence from the cold, minimal sounds of mid-2000s UK [Genre638].

Microfunk.name: Microfunk
Microfunk.description_short: Minimal, glitchy, and "bleep"-y sound inspired by [Genre90].

Neurofunk.name: Neurofunk
Neurofunk.description_short: Focuses on technical songwriting with warped, complex bass sounds, distorted and modulated synths (often with repeated stabs over the basslines), and dark but clean production.

Techstep.name: Techstep
Techstep.description_short: Futuristic, dark, and gritty sound; quantized and compressed drum breaks, distorted bass lines, and a focus on a sci-fi atmosphere and sampling sources.

Trancestep.name: Trancestep
Trancestep.description_short: Combination of [Genre93] melodies and structure with the breakbeats, fast tempos, and rolling basslines of [Genre86].

Dubstep.name: Dubstep
Dubstep.description_short: Half-time syncopated and sparse beats set around 140 BPM with heavy sub-basses; emerged in South London in the early 2000s.

Brostep.name: Brostep
Brostep.description_short: Offshoot of [Genre638] which replaces its sub-bass-oriented sound with an emphasis on catchy or aggressive mid-range melodies.

Briddim.name: Briddim
Briddim.description_short: Combining the kick-clap rhythms and syncopation of [Genre36214] with [Genre31624] sound design.

Colour Bass.name: Colour Bass
Colour Bass.description_short: Combines aggressive wobbling basses with the euphoric drops of [Genre42616] and [Genre41388].

Deathstep.name: Deathstep
Deathstep.description_short: Darker, heavier form of [Genre31624] that uses "machine gun" basses, atonal synths, and elements from genres like [Genre138] and [Genre545].

Minatory.name: Minatory
Minatory.description_short: Extreme, experimental style of [Genre32868], with a harsh sound and sudden BPM changes.

Tearout [Brostep].name: Tearout [Brostep]
Tearout [Brostep].description_short: Heavy and distorted, closely affiliated with [Genre32868] and other styles of [Genre31624].

Dungeon Sound.name: Dungeon Sound
Dungeon Sound.description_short: Commonly features dark textures, spatial production, and midrange basses.

Melodic Dubstep.name: Melodic Dubstep
Melodic Dubstep.description_short: Melodious, tuneful drops, rich, lush synth leads, powerful stretched chords, and light and harmonious sound design.

Purple Sound.name: Purple Sound
Purple Sound.description_short: Emerged in the late 2000s out of the [Genre638] scene of the time, incorporating synth leads and basslines inspired by 1980s [Genre26521] and 1990s [Genre113], and [genre475], into a rhythmic palette mostly derived from dubstep and [genre26].

Riddim.name: Riddim
Riddim.description_short: Repetitive and relatively simplistic style inspired by mid-to-late-2000s UK [Genre638], often using robotic and/or squishy sound design along with bouncy square basses and less prominent buildups.

Future Riddim.name: Future Riddim
Future Riddim.description_short: Melodic and futuristic style inspired by [Genre41388], and to a lesser extent [Genre50666] and [Genre42616].

Tearout.name: Tearout
Tearout.description_short: Emerged in the late 2000s, characterized by a gritty, aggressive sound and closely affiliated with early, deep [Genre638].

East Coast Club.name: East Coast Club
East Coast Club.description_short: Group of club styles from the US East Coast that combines [Genre326] rhythms with influence from [Genre85] and [Genre29836].

Jersey Club.name: Jersey Club
Jersey Club.description_short: Emerged in Newark in the late 2000s; features fast tempos, hard kicks, and less prominent breakbeats.

Philly Club.name: Philly Club
Philly Club.description_short: Builds on [Genre27030] with a faster tempo and sometimes influences from more modern genres like [Genre32535].

EBM.name: EBM
EBM.description_short: Melodic and dancefloor-friendly take on [Genre38714] music that developed in the early 1980s.

Dark Electro.name: Dark Electro
Dark Electro.description_short: Emerged in the early 1990s in Europe, incorporating the abrasiveness of old school [Genre336] but with a greater focus on a horror-inspired atmosphere and harsh, distorted vocals.

Aggrotech.name: Aggrotech
Aggrotech.description_short: Merges aggressive-sounding synths and apocalyptic atmospheres with harsh 4/4 beats and fast tempos.

Futurepop.name: Futurepop
Futurepop.description_short: Derivative of [Genre337], retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of [Genre382].

New Beat.name: New Beat
New Beat.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1980s in Belgium; characterized by dark basslines, hard-hitting grooves and a slow tempo.

Hard Beat.name: Hard Beat
Hard Beat.description_short: Short-lived, harder, harsh form of [Genre10404] with [Genre336], [Genre464] and [Genre337]-influenced arrangement.

Electro.name: Electro
Electro.description_short: Syncopated rhythms programmed on the Roland TR-808 drum machine, often resembling [Genre255] breaks, along with simple funky basslines.

Electroclash.name: Electroclash
Electroclash.description_short: Draws from 1980s styles such as [Genre319], [Genre129], and [Genre320] combined with [Genre91], resulting in minimal, throbbing beats and basslines, buzzing synthesizer parts, vocoders and often monotone, half-spoken, half-sung vocals.

Electro latino.name: Electro latino
Electro latino.description_short: Mixes elements of [genre10299] and [genre590] with polished production from mainstream [genre463] subgenres; often shares traits with [genre583], having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

Electro Swing.name: Electro Swing
Electro Swing.description_short: Upbeat, energetic style that splices [Genre624] with [Genre31431], looking to recapture the atmosphere of late 1920s to mid-1940s [Genre6] within a more updated club-friendly medium.

Eurobeat.name: Eurobeat
Eurobeat.description_short: Fast-paced with roots in [Genre592] and [Genre321]; became mainly popular in Japan in the 1990s.

J-Euro.name: J-Euro
J-Euro.description_short: Italian-oriented Japanese scene of [Genre29254], which emerged with Japanese-language covers of Italian songs in the early-to-mid-1990s.

Eurodance.name: Eurodance
Eurodance.description_short: Takes elements of [Genre26628], [Genre463], [Genre91], and [Genre592] while featuring on-beat kick, hi-hat and snare sounds at around 110 to 150 bpm.

Italo Dance.name: Italo Dance
Italo Dance.description_short: Appeared in the 1990s after the decline of [Genre321], featuring rhythmic influence from that genre.

Footwork.name: Footwork
Footwork.description_short: Extensive use of drum fills, tom drums, handclaps, and snares within fast-paced, highly syncopated beats not bound to a 4/4 kick rhythm.

Funk mandelão.name: Funk mandelão
Funk mandelão.description_short: Simple lyricism, raw and minimalistic production, and distinct drops with bursting bass.

Beat bruxaria.name: Beat bruxaria
Beat bruxaria.description_short: São Paulo-originated [Genre21335] with aggressive, distorted and high-pitched beats featuring minimalistic percussion and diversified sampling.

Brazilian Phonk.name: Brazilian Phonk
Brazilian Phonk.description_short: Merges [Genre60153]'s rhythms, vocals, and energy, with the energetic and nocturnal production typical of the [Genre53354] scene, and [Genre57658].

Funk automotivo.name: Funk automotivo
Funk automotivo.description_short: Catchy, repetitive synths accompanied by a strong four-on-the-floor kick and loud, reverberated vocals.

Ritmada.name: Ritmada
Ritmada.description_short: Short, repetitive and resonant beats with more danceable, immersive grooves drawn out of Afro-Brazilian instrumentation, a cleaner, more radio-friendly sound and greater focus on lyrics.

Funkot.name: Funkot
Funkot.description_short: Fast-paced Indonesian form of [Genre31431] that combines [Genre421] and [Genre93] synths with the syncopated rhythm from [Genre38047].

Future Bass.name: Future Bass
Future Bass.description_short: Woozy, detuned synthesizers, 7th chords, harsh basslines, syncopated percussion with fast-paced hi-hats and a melodic, carefree atmosphere.

Kawaii Future Bass.name: Kawaii Future Bass
Kawaii Future Bass.description_short: "Cute" style of [Genre41388] rooted in anime and video game culture; emerged in Japan in the mid-2010s.

Future Core.name: Future Core
Future Core.description_short: Blends the speed, basslines, and rhythms of [Genre43776] (mostly coming from the [Genre32019] sphere) with euphoric, woozy synths, 7th chords and arpeggios, and vocal chops of [Genre41388], particularly [Genre42952].

Future Rave.name: Future Rave
Future Rave.description_short: Emerged in the late 2010s by combining the mainstage EDM approach with influences from then-popular forms of [Genre91] and old-school [Genre93]/rave-inspired grooves and atmospheres.

Ghettotech.name: Ghettotech
Ghettotech.description_short: Fuses the syncopation and synthesized sounds of [Genre319] and [Genre462] with the cut-up samples of [Genre29836] and fast rhythms of [Genre326].

Glitch Hop [EDM].name: Glitch Hop [EDM]
Glitch Hop [EDM].description_short: Tempos around 100-110 BPM, swung, bouncy drum patterns, and a focus on upbeat, danceable drops and buildups.

Ghetto Funk.name: Ghetto Funk
Ghetto Funk.description_short: Rich sampling, drawing from classic [Genre11] as well as from [Genre255] and [Genre235], and strong midtempo break grooves.

Neurohop.name: Neurohop
Neurohop.description_short: Features the complex bass of [Genre261] and a frantic and mechanical sound design.

Grime.name: Grime
Grime.description_short: [Genre10477]-derived production style characterized by dark, fast-paced, often aggressive beats that commonly features fast-paced MCing.

Neo-Grime.name: Neo-Grime
Neo-Grime.description_short: Mixes [Genre43100] with [Genre26] and other forms of UK [Genre82] music.

Weightless.name: Weightless
Weightless.description_short: Typically instrumental, leftfield [Genre26] style characterized by sparse, "weightless" percussion and spectral, atmospheric production.

Hardcore [EDM].name: Hardcore [EDM]
Hardcore [EDM].description_short: Umbrella term for a wide variety of fast-paced and energetic [Genre31431] styles that have been developed since the early 1990s.

Acidcore.name: Acidcore
Acidcore.description_short: Developed out of the 1990s [genre270] scene utilizing its prominence of "acid" TB-303 bassline sequences into more intense rhythms derived from earlier [Genre272], [genre276] and [genre93] music.

Amigacore.name: Amigacore
Amigacore.description_short: [Genre276]-like forms of [Genre272,Hardcore] written in first-gen trackers for the [GamePlatform4,Amiga] like ProTracker and OctaMED, resulting in a minimalistic raw lo-fi sound.

Belgian Techno.name: Belgian Techno
Belgian Techno.description_short: Early form of [Genre272], resulting from the further evolution of [Genre10404] due to the strong influence of [Genre91] and [Genre337].

Breakcore.name: Breakcore
Breakcore.description_short: Mixes [Genre272] with cut-up, complex, and frequently noisy breakbeats at very high tempos inspired by [Genre143] and [Genre86], often with heavy use of sampling.

Lolicore.name: Lolicore
Lolicore.description_short: Heavily distorted or high-pitched anime vocal samples and complex cut-up breakbeats with extreme tempos.

Mashcore.name: Mashcore
Mashcore.description_short: Sampling, particularly from [Genre36] and [Genre31431], as well as playful melodies, hard kicks, and the typical breakcore breakbeats.

Raggacore.name: Raggacore
Raggacore.description_short: Prominently incorporates samples from [Genre589] and [Genre302], typically through shouted vocal lines and [Genre144]-influenced instrumentals.

Darkcore.name: Darkcore
Darkcore.description_short: Aggressive, dark, and often midtempo with influences from [Genre43736], [Genre43410], and [Genre27887].

Deathchant Hardcore.name: Deathchant Hardcore
Deathchant Hardcore.description_short: Took shape in the UK in the late 1990s and early 2000s, characterized by rapid rhythms with [Genre276]-influenced kicks, frequent use of breakbeats and [Genre11]-inspired sampling.

Digital Hardcore.name: Digital Hardcore
Digital Hardcore.description_short: High-tempo fusion of [Genre333] and [Genre82], combining harsh vocals and electric guitars of the former with electronic instruments.

Doomcore.name: Doomcore
Doomcore.description_short: Often somber and contemplative in mood, a feature achieved by the common use of long-stretched ambient pads, and sometimes even samples of screaming and other "spooky" sounds.

Freeform Hardcore.name: Freeform Hardcore
Freeform Hardcore.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1990s, combining fast and hard-hitting rhythms with heavy influence from the synthesizers of [Genre93].

Frenchcore.name: Frenchcore
Frenchcore.description_short: Off-beat, bouncy rhythmic patterns and tempos around the 200 BPM range.

Gabber.name: Gabber
Gabber.description_short: Fast-paced and energetic, often in the 160-220 BPM range, with a hallmark of a distinctive distorted kick sound.

Nu Style Gabber.name: Nu Style Gabber
Nu Style Gabber.description_short: Emerged near the end of the 1990s; deeper, more harmonic bassdrums with constant use of supersaw melodies, breakdown sections and slower tempos closer to the 150-180 BPM range.

Happy Hardcore.name: Happy Hardcore
Happy Hardcore.description_short: Emerged in the 1990s from the UK [Genre25191] scene; characterized by saccharine vocals, uplifting piano riffs and spacey effects, gradually developing to emphasize extremely fast-paced four-on-the-floor beats.

Bouncy Techno.name: Bouncy Techno
Bouncy Techno.description_short: Average tempo of 160 to 180 BPM, four-on-the-floor beats, melodic and repetitive synth melodies, drums with hard kicks, short breaks, progressive stomping rhythms, and offbeat notes.

UK Hardcore.name: UK Hardcore
UK Hardcore.description_short: Four-on-the-floor beat around 175 BPM, thick, prominent basslines, and uplifting synth leads, with a cleaner and more accessible sound than other forms of [Genre272].

Powerstomp.name: Powerstomp
Powerstomp.description_short: Prominent, "stomping", and slightly distorted kick, relentless, repetitive reverse basses on the offbeats (borrowed from [Genre21072]) that drive the tracks, giving the genre its distinct energetic sound, and cacophonous, noisy riffs and synth leads.

Hardtek.name: Hardtek
Hardtek.description_short: Modern version of the "tribecore" sound featuring deep alternating basses and festival EDM-influenced drops.

Raggatek.name: Raggatek
Raggatek.description_short: Influenced by [genre144], [genre589] and [genre302], combining half-time instrumental sections with [genre53676]'s fast four-on-the-floor rhythms, as well as vocal samples, clean basslines and skank rhythms.

Industrial Hardcore.name: Industrial Hardcore
Industrial Hardcore.description_short: Fuses the sonic palettes and aesthetics of [Genre336] with the intense rhythms of [Genre276], [Genre273], [Genre43736] and other subsequent styles.

Speedcore.name: Speedcore
Speedcore.description_short: Exceedingly fast tempos, frequently above 300 BPM, and often aggressive themes and samples.

Extratone.name: Extratone
