Extratone.description_short: At and above the threshold of 1000 BPM where sequences of kick drums begin to form a continuous pitch.

Splittercore.name: Splittercore
Splittercore.description_short: Faster version of [Genre273] with BPM ranging from around 600 to 1000.

Terrorcore.name: Terrorcore
Terrorcore.description_short: Utilizes rhythms from earlier [Genre276] with a faster BPM (usually no more than 300) and darker approach.

Uptempo Hardcore.name: Uptempo Hardcore
Uptempo Hardcore.description_short: Utilizes lo-fi production, harsh kicks, and elements borrowed from [Genre47102] and other gritty [Genre272] styles while usually sitting at around 185-220 BPM.

Hard Dance.name: Hard Dance
Hard Dance.description_short: Umbrella term for EDM mainly developed out of [Genre27342] and [Genre26255]; usually characterized by fast tempos, hard kick drums and a "bouncy" syncopated groove.

Hardstyle.name: Hardstyle
Hardstyle.description_short: Hard, four-on-the-floor kick drums, fast tempo around 150 BPM, reverse bass and harsh, distorted synths.

Dubstyle.name: Dubstyle
Dubstyle.description_short: Characterized by the incorporation of the half-time rhythms and wobbly basslines of [Genre638].

Early Hardstyle.name: Early Hardstyle
Early Hardstyle.description_short: Forerunner subgenre that emerged around the turn of the 2000s from [Genre27342] and [Genre276], distinguished by the signature reverse bass groove, slower tempo around 140 BPM and straightforward, repetitive sound.

Nustyle.name: Nustyle
Nustyle.description_short: Developed out of early hardstyle from the mid-to-late 2000s, by incorporating distorted, crunchy, pitched kicks, faster tempo around 150 BPM, and detuned supersaw/square synth leads playing stompy, dramatic melodies.

Psystyle.name: Psystyle
Psystyle.description_short: Prominent [Genre10122] influences, especially the basslines and energy of mainstream psytrance.

Rawstyle.name: Rawstyle
Rawstyle.description_short: Incorporates earlier [Genre21072] and [Genre272] influences into the sound of 2010s hardstyle, creating a distinctly harsh, simplistic, raw, and dark sound, with fast BPM.

Rawphoric.name: Rawphoric
Rawphoric.description_short: Combines raw harsh kicks with the uplifting melodies of [Genre46815].

Hard Trance.name: Hard Trance
Hard Trance.description_short: Rave-oriented form of [genre93] infusing its atmospheres with faster, thumping rhythms and strong melodic / bassline sections, initially spawning out of the first wave in early-1990s Western Europe.

Jumpstyle.name: Jumpstyle
Jumpstyle.description_short: Features a heavy 909 kick drum, four-on-the-floor beat, and a tempo between 140 and 150 BPM.

Lento violento.name: Lento violento
Lento violento.description_short: Features a "slow and violent" sound between 70-120 BPM with hard kicks inspired by [Genre272] and [Genre21072].

NRG.name: NRG
NRG.description_short: Derived from [Genre26255]; featuring darker, more anthemic [Genre93] beats and a tempo of 155-165 BPM.

UK Hard House.name: UK Hard House
UK Hard House.description_short: Defined by offbeat bass patterns, compressed 909-style drums, buildup-drop structures, hoover sounds, and tempos between 120 and 155 BPM.

Scouse House.name: Scouse House
Scouse House.description_short: Features an upbeat and energetic sound often described as being "bouncy", influenced somewhat by [Genre567].

Hardbass.name: Hardbass
Hardbass.description_short: Bouncy hard bass beats, fast tempo, usually 150-175 BPM, and occasional lyrics or rapping.

Speed House.name: Speed House
Speed House.description_short: Mixes busy, dirty sound design and intense drums derived from [Genre38616] with fast tempos from 140-160 BPM, pumping basslines, and other [Genre26255] influences.

Hard Drum.name: Hard Drum
Hard Drum.description_short: Highly percussive, syncopated rhythms, influences from global contemporary genres, and lack of melodic elements, with a tempo lingering around 130 BPM.

Hardvapour.name: Hardvapour
Hardvapour.description_short: Influenced by [Genre272] and [Genre91] and made in response to the [Genre32584] movement.

Hardwave.name: Hardwave
Hardwave.description_short: Harder, festival-oriented offshoot of [Genre43100], combining its "reese" basses and icy synths with [Genre32535] drum patterns, build-up-drop structures, and fuller sound influenced by [Genre93] and [Genre21072].

House.name: House
House.description_short: Large, hugely popular group of related [Genre31431] styles, initially developing from [Genre417] in the early 1980s.

Acid House.name: Acid House
Acid House.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1980s, characterised by repetitive basslines created with the distinctive modulated "squelching" sound of the Roland TB-303 synthesiser.

Afro House.name: Afro House
Afro House.description_short: Emerged by fusing [Genre471] with [Genre32057], characterized by hypnotizing drum patterns of shakers and congas, often sampled African vocals or soulful original features, and spiritual, organic, melodic atmosphere.

3-Step.name: 3-Step
3-Step.description_short: Distinct three-kick-drum rhythm, blends influences from [Genre43297] and [Genre10504], resulting in relaxed, freeform, playful, [Genre6]-like feel.

Amapiano.name: Amapiano
Amapiano.description_short: [Genre463] from South Africa deriving from previous popular genres including [Genre37157], [Genre20939], and [Genre471].

Afropiano.name: Afropiano
Afropiano.description_short: Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic [Genre33642] sound and rhythms with major [Genre43297] elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.

Ambient House.name: Ambient House
Ambient House.description_short: Primarily British genre developed in the 1990s with beats, synthesizers, and vocals in styles similar to [Genre463], treated with effects that are often described as "dream-like" or "chilled out".

Ballroom.name: Ballroom
Ballroom.description_short: Emerging from the predominantly Black and LGBT Harlem ballroom culture, it is characterized by hard-hitting rhythms, generally improvised chanting by MCs known as commentators, and a distinctive crash sample.

Bass House.name: Bass House
Bass House.description_short: Busy, punchy percussion, prominent basslines and dirty, distorted synths resembling other bass music genres, with influences including [Genre31624], [Genre26732], [Genre21107], [Genre29835], and [Genre10366].

Bassline.name: Bassline
Bassline.description_short: Strong emphasis on intricate basslines as well as four-on-the-floor beat patterns.

Big Room House.name: Big Room House
Big Room House.description_short: Energetic, festival-oriented style characterized by heavy reverb, intense build-ups, strong kicks, minimalistic drop melodies, and sparse, raw breakdowns.

Brazilian Bass.name: Brazilian Bass
Brazilian Bass.description_short: Originated in the 2010s in Brazil, taking influences from [Genre471] and [Genre10366], characterized by deep, punchy basslines making use of detuning and filtering effects.

Mega funk.name: Mega funk
Mega funk.description_short: Blends funk vocal performances with production derived from mainstage 2010s [Genre463] genres like [Genre47275] and [Genre47366].

Slap House.name: Slap House
Slap House.description_short: Taking influences from [Genre47275] and [Genre37063], characterized by prominent, "bouncy" bassline and simple, upbeat melodies.

Bubbling House.name: Bubbling House
Bubbling House.description_short: Developed in the Netherlands in the 2000s, combining the older style of [Genre43053] with more modern [Genre463], especially [Genre29430].

Changa tuki.name: Changa tuki
Changa tuki.description_short: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s [Genre91] and [Genre21222], featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

Chicago Hard House.name: Chicago Hard House
Chicago Hard House.description_short: Originated from Chicago around the mid-1990s as a development of [Genre29836], emphasizing hard-hitting, off-beat drum patterns, fast tempos, and lack of melodies.

LA Hard House.name: LA Hard House
LA Hard House.description_short: Distorted, minimalistic TR-909 derived rhythms, basic climaxing structures and heavy reliance on high-pitched synthesizer / hoover sounds.

Chicago House.name: Chicago House
Chicago House.description_short: Umbrella term for a broad variety of [Genre463] that originated from Chicago in the (mostly mid-to-late) 1980s and early 90s.

Deep House.name: Deep House
Deep House.description_short: Emerged in the United States during the mid-1980s, featuring a relaxed tempo and influences from [Genre6], [Genre255], and [Genre235].

Lo-Fi House.name: Lo-Fi House
Lo-Fi House.description_short: Primarily distinguished from earlier styles of outsider house by its stricter reliance on deep house elements, cranky, nocturnal, and nostalgic atmospheres, and a distinct dreamy, lo-fi aesthetic.

Diva House.name: Diva House
Diva House.description_short: Dominant, anthemic female vocals, common use of piano stabs, and energetic, driving four-on-the-floor rhythms.

Hardbag.name: Hardbag
Hardbag.description_short: Development of handbag / [Genre53678] characterized by heavier, hard hitting percussion, more pronounced rave and early [Genre52469] elements, and fewer vocals.

Electro House.name: Electro House
Electro House.description_short: Warm analog basslines, punchy percussion, crisp high-pitched synthesizer leads, and clipped vocal samples.

Complextro.name: Complextro
Complextro.description_short: Features densely-layered sound design, fast-paced cut-up sections, aggressive stabs, and common crossover with [Genre31624] and [Genre26732].

Dutch House.name: Dutch House
Dutch House.description_short: High-pitched wonky synth melodies and heavy influence from [Genre26732] which developed in the Netherlands around 2007-08.

Noiadance.name: Noiadance
Noiadance.description_short: Blends [Genre29430] production with [Genre21335] vocals and drumming on top of [Genre30405] rhythms.

Fidget House.name: Fidget House
Fidget House.description_short: Makes heavy use of [Genre25191]-esque synth stabs, pitch bending of basslines, and cut-up vocal samples, as well as glitchy, or "choppy", 4/4 rhythms.

French Electro.name: French Electro
French Electro.description_short: Mixes [Genre21082] with major elements of genres such as [Genre322], [Genre30075], [Genre26521], and even [Genre20757], resulting in a harsh, punchy, and funky midtempo sound.

Melbourne Bounce.name: Melbourne Bounce
Melbourne Bounce.description_short: Offbeat basslines giving it a "bouncy" groove, and minimalistic, side-chained melodies often making use of [Genre29430]-influenced synths, horns or vocal chops, resulting in a flippant, party-oriented atmosphere.

Eletrofunk.name: Eletrofunk
Eletrofunk.description_short: Blends [Genre21335] vocals with production from popular late 2000s and early 2010s [Genre463].

Euro House.name: Euro House
Euro House.description_short: Vocal-focused style emerging in the late 1980s in Europe, developing in parallel with [Genre421].

Festival Progressive House.name: Festival Progressive House
Festival Progressive House.description_short: Uplifting, melodic, energetic but clean drops, featuring modern supersaws and pianos, taking influences from [Genre10193], [Genre29683], but applying them to a form structurally closer to [Genre35035] and [Genre21082].

French House.name: French House
French House.description_short: Originated in France in the mid-1990s, characterized by the use of filtered (low-pass, phaser, etc.) samples of [Genre255] and [Genre417].

Funky House.name: Funky House
Funky House.description_short: Funky, warm, catchy basslines on top of looped [Genre255] or [Genre417] samples, resulting in an upbeat, bouncy, and pacy groove.

Future Funk.name: Future Funk
Future Funk.description_short: Sample-based form of [Genre463] which formed out of [Genre32584] in the early 2010s.

Future House.name: Future House
Future House.description_short: Features distinctive metallic-sounding drops and frequency-modulated basslines at around 120-130 BPM.

Future Bounce.name: Future Bounce
Future Bounce.description_short: Fusion of [Genre37602] and [Genre37063] that combines the former's basslines and bouncy, upbeat drops with the latter's metallic, pronounced synth leads.

Garage House.name: Garage House
Garage House.description_short: [Genre417]-influenced style of [Genre463] that developed in the 1980s, incorporating elements of [Genre10014], [Genre235], and [Genre150], before evolving into a more upbeat style that prominently features crisp syncopated hi-hats and synth stabs.

Gospel House.name: Gospel House
Gospel House.description_short: Incorporates heavy [Genre10014] elements and singing borrowed from classic and contemporary gospel, usually in the form of choir vocals and call-and-response chants.

Jersey Sound.name: Jersey Sound
Jersey Sound.description_short: Soulful, melodic, [Genre10014]-infused [Genre463] music developed in Newark, NJ in the late 1980s and early 1990s with an emphasis on songcraft.

Ghetto House.name: Ghetto House
Ghetto House.description_short: Rough sound based around minimal drum machine-driven tracks and heavy usage of vocal samples.

Juke.name: Juke
Juke.description_short: Faster than [Genre29836], playing at 160bpm, and makes striking use of unconventional drum patterns which differ wildly from other [Genre463] styles.

G-House.name: G-House
G-House.description_short: Deep, dark form of [Genre463] music that primarily incorporates rap samples or original rapping on top of minimal, bassy beats.

Gqom.name: Gqom
Gqom.description_short: Evolved from South African [Genre463], specifically [Genre20939]; often described as a more minimal and raw version.

Hip House.name: Hip House
Hip House.description_short: Incorporates production elements of early [Genre11] and usually rapping into 1980s [Genre463].

Italo House.name: Italo House
Italo House.description_short: Originated in Italy during the late 1980s, making use of anthemic pianos, diva vocals, and [Genre459] song structures.

Jackin' House.name: Jackin' House
Jackin' House.description_short: Punchy, 'shuffly' percussion, strong grooves, funky basslines, and chopped-up samples.

Kwaito.name: Kwaito
Kwaito.description_short: Emerged from South Africa in the early 1990s, taking influence from [Genre417] and [Genre11].

Bacardi.name: Bacardi
Bacardi.description_short: Bacardi is a type of [Genre463] music from South Africa derived from [Genre20939], delivering upbeat, danceable rhythms with lively snares and hi-hats.

Latin House.name: Latin House
Latin House.description_short: Emerged in the second half of the 1980s, blending four-on-the-floor beats with [Genre519] influences from Puerto Rico, Mexico, Cuba, Dominica, and Colombia.

Melodic House.name: Melodic House
Melodic House.description_short: Arpeggiated synth lines, focus on a chilled and laid-back atmosphere, and influence from genres such as [Genre10193] and [Genre471].

Microhouse.name: Microhouse
Microhouse.description_short: Stripped-down, minimal form of [Genre463], originating in the late 90s, which takes influence from [Genre271], [Genre106] and [Genre90].

Organic House.name: Organic House
Organic House.description_short: Subtle drums and grooves, slow tempos, and acoustic, traditional instrumentation, resulting in an organic, warm sound and spiritual atmosphere.

Outsider House.name: Outsider House
Outsider House.description_short: Mostly derived from [Genre471]; intentional use of rough, lo-fi production, often utilizing a mix of analog/analog-like and digital instrumentation.

Phonk House.name: Phonk House
Phonk House.description_short: Merges [Genre53354]'s nocturnal atmospheres, cowbell melodies, vocal samples, and energetic production, with [genre463] rhythms and tempos, characterized by a banging and upbeat sound.

Progressive House.name: Progressive House
Progressive House.description_short: [Genre93]-influenced strain of [Genre463] that grew to prominence in the early 1990s, using polished production and gradual progressions.

Speed Garage.name: Speed Garage
Speed Garage.description_short: Primarily British style that paved the way for [Genre10477], combining cut-up vocal samples and sped up four-on-the-floor [Genre21221] rhythms with [Genre143]-esque basslines.

Stutter House.name: Stutter House
Stutter House.description_short: Emerged in the 2020s taking influences from [Genre58073], [Genre93], and [Genre29223]; features distinctive chopping of vocal samples and pads.

Tech House.name: Tech House
Tech House.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1990s taking influences from [Genre91], broadly characterized by minimalistic and repetitive melodies, focus on the bassline, and constant groove recognizable by prominent off-beat hi-hats.

Deep Tech.name: Deep Tech
Deep Tech.description_short: Incorporates [Genre10477] rhythms and synths stabs, influences from British rave music, [Genre31237] and UK [Genre471], resulting in an urban, subdued, but danceable sound with deep, muted basslines.

Rominimal.name: Rominimal
Rominimal.description_short: Hypnotic, minimal, and "dubby" loops, featuring subtle and intricate synth pads, cranky, clicky percussion, and bouncy, pulsing basslines.

Tribal House.name: Tribal House
Tribal House.description_short: Prominent, syncopated rhythms of tribal drums such as toms and bongos on top of a [Genre463] beat, usually resulting in a percussive, energetic sound, while ranging in mood.

Guaracha [EDM].name: Guaracha [EDM]
Guaracha [EDM].description_short: Originated in Colombia, featuring "fluttering" trumpets, accordion, and tambora drums.

Tropical House.name: Tropical House
Tropical House.description_short: Offshoot of [Genre471] featuring slow tempos around 100-115 BPM, light percussion and acoustic instrumentation, setting out to create a relaxed, summery, beach-like atmosphere.

UK Jackin'.name: UK Jackin'
UK Jackin'.description_short: Successor to British [Genre21107], characterized by strong basslines, dark atmospheres, and dominant grooves.

Vinahouse.name: Vinahouse
Vinahouse.description_short: Fast-paced [Genre463] popular in Vietnam, remixing Vietnamese melodies.

Hypertechno.name: Hypertechno
Hypertechno.description_short: Emerged in the 2020s by mixing fast tempos, prominent basslines, and hard-hitting drums derived from popular [Genre91] with simplistic, catchy melodies and vocals, often influenced by 2000s [Genre52469], [Genre421] and [Genre402].

Hyper Techno.name: Hyper Techno
Hyper Techno.description_short: Exaggerated fast form of [genre55441] for the Japanese market, focusing mainly on synth sounds and samples typical of 1990s dance music.

Jungle Terror.name: Jungle Terror
Jungle Terror.description_short: Emerging mostly from [Genre29430] and [Genre35035], incorporates [Genre21222]-influenced percussion, hard kicks, and animal sounds resulting in a wild, jungle-resembling atmosphere in a festival EDM-oriented context.

Krushclub.name: Krushclub
Krushclub.description_short: Bitcrushed synths and occasionally bitcrushed vocals, energetic [Genre35601]-derived beats, and elements of [Genre54077]'s dark production style.

Kuduro.name: Kuduro
Kuduro.description_short: Angolan music combining traditional [Genre33420] and [Genre25036] with [Genre91] and [Genre463].

Batida.name: Batida
Batida.description_short: Initially developed in the late '80s in Luanda, Angola, as a mixture of [Genre10305]- and [Genre10506]-based percussion samples.

Makina.name: Makina
Makina.description_short: Spanish [Genre91] developed in the early 1990s; strongly influenced by [Genre10404] and [Genre337], but aiming for a lighter sound.

Manyao.name: Manyao
Manyao.description_short: Asian [Genre31431] that mixes vocals and melodies from [Genre25034] with fairly hard, melodic EDM.

Melodic Bass.name: Melodic Bass
Melodic Bass.description_short: Outgrowth of [Genre42616] with euphoric sound design taking influences from [Genre41388], guitar melodies and pop-driven structures

Midtempo Bass.name: Midtempo Bass
Midtempo Bass.description_short: Harsh synth leads and a usual tempo of around 90-110 BPM.

Moombahcore.name: Moombahcore
Moombahcore.description_short: High-pitched synth leads, gritty percussion, a kick-snare pattern, aggressive bass drops, and around 110 BPM while often paralleling [Genre31770] or [Genre31624].

Moombahton.name: Moombahton
Moombahton.description_short: Offshoot of [Genre29430] characterized by tempos in the 100-110 BPM range, [Genre590]-influenced rhythms, bass-heavy kicks and high-pitched synths.

Nerdcore Techno.name: Nerdcore Techno
Nerdcore Techno.description_short: Stylistically diverse form of underground Japanese [genre31431] utilizing energetic beats built around samples from pop and/or nerd culture.

Ori deck.name: Ori deck
Ori deck.description_short: Incorporates elements of [Genre30405] and [Genre638] to create a style characterized by sluggish, kick-heavy dembow rhythms.

Post-Dubstep.name: Post-Dubstep
Post-Dubstep.description_short: Minimalistic, atmospheric sound design and eclectic drum patterns, derived from but not fitting [Genre638].

Shangaan Electro.name: Shangaan Electro
Shangaan Electro.description_short: South African genre with very fast BPM (around 180) featuring MIDI keyboard sounds and marimba.

Singeli.name: Singeli
Singeli.description_short: Developed in Tanzania in the mid-2000s; fuses incredibly rapid beats, usually between 180-300BPM, with MCing and musical influences from older Tanzanian genres.

Skweee.name: Skweee
Skweee.description_short: Mid-2000s offshoot of the Nordic [Genre319] scene which uses simple, analogue or [Genre10041]-inspired synthesizer leads and basslines to create stripped-down, midtempo grooves drawing on [Genre26521] and [Genre11].

Slimepunk.name: Slimepunk
Slimepunk.description_short: Loud synth leads with a distorted, gritty, and "slimy" sound design, usually laid on top of production inspired by or taken directly from genres such as [Genre42497], [Genre32535], [Genre31624], and other forms of 2010s EDM.

Techno.name: Techno
Techno.description_short: Highly beat-driven, repetitive, and mechanical, typically featuring minimal chord variation and melodies, focuses on rhythms and timbral variety; generally produced for club environments.

Acid Techno.name: Acid Techno
Acid Techno.description_short: Incorporates "squelching" synths from [Genre464] into a mechanical and usually more energetic [Genre91] context.

Ambient Techno.name: Ambient Techno
Ambient Techno.description_short: Blends the mechanical, repetitive beats of [Genre91] with atmospheres and textures inspired by [Genre84] music, resulting in slower tempos and more understated rhythms.

Bleep Techno.name: Bleep Techno
Bleep Techno.description_short: Established in the late 1980s in the breakdancing and early rave scene of Yorkshire in the North of England, notable for its "bleepy" synth lines and heavy sub-bass.

Detroit Techno.name: Detroit Techno
Detroit Techno.description_short: Features a signature mechanical, detached sound that echoed the atmosphere of Detroit's nightlife and incorporated influences from [Genre319], [Genre575], as well as [Genre382] and [Genre320].

Freetekno.name: Freetekno
Freetekno.description_short: Originated in the early 1990s, commonly played at free parties in Europe, and features a repetitive pounding kick drum at tempos of 170 BPM or above.

Hardgroove Techno.name: Hardgroove Techno
Hardgroove Techno.description_short: Features shuffling grooves with heavy emphasis on layered percussive elements; often includes a mix of samples and drum machines played at a range of 135-140 BPM.

Hard Techno.name: Hard Techno
Hard Techno.description_short: Typically rave-oriented form characterized by hard, prominent kick drums, pounding rhythms, fast tempos around 140-160 BPM, and aggressive, often distorted sounds.

Schranz.name: Schranz
Schranz.description_short: Characterised by fast tempos, aggressive "whooshing" beat patterns, heavy compression and straightforward song structures.

Industrial Techno.name: Industrial Techno
Industrial Techno.description_short: Harder, darker style of [Genre91] which draws parallels with factories and the rhythm of machinery.

Birmingham Sound.name: Birmingham Sound
Birmingham Sound.description_short: Cold, mechanical, and hypnotic tracks, typically lacking the harsher and noisier elements of later [Genre33631].

Melodic Techno.name: Melodic Techno
Melodic Techno.description_short: [Genre93]-influenced subgenre that was established in the mid-to-late 2010s, characterized by gradually progressing structure, and hypnotizing, atmospheric sound with arpeggiated, minor melodies, playing at around 120-125 BPM.

Minimal Techno.name: Minimal Techno
Minimal Techno.description_short: Stripped-down and sparse, often featuring a dark sound and a slow, steady development through the track.

Dub Techno.name: Dub Techno
Dub Techno.description_short: Fuses elements of [Genre271] with characteristics of [Genre150].

Peak Time Techno.name: Peak Time Techno
Peak Time Techno.description_short: Hard, dynamic, energetic and accessible subgenre featuring strong kicks, massive dirty synths, tempos around 130 BPM, more suspenseful structures with breaks and build-ups, and big, modern, festival-oriented sound; rose to high popularity in the late 2010s.

Wonky Techno.name: Wonky Techno
Wonky Techno.description_short: Strays from the standard beat of [Genre91], opting for a more fractured sound.

Techno Bass.name: Techno Bass
Techno Bass.description_short: Minimal, stripped-down with an emphasis on low-frequency bass partitions.

Car Audio Bass.name: Car Audio Bass
Car Audio Bass.description_short: Slow and minimalistic extreme form, focused on ultra-low frequency sine wave notes and mainly intended for stress testing subwoofer sound systems.

Trance.name: Trance
Trance.description_short: Evolving, tension-building structures with rapid, minor arpeggios on top of a hypnotic, four-on-the-floor drum patterns at fast tempo around 130-150 BPM.

Acid Trance.name: Acid Trance
Acid Trance.description_short: Incorporates "squelching" acid basslines into [Genre93]'s evolving structure.

Big Room Trance.name: Big Room Trance
Big Room Trance.description_short: Incorporates production features associated with [Genre35035] and dirty, distorted leads influenced by [Genre21082], [Genre29430] and [Genre21072].

Dream Trance.name: Dream Trance
Dream Trance.description_short: Slow tempo (about 130 BPM) with strong roots in [Genre10193], using beats typical of [Genre421] and [Genre459]; emphasizes a laid-back, carefree, and dreamlike sound.

Euro Trance.name: Euro Trance
Euro Trance.description_short: Emerged as a fusion with [Genre421], features fast tempos, more accessible grooves and structures, and simple, catchy melodies with vocals and saw synth leads.

Hands Up.name: Hands Up
Hands Up.description_short: Prominent, melodic supersaw leads, [Genre459] derived hooks, and a strong reliance on sidechained basslines and hard, powerful drums.

Buchiage Trance.name: Buchiage Trance
Buchiage Trance.description_short: Japanese style that emerged in Shibuya's club scene in the 2000s and was primarily marketed to [i]gyaru[/i], infused with melodic and rhythmic influence from [Genre29254].

Hi-Tech Full-On.name: Hi-Tech Full-On
Hi-Tech Full-On.description_short: Largely Japanese genre with an energetic and glitchy sound derived from [Genre31765] and [Genre31770].

Ibiza Trance.name: Ibiza Trance
Ibiza Trance.description_short: Builds on the relaxing island atmosphere of [Genre30224], though with a slightly faster tempo of around 130 BPM.

Progressive Trance.name: Progressive Trance
Progressive Trance.description_short: Combination of [Genre93] and [Genre10193] which emerged in Western Europe in the early to mid-1990s.

Psytrance.name: Psytrance
Psytrance.description_short: Emphasizes a psychedelic feel and an energetic sound; based around influences from [Genre10298] and [Genre28356].

Dark Psytrance.name: Dark Psytrance
Dark Psytrance.description_short: Uses more complex sound design based on dark atmospheres and fast tempos.

Hi-Tech Psytrance.name: Hi-Tech Psytrance
Hi-Tech Psytrance.description_short: Glitchy sound design, morphing synth lines, strange sounds typically evoking futuristic or alien-like atmospheres, and faster tempos than most other forms of [Genre10122].

Psycore.name: Psycore
Psycore.description_short: Pushes the dark atmospheres of [Genre10296] to the extreme through the usage of exceptionally high tempos and experimental soundscapes influenced by [Genre245] and [Genre106].

Forest Psytrance.name: Forest Psytrance
Forest Psytrance.description_short: Mimicks the ambience of a forest by using swarming and teeming effects as well as natural samples; features straightforward song structures.

Full-On Psytrance.name: Full-On Psytrance
Full-On Psytrance.description_short: Faster and more intense, usually set around 145-150 BPM and featuring harder rolling basslines, vocal samples and "spacey" effects.

Goa Trance.name: Goa Trance
Goa Trance.description_short: Forerunner of [Genre10122] styles that emerged in the early 1990s, distinguished by old-school, organic sound with rapid, oriental-inspired melodies.

Nitzhonot.name: Nitzhonot
Nitzhonot.description_short: Fast-paced, featuring rapid melodic lines and usually hard and high-pitched kicks.

Progressive Psytrance.name: Progressive Psytrance
Progressive Psytrance.description_short: Emerged in the early 2000s, featuring a slow tempo range and clean production.

Zenonesque.name: Zenonesque
Zenonesque.description_short: Experimental and leftfield approach to [Genre10297], mixing the atmospheric and clean [Genre10122] production typical of it with funky and jazzy elements.

Suomisaundi.name: Suomisaundi
Suomisaundi.description_short: Finnish-based deviation of [Genre10122] with an emphasis on free-form experimentation and humor.

Tech Trance.name: Tech Trance
Tech Trance.description_short: Late 1990s-emerging subgenre characterized by energetic percussion with loud kicks, filtered hi-hats and tribal drums; side-chained, detuned and repetitive leads, as well as other raw, distorted, and complex sounds influenced by [Genre91], [Genre27342] and [Genre21082].

Uplifting Trance.name: Uplifting Trance
Uplifting Trance.description_short: Euphoric melodies, buildup-breakdown-anthem structures, common usage of supersaws, and a BPM range of usually around 135-142.

Vocal Trance.name: Vocal Trance
Vocal Trance.description_short: Melodic, polished, [Genre36]-like, and vocal-focused with around 120-145 BPM and frequent overlap with [Genre30871], [Genre29683], and [Genre30890].

Trap [EDM].name: Trap [EDM]
Trap [EDM].description_short: [Genre31066]-influenced syncopated percussion with 808 samples and fast-paced hi-hats.

Festival Trap.name: Festival Trap
Festival Trap.description_short: Massive, sub-bass-heavy drops with simple melodies, synth leads and production influenced by [Genre35035]; highly popular from 2013 to 2015.

Hard Trap.name: Hard Trap
Hard Trap.description_short: Often abrasive subgenre of [Genre32535] with heavy influence from [Genre21072].

Heaven Trap.name: Heaven Trap
Heaven Trap.description_short: Blends [Genre32535]’s signature percussion and sub-basses with euphoric, uplifting, melodious drops prominently derived from [Genre47128], contrary to the gritty, "dirty" nature of other EDM trap styles.

Hybrid Trap.name: Hybrid Trap
Hybrid Trap.description_short: Blending [Genre32535]'s typical percussion and sub-basses with major influences from heavy bass music genres, and in particular, metallic, gritty, and off-kilter sound design, originally derived from [Genre31624].

Tribal Guarachero.name: Tribal Guarachero
Tribal Guarachero.description_short: Features percussion from [genre10047] and [genre31874] with upbeat [genre21082]-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.

UK Bass.name: UK Bass
UK Bass.description_short: Prominent bass/sub-basses, a deep, dark, airy, and mechanical sound derived from [Genre638], and eclectic production influenced by [Genre21106], [Genre29839]/[Genre30431], [Genre91], and [Genre85].

UK Funky.name: UK Funky
UK Funky.description_short: Influenced by [Genre10477]-related styles and the regional styles of British immigrants, including [Genre10305] and West African-inspired [Genre21222].

UK Garage.name: UK Garage
UK Garage.description_short: Shuffling rhythms and influences from sources including [Genre244] and [Genre11], as well as many forms of [Genre82].

2-Step.name: 2-Step
2-Step.description_short: Originating in London and popular in the late 1990s; jittery, shuffling rhythms rarely following a four-on-the-floor pattern.

Breakstep.name: Breakstep
Breakstep.description_short: Hard-hitting [Genre85] rhythms and heavy, rolling basslines.

Future Garage.name: Future Garage
Future Garage.description_short: Combines the rhythms of late 1990s and early 2000s [Genre21098] with novel moods and production approaches, commonly featuring jittery, broken rhythms, vocal chops, and warm synth pads and plucks.

Wonky.name: Wonky
Wonky.description_short: Off-kilter fusion of [Genre638] and [Genre11] which first developed in the mid-to-late 2000s.

Aquacrunk.name: Aquacrunk
Aquacrunk.description_short: Syncopated, half-time rhythms inspired by [Genre638] and [Genre26], funky, sludgy, "aquatic"-sounding synths and sound design.

Miami Bass.name: Miami Bass
Miami Bass.description_short: Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct [Genre319] influence.

Atlanta Bass.name: Atlanta Bass
Atlanta Bass.description_short: Originated in Atlanta, slower tempos and a more melodic approach than [Genre326].

Tamborzão.name: Tamborzão
Tamborzão.description_short: Adds Afro-Brazilian percussive elements such as the [i]atabaque[/i] sound into the [Genre326] kick drums.

Wa Euro.name: Wa Euro
Wa Euro.description_short: Traditional form of J-Pop that emerged in the second half of the 1980s from late [Genre592], '80s British [Genre459] and [Genre321]/[Genre29254].

Easy Listening.name: Easy Listening
Easy Listening.description_short: Typically instrumental, including lush arrangements and melodies played by orchestras or big bands aiming for light entertainment.

Cocktail Nation.name: Cocktail Nation
Cocktail Nation.description_short: Decidedly ironic take on [Genre355] that emerged in the early 1990s.

Exotica.name: Exotica
Exotica.description_short: Emerged in the early 1950s as the United States developed a fascination with Polynesia and the South Pacific, incorporates traditional instruments and rhythms from these cultures into a Western [Genre36] context.

Sitarsploitation.name: Sitarsploitation
Sitarsploitation.description_short: Variant of [Genre10203] capitalising on the surge of Western interest in Indian music in the late 1960s; featured melodies played on the sitar (or instruments imitating it) atop [Genre353] accompaniment.

Lounge.name: Lounge
Lounge.description_short: Emerged in the United States during the 1950s, emphasizing a chilled-out atmosphere with light instrumentation and sometimes vocals indebted to [Genre227].

Pops Orchestra.name: Pops Orchestra
Pops Orchestra.description_short: Orchestra that plays covers of popular songs as well as famous classical compositions.

Space Age Pop.name: Space Age Pop
Space Age Pop.description_short: Inspired by the excitement and optimism of the Space Age during the 1950s and 1960s, frequently experimenting with futuristic sounds made possible by contemporary technology.

Electronic.name: Electronic
Electronic.description_short: Uses non-traditional electronic instrumentation and sound manipulation technology as the primary backbone of a composition.

Acholitronix.name: Acholitronix
Acholitronix.description_short: Fusion of traditional Acholi rhythms and melodies with [genre82] production, originating in the city of Gulu.

Algorave.name: Algorave
Algorave.description_short: Generative dancefloor-oriented music produced live via algorithms.

Binaural Beats.name: Binaural Beats
Binaural Beats.description_short: Auditory illusions created when two different frequencies are played simultaneously in separate ears.

Bit Music.name: Bit Music
Bit Music.description_short: Created by sound chips, cards, and sequencers found in video game consoles, personal computers, and arcade machines, as well as synthesizers emulating these sounds.

Chiptune.name: Chiptune
Chiptune.description_short: Used primarily in the 1980s within the context of 8-bit [Genre475], combining simple synthesized waveforms and noise in a compositionally limited but overtly melodic style.

FM Synthesis.name: FM Synthesis
FM Synthesis.description_short: Sound synthesis that combines the simple waveforms of [Genre10041] with modulating oscillators to create a bouncier synthesizer sound that would be used in arcade cabinets and home video game consoles like the [GamePlatform91] in the late 1980s.

MIDI Music.name: MIDI Music
MIDI Music.description_short: Intended for real-time sequenced playback via MIDI protocol on MIDI devices and used primarily in 1990s PC [Genre475], arranger keyboards and karaoke.

Black MIDI.name: Black MIDI
Black MIDI.description_short: Consists of extremely dense MIDI piano compositions, impossible to play on physical instruments.

Sequencer & Tracker.name: Sequencer & Tracker
Sequencer & Tracker.description_short: Composed for early home computer and game consoles from the late 1980s to the late 1990s, primarily for video game soundtracks.

16-bit.name: 16-bit
16-bit.description_short: Created using video game consoles with audio hardware using 16-bit audio samples, most notably the [GamePlatform102].

Tracker Music.name: Tracker Music
Tracker Music.description_short: Vertical text-based step-sequencer software sampler music in the first and second gen module formats like .MOD, .MED, .S3M, .XM and .IT.

Demostyle.name: Demostyle
Demostyle.description_short: Traditional eclectic style of the [Genre61973] with a special emphasis on tracker techniques and samples, and combining numerous elements of completely different genres - from [Genre321], [Genre10035] and [Genre255] to [Genre55441], [Genre84] and [Genre86].

Bitpop.name: Bitpop
Bitpop.description_short: Fuses [Genre33179] with additional synths, beats, guitars and modern production values, emphasizing highly catchy melodies and relatively fast tempos.

Celtic Electronica.name: Celtic Electronica
Celtic Electronica.description_short: Fusion of [Genre642] with various types of [Genre31431].

Chillout.name: Chillout
Chillout.description_short: Broad category of many relaxed styles of [Genre82] music which predominantly draw influence from [Genre31431] subgenres and [Genre84].

Ambient Dub.name: Ambient Dub
Ambient Dub.description_short: Takes cues from [Genre84] and [Genre150] reggae, featuring the atmosphere of the former and the Jamaican-style basslines, percussion, and psychedelic production techniques of the latter.

Ambient Trance.name: Ambient Trance
Ambient Trance.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1990s mainly in the form of [Genre56645] remixes of [Genre93] tracks; incorporates its arpeggiated synthesizer sound into [Genre10013] and [Genre84] contexts.

Barber Beats.name: Barber Beats
Barber Beats.description_short: Borrows elements from [Genre10013], [Genre632], and [Genre17]; emulates 1990s and 2000s [Genre56645] music.

Downtempo.name: Downtempo
Downtempo.description_short: Atmospheric and groove-based with relaxed tempos and mellow beats.

Trip Hop.name: Trip Hop
Trip Hop.description_short: Evokes a surreal, trippy, dreamy, and sometimes dark atmosphere with offbeat turntable scratches, light vocal melodies, and [Genre11]-influenced beats.

Psybient.name: Psybient
Psybient.description_short: Heavy influence from [genre10122] and [genre10298] incorporated in an atmospheric [genre84] context.

Digital Fusion.name: Digital Fusion
Digital Fusion.description_short: Incorporates the hardware-limited sounds of [Genre10041] and other [Genre33179] into compositions drawing on [Genre6], [Genre42898], progressive music, and other [Genre82] styles, sometimes augmented with live instrumentation.

Drift Phonk.name: Drift Phonk
Drift Phonk.description_short: Busy, noisy production inspired by lo-fi [Genre20720]; frequently features 808 cowbell melodies and chopped, compressed samples.

Dungeon Synth.name: Dungeon Synth
Dungeon Synth.description_short: Focuses on evoking epic and atmospheric soundscapes primarily associated with fantasy and medieval settings through the usage of synthesizers, keyboards, lo-fi production, and drum machines.

Comfy Synth.name: Comfy Synth
Comfy Synth.description_short: Calm, peaceful and soothing sounds, as well as nostalgic, sentimental, or childish atmospheres and aesthetics; often incorporates wholesome themes while utilizing lo-fi or hazy recordings and influences from [genre543].

Winter Synth.name: Winter Synth
Winter Synth.description_short: Cold, minimalistic, and repetitive soundscapes, commonly invoking imagery of winter.

Electroacoustic.name: Electroacoustic
Electroacoustic.description_short: Manipulation and processing of sound sources to create atmospheric pieces.

Acousmatic Music.name: Acousmatic Music
Acousmatic Music.description_short: Fixed-media [Genre10150] music designed to be reproduced by multiple loudspeakers without the presence of instrumentalists and visual cues.

EAI.name: EAI
EAI.description_short: Slow paced, physical, textured aesthetic - often created using unconventional instruments processed through a computer.

Musique concrète.name: Musique concrète
Musique concrète.description_short: Manipulation of recorded sounds, mostly [Genre293], natural sounds, and real-world noises, as a process of abstracting "concrete" sounds, or "sound objects", from their acoustic origins.

Electro Hop.name: Electro Hop
Electro Hop.description_short: Emerged in the mid 2000s featuring upbeat rap verses and catchy hooks over four-on-the-floor [Genre402] and  [Genre21082]-inspired production.

Electro-Industrial.name: Electro-Industrial
Electro-Industrial.description_short: Formed in the late 1980s and early 1990s; grew out of a combination of [Genre337] and [Genre336].

Electropop.name: Electropop
Electropop.description_short: Dense, layered, and compressed production, usually coupled with a distinct fuzzy and "warm" low-frequency synthesizer style.

Epic Collage.name: Epic Collage
Epic Collage.description_short: Cinematic, dense digital collage; frequently utilizes a [Genre41411] sonic palette and decontextualized novel samples.

Flashcore.name: Flashcore
Flashcore.description_short: Fast-paced short sounds, complex structures with erratic progression, and often dense and atmospheric abstract sound design, featuring recontextualized elements from [Genre90], [Genre273], [Genre43410], and [Genre10152].

Folktronica.name: Folktronica
Folktronica.description_short: Combines sound design techniques from [Genre90] and [Genre106] with acoustic instrumentation inspired by [Genre209].

Funktronica.name: Funktronica
Funktronica.description_short: Originated in eastern North America around the turn of the 21st century, combining trends of [Genre26521] and [Genre321].

Glitch.name: Glitch
Glitch.description_short: Uses abstract sound design and malfunctioning electronics—CD skips, data corruption, and hardware noise—as main compositional elements.

Glitch Hop.name: Glitch Hop
Glitch Hop.description_short: Incorporation of [Genre90]-derived production into drum patterns inspired by [Genre11] beats.

Graphical Sound.name: Graphical Sound
Graphical Sound.description_short: Compositional technique in which markings are manually applied to a medium, then processed by a machine to produce synthetic sound from the markings in real time.

HexD.name: HexD
HexD.description_short: Heavily bit-crushed vocals, sometimes sped-up and pitched-up, and highly compressed and distorted production, typically made from existing material of other genres.

Horror Synth.name: Horror Synth
Horror Synth.description_short: Combines eerie and haunting synth pads and sharp, abrasive sounds to create atmospheres that accentuated the dark, unnerving, violent, or ghostly themes of horror films.

Hyperpop.name: Hyperpop
Hyperpop.description_short: Developed and took inspiration from [Genre36055] and popular 2000s-2010s [Genre402], characterized by eclectic, unconventional, mechanical-sounding and dense production; and by manipulated, usually auto-tuned vocals.

IDM.name: IDM
IDM.description_short: Emerged through the development of [genre31431] idioms into a less club-oriented and more experimental direction, often incorporating unconventional sound design and complex rhythms.

Drill and Bass.name: Drill and Bass
Drill and Bass.description_short: Frenzied, intricate beat programming inspired by [Genre86].

Illbient.name: Illbient
Illbient.description_short: Combines [Genre84] soundscapes with [Genre11] drum patterns, breaks, and samples through the busy effect layering of [Genre150].

Indietronica.name: Indietronica
Indietronica.description_short: Leftfield or DIY approach characterised by simpler [Genre36]-informed melodies, often incorporating vocals or live instrumentation alongside [Genre82] production.

Chillwave.name: Chillwave
Chillwave.description_short: Emulates vintage aesthetics and popular musical styles of the 1980s/1990s altered by modern recording technology to create a hazy dreamlike atmosphere.

Chillsynth.name: Chillsynth
Chillsynth.description_short: Mixes [Genre34144] with major [Genre27390] elements, characterized by a dreamy and relaxed sound.

Glitch Pop.name: Glitch Pop
Glitch Pop.description_short: Incorporates elements of more experimental [Genre82] styles like [Genre90] and [Genre106].

Picopop.name: Picopop
Picopop.description_short: Originated in the early 2000s as an offshoot of the Japanese [Genre21220] movement when artists introduced more prominent "bleepy" electronic elements and faster tempos.

Latin Electronic.name: Latin Electronic
Latin Electronic.description_short: Combines [Genre82] with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.

Electrotango.name: Electrotango
Electrotango.description_short: Combines [Genre10071] rhythms and melodies with [Genre82] music.

Nortec.name: Nortec
Nortec.description_short: Samples and synthesizes Mexican styles like [Genre527] and [Genre28467] into a sound related to [Genre90] and [Genre463].

Livetronica.name: Livetronica
Livetronica.description_short: Incorporates [Genre82] instrumentation into live [Genre5] jamming, drawing on a wide variety of [Genre31431] and [Genre10013] styles.

Maloya électronique.name: Maloya électronique
Maloya électronique.description_short: Combines the 6/8 ternary rhythm with [Genre82] production, using computer music, synthesizers and drum machines.

Micromontage.name: Micromontage
Micromontage.description_short: Arrangement of microsounds on an incredibly small time scale.

Minimal Wave.name: Minimal Wave
Minimal Wave.description_short: Retrospective term for more [Genre82] and minimal forms of [Genre129], [Genre332], [Genre382], and related styles, tending towards a more sparse and lo-fi sound.

Minimal Synth.name: Minimal Synth
Minimal Synth.description_short: Minimal and distinctly DIY take on [Genre382] with a bleak and naive aesthetic.

Moogsploitation.name: Moogsploitation
Moogsploitation.description_short: Moog synthesizer-led music often associated with a wave of [genre426] records in the 1960s and 1970s.

Nightcore.name: Nightcore
Nightcore.description_short: Based around the technique of speeding and pitching up already existing songs.

Nu Jazz.name: Nu Jazz
Nu Jazz.description_short: [Genre82] styles which feature aesthetics and occasionally instrumentation inspired by [Genre6].

Power Electronics.name: Power Electronics
Power Electronics.description_short: Waves of feedback, screeching analog synthesizers, and harsh, screamed vocals.

Death Industrial.name: Death Industrial
Death Industrial.description_short: Combines the abrasive textures of [Genre342] and [Genre336] music with dark, brooding drones and atmospheres.

Power Noise.name: Power Noise
Power Noise.description_short: Combines looped samples of [Genre342] with [Genre82] rhythms.

Progressive Electronic.name: Progressive Electronic
Progressive Electronic.description_short: Synthesizer-driven genre focusing on developing, often longform compositions and drawing inspiration from various sources such as [Genre97], [Genre183], and [Genre84].

Berlin School.name: Berlin School
Berlin School.description_short: Atmospheric, multi-layered synthesizer textures; pioneered in Berlin in the 1970s as an offshoot to the [Genre58] movement.

Synthpop.name: Synthpop
Synthpop.description_short: Led by melodic synthesizer sounds, often with reverberating drum machine patterns; commonly associated with the 1980s.

Pon-chak disco.name: Pon-chak disco
Pon-chak disco.description_short: Heavily influenced by [Genre320], featuring cheap "electronic organ" synth leads and minimalistic, repetitive rhythms.

Techno kayō.name: Techno kayō
Techno kayō.description_short: Offshoot of 1980s [Genre28512] and [Genre46939] incorporating characteristics from [Genre382].

Synth Punk.name: Synth Punk
Synth Punk.description_short: Appropriates the harsh elements of [Genre160] but replaces the predominance of guitars with synthesizers and drum machines.

Synthwave.name: Synthwave
Synthwave.description_short: Rooted in 1980s synth music, characterized by large, throbbing "retro" synths and visual elements, often features upbeat percussion and/or epic, cinematic atmospheres.

Darksynth.name: Darksynth
Darksynth.description_short: Incorporates atmospheric [Genre35511] and faster tempos into a much heavier and darker sound.

Sovietwave.name: Sovietwave
Sovietwave.description_short: Scene of [genre34144] that emerged in the early 2010s, taking its inspiration from Soviet [genre82] electronic music and Soviet pop.

Tecnobrega.name: Tecnobrega
Tecnobrega.description_short: Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from [Genre51022], particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.

Tecnofunk.name: Tecnofunk
Tecnofunk.description_short: Raw and vulgar [genre27665] and [genre21335] fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

Vapor.name: Vapor
Vapor.description_short: Meta-genre beginning with the rise of [Genre32584] and the aesthetics that it spawned.

Dreampunk.name: Dreampunk
Dreampunk.description_short: Accentuates ambiance and a dreamy, futuristic atmosphere, taking influence from [Genre10035], as well as [Genre20125] and [Genre21036] movies.

Utopian Virtual.name: Utopian Virtual
Utopian Virtual.description_short: Emulates late 20th century futuristic and corporate aesthetics, often using "tacky"-sounding instruments likened to [Genre55926], in contrast to [Genre32584]'s sample-based approach.

Vapornoise.name: Vapornoise
Vapornoise.description_short: Uses [Genre342] and other avant-garde techniques not typically found in [Genre32584].

Vaportrap.name: Vaportrap
Vaportrap.description_short: Incorporates a blend of [Genre31066] percussion set to the re-utilization of old samples, such as 1990s pop culture or old computer library sounds.

Vaporwave.name: Vaporwave
Vaporwave.description_short: Sample-based, involves heavily synthesized and processed manipulation of corporate mood and background (elevator) music; though source material can also include genres such as [Genre36], [Genre244], and [Genre26521].

Broken Transmission.name: Broken Transmission
Broken Transmission.description_short: Manipulates samples from TV broadcasts, advertisements, film, radio, and other sources.

Eccojams.name: Eccojams
Eccojams.description_short: Simple, prototypical [Genre32584] style, heavily influenced by [Genre533] and [Genre106], that features short, slowed-down, lyric focused, sampled loops smothered in reverb and continuously repeated, usually taken from late 20th century music.

Mallsoft.name: Mallsoft
Mallsoft.description_short: Blends the main characteristics of [Genre32584] with what can be described as background/elevator music.

Slushwave.name: Slushwave
Slushwave.description_short: Utilizes a distinct form of sample manipulation to create a “slushy” sound, usually sequenced in soft [genre84]-based soundscapes.

Wave.name: Wave
Wave.description_short: Melancholic, atmospheric, melodic beats, defined by its [Genre31066] and [Genre31219] influence, ethereal and cold production style, and abundant use of sub bass.

Witch House.name: Witch House
Witch House.description_short: Nocturnal, occult-themed/horror-inspired, and murky beats with altered, slowed down and heavily processed samples laid on top of slow [Genre11]-derived drum rhythms and droning, dense synthesizers.

Experimental.name: Experimental
Experimental.description_short: Most radical approaches throughout history, featuring non-traditional production methods resulting in sounds and styles that go largely beyond traditional boundaries.

Conducted Improvisation.name: Conducted Improvisation
Conducted Improvisation.description_short: Collective improvisation directed by a conductor.

Data Sonification.name: Data Sonification
Data Sonification.description_short: Usage of data to create sound, soundscapes and music mostly as a way to illustrate its information.

Drone.name: Drone
Drone.description_short: Focuses on long, sustained tones and tone clusters, or repetition of single notes.

Free Improvisation.name: Free Improvisation
Free Improvisation.description_short: Improvised music which, in descending from [Genre468] and classical [Genre10038], further abandons the prescriptions of harmonic or rhythmic structures which characterized those genres.

Industrial.name: Industrial
Industrial.description_short: Emerged out of [Genre38713] and avant-garde art movements in the mid-1970s, often characterized by a bleak, mechanical atmosphere, the use of metallic percussion as well as other unconventional instruments, and extensive use of sampling influenced by [Genre10084].

Modern Creative.name: Modern Creative
Modern Creative.description_short: Style of semi-improvisation that derives heavily from both the composition of [Genre201] and the techniques of [Genre68].

Noise.name: Noise
Noise.description_short: Strays away from conventional structure, tonality, and composition and consists predominantly of noise.

Ambient Noise Wall.name: Ambient Noise Wall
Ambient Noise Wall.description_short: Combines the static approach of [Genre32334] with textures leaning towards [Genre84] music.

Black Noise.name: Black Noise
Black Noise.description_short: Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant [genre342] and [genre189] elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

Gorenoise.name: Gorenoise
Gorenoise.description_short: Combines and subverts [Genre485] and [Genre482] with brash [Genre342] and even faster drum tempos.

Harsh Noise.name: Harsh Noise
Harsh Noise.description_short: Highly aggressive walls of sound that assault the listener.

Harsh Noise Wall.name: Harsh Noise Wall
Harsh Noise Wall.description_short: Harsh, distorted walls of sound that feature few dynamic variations and often take the form of long compositions with little to no change or progression over time.

Plunderphonics.name: Plunderphonics
Plunderphonics.description_short: Compositional technique of utilizing and manipulating one or more recognizable recordings to create a new composition.

Reductionism.name: Reductionism
Reductionism.description_short: Experimental music that centers around quiet dynamics and use of silence.

Lowercase.name: Lowercase
Lowercase.description_short: Centered around the digital amplification and processing of quiet sounds.

Onkyo.name: Onkyo
Onkyo.description_short: Exploration of the physical traits of sound rather than music as expression.

Sound Art.name: Sound Art
Sound Art.description_short: Incorporates elements from [Genre584] music and visual arts, with sound utilized as its primary medium and subject.

Sound Collage.name: Sound Collage
Sound Collage.description_short: Compositional method emphasizing the rough layering of sampled elements, presenting an impression similar to a visual collage.

Sound Poetry.name: Sound Poetry
Sound Poetry.description_short: Emphasis is placed upon phonetics and the sounds of syllables rather than the meaning of the words themselves.

Tape Music.name: Tape Music
Tape Music.description_short: Explores the nature of audio recorded to magnetic tape and the act of playing sound from it.

Turntable Music.name: Turntable Music
Turntable Music.description_short: Has its roots in the early half of the twentieth century, with experimental artists using the turntable (as well as the vinyl records it plays) as a distinct instrument in the creation of compositions.

Folk.name: Folk
Folk.description_short: Rooted in mostly oral traditions of the peoples of the world, encompassing international [Genre10448] as well as Western [Genre209] which arose in the 1940s.

Contemporary Folk.name: Contemporary Folk
Contemporary Folk.description_short: Generally acoustic and rooted in modernized [Genre10448], originated with the 20th century American folk revival.

American Primitivism.name: American Primitivism
American Primitivism.description_short: Blends avant-garde and neo-classical compositions with traditional [Genre133] fingerpicking techniques.

Anti-Folk.name: Anti-Folk
Anti-Folk.description_short: Rawer approach to folk, with an often self-mocking and sarcastic tone.

Avant-Folk.name: Avant-Folk
Avant-Folk.description_short: [Genre584]-influenced and playing with instrumentation, rhythm, and other factors not commonly found in folk.

Free Folk.name: Free Folk
Free Folk.description_short: Incorporates improvisation, repetition and extended song lengths.

Campus Folk.name: Campus Folk
Campus Folk.description_short: Born in Taiwan in the mid-1970s, this movement originated with university students creating their own modern-style songs in the wake of international tensions like Taiwan's isolation from the United Nations and the United States' embrace of the PRC as a diplomatic partner.

Chamber Folk.name: Chamber Folk
Chamber Folk.description_short: Gentle fingerpicked acoustic guitar or harp-led music that commonly includes a backing ensemble of harpsichords, strings, horns, or other orchestral instruments.

Folk Baroque.name: Folk Baroque
Folk Baroque.description_short: Originated in England in the early 1960s, featuring a distinctive guitar fingerpicking style of the same name and the DADGAD guitar tuning.

Folk Pop.name: Folk Pop
Folk Pop.description_short: Blends [Genre209] with a [Genre36] sensibility, most popular in the late 1960s and early 1970s and featuring influence from the contemporary [Genre66] style.

Stomp and Holler.name: Stomp and Holler
Stomp and Holler.description_short: Highlights driving "stomping" rhythms and shouted group vocal harmonies, often drawing influences from [Genre630], [genre25388], and other genres, while maintaining a characteristically mellow and commercial sound.

Indie Folk.name: Indie Folk
Indie Folk.description_short: Combines the melodic sensibilities and production style of [Genre103] and [Genre390] with acoustic instrumentation and influences from [Genre26677], [Genre558], and sometimes [Genre166].

Loner Folk.name: Loner Folk
Loner Folk.description_short: Lo-fi, downbeat, and frequently depressive atmosphere with psychedelic undertones that emerged among independent creators following the collapse of the counterculture in the 1970s.

Neofolk.name: Neofolk
Neofolk.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1980s from the [Genre38714] scene, with a dark, often martial atmosphere.

Dark Folk.name: Dark Folk
Dark Folk.description_short: Minimalistic and melancholic sound with influence from [Genre10117] and even [Genre84].

Neofolklore.name: Neofolklore
Neofolklore.description_short: Short-lived movement that reincorporated traditional Chilean folklore into modern production and styling inspired by foreign musicians.

Progressive Folk.name: Progressive Folk
Progressive Folk.description_short: Draws from a variety of sources to subvert traditional acoustic song forms, with diversity ranging from [Genre6] to Medieval music to various [Genre32988] traditions.

Psychedelic Folk.name: Psychedelic Folk
Psychedelic Folk.description_short: Acoustic forms that capture an atmosphere that is at turns dream-like, 'spaced-out', whimsical, haunting, mystical, and melancholic.

Freak Folk.name: Freak Folk
Freak Folk.description_short: Offshoot of the [Genre60972] movement characterised by acoustic and eclectic instruments, peculiar vocal styles, romantic lyrics, and a childlike atmosphere.

Udigrudi.name: Udigrudi
Udigrudi.description_short: Movement that emerged in the Brazilian city of Recife during the 1970s that combines psychedelic elements with music of Northeastern Brazil.

Wyrd Folk.name: Wyrd Folk
Wyrd Folk.description_short: Closely tied to mysticism, old folk beliefs, and [Genre41199]; often described as 'witchy' or 'pagan.'

Skiffle.name: Skiffle
Skiffle.description_short: Grew out of British [Genre623] trad jazz, drawing influence from 1920s [Genre10343]s and the strong rhythms of 1950s [Genre169] and [Genre55].

Xinyao.name: Xinyao
Xinyao.description_short: Singaporean Mandarin-language style, generally featuring harmonised group vocals and backed mainly by acoustic guitar.

Traditional Folk Music.name: Traditional Folk Music
Traditional Folk Music.description_short: Informed by a long history of tradition in a specific culture or region, mostly associated with the peasantry and non-aristocratic public.

African Folk Music.name: African Folk Music
African Folk Music.description_short: Indigenous music of Africa that is passed down orally from generation to generation, the authors of the songs are usually unknown.

Ambasse bey.name: Ambasse bey
Ambasse bey.description_short: [Genre10517] developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.

Apala.name: Apala
Apala.description_short: [Genre35745] developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.

Batuque.name: Batuque
Batuque.description_short: Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.

Dagomba Music.name: Dagomba Music
Dagomba Music.description_short: Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.

Gnawa.name: Gnawa
Gnawa.description_short: Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and [Genre26710], created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.

Kabye Folk Music.name: Kabye Folk Music
Kabye Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.

Kilapanga.name: Kilapanga
Kilapanga.description_short: Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as [Genre21264].

Malagasy Folk Music.name: Malagasy Folk Music
Malagasy Folk Music.description_short: Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the [Genre26458] of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.

Mbenga-Mbuti Music.name: Mbenga-Mbuti Music
Mbenga-Mbuti Music.description_short: Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.

Moutya.name: Moutya
Moutya.description_short: Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.

Ngoma.name: Ngoma
Ngoma.description_short: Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.

Unyago.name: Unyago
Unyago.description_short: Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.

Afrikaner Folk Music.name: Afrikaner Folk Music
Afrikaner Folk Music.description_short: Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.

Khoisan Folk Music.name: Khoisan Folk Music
Khoisan Folk Music.description_short: Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.

Nguni Folk Music.name: Nguni Folk Music
Nguni Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.

Sotho-Tswana Folk Music.name: Sotho-Tswana Folk Music
Sotho-Tswana Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.

Tchinkoumé.name: Tchinkoumé
Tchinkoumé.description_short: Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.

Traditional Maloya.name: Traditional Maloya
Traditional Maloya.description_short: Derived from [Genre31962], this is the original dance music of La Réunion.

Traditional Séga.name: Traditional Séga
Traditional Séga.description_short: [Genre21700] dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.

Zinli.name: Zinli
Zinli.description_short: Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.

American Folk Music.name: American Folk Music
American Folk Music.description_short: Traces back through the history of European and West African settlement and migration to North America, including parts of northern Mexico and Canada in addition to the United States.

Appalachian Folk Music.name: Appalachian Folk Music
Appalachian Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Appalachian Mountains in the Eastern United States.

Old-Time.name: Old-Time
Old-Time.description_short: Pre-[Genre172] North American string band styles, particularly those rooted in [Genre36859].

Field Hollers.name: Field Hollers
Field Hollers.description_short: Created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, featuring expressive vocals to no strict rhythm.

Ring Shout.name: Ring Shout
Ring Shout.description_short: Ritual practiced by African-Americans in the US South, characterized by shouting, chanting and people dancing in a circle while praying and clapping.

Sacred Harp Singing.name: Sacred Harp Singing
Sacred Harp Singing.description_short: Predominantly 19th-century English hymns with tunes derived from old folk melodies.

Spirituals.name: Spirituals
Spirituals.description_short: Predecessor to [Genre10014] that began as unaccompanied singing by American slaves; shares some of the characteristics of [Genre294].

Talking Blues.name: Talking Blues
Talking Blues.description_short: [Genre31697] with spoken or nearly spoken vocals; often features dry humor and social commentary.

Traditional Black Gospel.name: Traditional Black Gospel
Traditional Black Gospel.description_short: Born out of [Genre10015] in the early 20th century with influence from [Genre10275] and [Genre131], often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.

Traditional Cajun Music.name: Traditional Cajun Music
Traditional Cajun Music.description_short: Earliest and most "pure" form of [Genre10478], employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.

Aita.name: Aita
Aita.description_short: [Genre30752] from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.

Raqs baladi.name: Raqs baladi
Raqs baladi.description_short: Egyptian folk dance and its associated musical accompaniment, appearing in the 20th century.

Ayyalah.name: Ayyalah
Ayyalah.description_short: Traditional Khaliji-Bedouin weapon performance, commonly found across the United Arab Emirates and Northwestern Oman.

Fijiri.name: Fijiri
Fijiri.description_short: Deeply rooted in the Persian Gulf pearl diving culture, and sung during weekly gatherings combining solo and choral sections with minimal percussion.

Liwa.name: Liwa
Liwa.description_short: Traditional Khaliji performance with [Genre39268] roots centered around the mizmar and traditional drums, typically sung in Khaliji Arabic and Swahili.

Nuban.name: Nuban
Nuban.description_short: Traditional Afro-Emirati [Genre26677] performance of Nuban origin most commonly performed in the emirate of Dubai.

Sa'idi.name: Sa'idi
Sa'idi.description_short: Traditional folkloric performance and form of [Genre30752] originating from Upper Egypt.

Australian Folk Music.name: Australian Folk Music
Australian Folk Music.description_short: Folk traditions of the European colonists and convicts in Australia.

Bayawan.name: Bayawan
Bayawan.description_short: Distinct muqam tradition of the Dolan subgroup of the Uyghur people, often considered the wildest of the regional muqam variations.

Brazilian Folk Music.name: Brazilian Folk Music
Brazilian Folk Music.description_short: Comprises the various traditions of folk music found in Brazil, often resulting from the interplay of Indigenous, African and European music.

Aboio.name: Aboio
Aboio.description_short: Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.

Banda de pífano.name: Banda de pífano
Banda de pífano.description_short: Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion.

Candomblé Music.name: Candomblé Music
Candomblé Music.description_short: Music of the Afro-Brazilian Candomblé religion that influenced the secular [Genre28322].

Cantoria.name: Cantoria
Cantoria.description_short: Sung poetry of itinerant [i]cantadores[/i] from Northeastern Brazil.

Repente.name: Repente
Repente.description_short: Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats.

Capoeira Music.name: Capoeira Music
Capoeira Music.description_short: Afro-Brazilian style that accompanies and sets the rhythm and energy of the capoeira martial art, originating in the 19th century with the relocation of African slaves to the states of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro.

Fandango caiçara.name: Fandango caiçara
Fandango caiçara.description_short: Style of fandango born in coastal Southern Brazil amidst the Caiçara people.

Jongo.name: Jongo
Jongo.description_short: Afro-Brazilian cultural manifestation involving music and dance; composed of percussion instruments and chants.

Ponto de umbanda.name: Ponto de umbanda
Ponto de umbanda.description_short: Afro-Brazilian religious ritualistic praise sung by priests to evoke entities; typically accompanied by claps and traditional drums known as [i]atabaque[/i].

Lundu.name: Lundu
Lundu.description_short: Afro-Brazilian musical genre that emerged in the 18th century with influences from African drumming with European Fandango.

Maracatu.name: Maracatu
Maracatu.description_short: Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.

Modinha.name: Modinha
Modinha.description_short: Popular during the 18th and 19th centuries in Brazil; characterized by sentimental works with amorous themes, poetic lyrics, acoustic instrumentation and operatic vocals.

Rasqueado.name: Rasqueado
Rasqueado.description_short: Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.

Samba de roda.name: Samba de roda
Samba de roda.description_short: Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with [Genre27668] and [Genre33493].

Sertanejo de raiz.name: Sertanejo de raiz
Sertanejo de raiz.description_short: Earliest form of [Genre613], emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.

Moda de viola.name: Moda de viola
Moda de viola.description_short: Style of [Genre615] predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.

Toada de Boi.name: Toada de Boi
Toada de Boi.description_short: Slow, heavy-percussed tunes celebrating the folkloric Ox, originally from Bumba-meu-boi June parties in Northeastern Brazil.

Xaxado.name: Xaxado
Xaxado.description_short: Features a strong rhythmic beat, sliding tap dances, and stories of backland bandits.

Buryat Folk Music.name: Buryat Folk Music
Buryat Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Buryat people, a Mongolic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Buryatia, a federal subject of the Russian Far East region.

Canadian Folk Music.name: Canadian Folk Music
Canadian Folk Music.description_short: Traditional folk of the European settlers who arrived in Canada.

Canadian Maritime Folk.name: Canadian Maritime Folk
Canadian Maritime Folk.description_short: Traditional folk of Canada's Maritimes (Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick).

Cape Breton Folk Music.name: Cape Breton Folk Music
Cape Breton Folk Music.description_short: [Genre642] that emerged in Cape Breton, an island at the eastern shore of Nova Scotia, through immigrants from Scotland and Ireland.

Cape Breton Fiddling.name: Cape Breton Fiddling
Cape Breton Fiddling.description_short: Distinctive Celtic fiddling originating from the Scottish immigrants who settled in Canada on Cape Breton Island.

French-Canadian Folk Music.name: French-Canadian Folk Music
French-Canadian Folk Music.description_short: Brought by French colonists to their Nouvelle-France settlements, primarily based around [Genre10437] with influences from [Genre27764] and [Genre642], typically played during gatherings and holidays.

Métis Fiddling.name: Métis Fiddling
Métis Fiddling.description_short: Canadian style blending First Nations and European musical influences into an up-tempo style of fiddling characterized by the use of syncopation and indigenous rhythms.

Newfoundland Folk Music.name: Newfoundland Folk Music
Newfoundland Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada's easternmost province.

Caribbean Folk Music.name: Caribbean Folk Music
Caribbean Folk Music.description_short: Meta-genre that covers the different forms of [Genre10448] from the Caribbean.

Bele.name: Bele
Bele.description_short: Drum-based folkdance with a strong Afro-influence, conducted by duos of dancers and accompanied by call-and-response singing, particularly popular in Martinique, Dominica and Trinidad and Tobago.

Benna.name: Benna
Benna.description_short: Traditional music of Antigua & Barbuda, using call-and-response and bawdy lyrics.

Bomba.name: Bomba
Bomba.description_short: Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.

Fungi.name: Fungi
Fungi.description_short: [Genre10448] native to the Virgin Islands, named after a local dish which features a "mixed-up" flavor that can be compared to the style that combines Western instruments with local ones.

Garifuna Folk Music.name: Garifuna Folk Music
Garifuna Folk Music.description_short: Folk of Garifunas, Caribbean people born from escaped African slaves and local Caribbean natives.

Haitian Vodou Drumming.name: Haitian Vodou Drumming
Haitian Vodou Drumming.description_short: Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.

Jibaro.name: Jibaro
Jibaro.description_short: Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.

Kaiso.name: Kaiso
Kaiso.description_short: Trinidadian folk considered to be the precursor of [Genre10154], led by "griot" storytellers who sing derogatory lyrics to the sound of drums and guitars in a call-and-response manner in order to rebel against slaveowners.

Kitchen Dance Music.name: Kitchen Dance Music
Kitchen Dance Music.description_short: Cayman Islands music played during kitchen dance parties, centered around fiddle and percussion (handmade or kitchen grater) playing.

Mento.name: Mento
Mento.description_short: Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in [Genre144].

Méringue.name: Méringue
Méringue.description_short: Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of [Genre20729].

Plena.name: Plena
Plena.description_short: Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.

Ripsaw.name: Ripsaw
Ripsaw.description_short: Indigenous style of the Turks and Caicos Islands, featuring a handsaw as the primary instrument.

Tumba.name: Tumba
Tumba.description_short: African-style percussion alongside Latin influences and often explicit lyrics.

Virgin Islander Cariso.name: Virgin Islander Cariso
Virgin Islander Cariso.description_short: Folk of the Virgin Islands, sung exclusively by women to the beat of one or two drums.

Caucasian Folk Music.name: Caucasian Folk Music
Caucasian Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Caucasus region, a mountainous area that connects Eastern Europe to Asia.

Abkhazian Folk Music.name: Abkhazian Folk Music
Abkhazian Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Republic of Abkhazia, a disputed territory on the Black Sea in northwestern Georgia.

Chechen Folk Music.name: Chechen Folk Music
Chechen Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Chechens, a Northeast Caucasian ethnic group predominantly living in the Republic of Chechnya, a federal subject of Russia.

Circassian Folk Music.name: Circassian Folk Music
Circassian Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the native Circassian peoples of Northern Caucasus, residing in the Republics of Adygea, Karachay-Cherkessia, and Kabardino-Balkaria respectively, which are federal subjects of the Russian Federation, as well as the territories of the former Ottoman Empire, with a significant diaspora population in modern Turkey.

Georgian Folk Music.name: Georgian Folk Music
Georgian Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Georgian people, who mostly live in Georgia.

Batonebi Songs.name: Batonebi Songs
Batonebi Songs.description_short: Traditional Georgian [Genre21093] often meant to soothe sick children.

Ossetian Folk Music.name: Ossetian Folk Music
Ossetian Folk Music.description_short: Folk music of Ossetians, an ethnic group that mainly inhabits a region located on both sides of the Greater Caucasus Mountains.

East Asian Folk Music.name: East Asian Folk Music
East Asian Folk Music.description_short: All the forms of [Genre10448] from East Asia, including [Genre22229], [Genre25511], and [Genre28306].

Amami shimauta.name: Amami shimauta
Amami shimauta.description_short: Tradition from the Amami Islands, located in southern Japan.

Chinese Folk Music.name: Chinese Folk Music
Chinese Folk Music.description_short: Traditional folk of the Chinese people.

Chaozhou xianshi.name: Chaozhou xianshi
Chaozhou xianshi.description_short: Traditional and instrumental ensemble music originating from Chaozhou; played mainly on stringed instruments.

Han Folk Music.name: Han Folk Music
Han Folk Music.description_short: Chinese folk form often played at weddings and funerals, using the Suona (a form of oboe) and Chuigushou (a specific type of percussive ensemble), together with heterophony.

Haozi.name: Haozi
Haozi.description_short: Chinese [Genre294] that originated from collective manual labor and usually follows a call-and-response structure, aiming to coordinate work.

Jiangnan sizhu.name: Jiangnan sizhu
Jiangnan sizhu.description_short: Originating from Jiangnan region and played by a varying ensemble of stringed instruments, flutes, mouth organs and small percussions.

Shan'ge.name: Shan'ge
Shan'ge.description_short: [Genre26677] songs found in upland regions of China, typically sung while working.

Indigenous Taiwanese Music.name: Indigenous Taiwanese Music
