Indigenous Taiwanese Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the various Austronesian people groups that make up the indigenous population of the island of Taiwan.

Kagura.name: Kagura
Kagura.description_short: Performed at Shinto shrines for ceremonies and rituals.

Kouta.name: Kouta
Kouta.description_short: Kouta, which literally means "little" or "short" song, is one type of the many varieties of Japanese folk songs that is distinguished by its briefness and wittiness.

Min'yō.name: Min'yō
Min'yō.description_short: Form of [Genre22229] which literally translates to "folk song".

Ondō.name: Ondō
Ondō.description_short: Originally referred to the type of call-and-response form of [Genre10259], but later became to be known for and distinguished by a swung 2/2 rhythm and storytelling.

Rōkyoku.name: Rōkyoku
Rōkyoku.description_short: Storytelling usually accompanied by a shamisen.

Taiko.name: Taiko
Taiko.description_short: Modern style of ensemble drumming, sometimes called kumi-daiko.

Tsugaru shamisen.name: Tsugaru shamisen
Tsugaru shamisen.description_short: Shamisen playing originating in the Tsugaru Peninsula of Aomori prefecture, recognizable in its percussive quality and special, slightly larger instrument.

Pansori.name: Pansori
Pansori.description_short: Korean style of storytelling characterized by over-the-top, passionate singing from a solo vocalist accompanied by minimal drumming.

Pungmul.name: Pungmul
Pungmul.description_short: Consists of drumming, dancing, and singing, and is a tradition deeply ingrained in South Korean culture.

Sanjo.name: Sanjo
Sanjo.description_short: Traditional instrumental [Genre28306] that focuses on a wide variety of rhythmic changes with many different classical Korean instruments.

Sinawi.name: Sinawi
Sinawi.description_short: Improvisational genre traditionally serving as an accompaniment to Korean shamanic rituals.

Vietnamese Folk Music.name: Vietnamese Folk Music
Vietnamese Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Vietnamese people, with traditions influenced by both [Genre46918] and Austronesian culture through the Cham people.

Chèo.name: Chèo
Chèo.description_short: Northern Vietnamese folk musical theatre, characterized by minimal set design and satirical content.

Quan họ.name: Quan họ
Quan họ.description_short: Tradition of the Northern Vietnamese provinces of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang, originally consisting of harmonic, a cappella singing from two competing duos.

Xẩm.name: Xẩm
Xẩm.description_short: Developed in Northern Vietnam, traditionally sung by blind bards accompanied by a [i]đàn bầu[/i] or [i]đàn nhị[/i].

European Folk Music.name: European Folk Music
European Folk Music.description_short: Encompasses numerous folk traditions found in Europe.

Alpine Folk Music.name: Alpine Folk Music
Alpine Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Alps, including parts of Germany, Austria, Slovenia, Switzerland, and Italy.

Ländler.name: Ländler
Ländler.description_short: Swiss-German dance band music based on the accordion, combining traditional [Genre10359] with elements from [Genre431] and [Genre6].

Narodno zabavna glasba.name: Narodno zabavna glasba
Narodno zabavna glasba.description_short: Modernised form of [Genre21852] from the Alpine region of Upper Carniola (Oberkrain).

Naturjodel.name: Naturjodel
Naturjodel.description_short: Originated in Toggenburg and Appenzell in Switzerland; deep vocal range, relaxed voice, free tempo, polyphony, elongated notes, improvisation, glissando, and use of syllabic sounds.

Balkan Folk Music.name: Balkan Folk Music
Balkan Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Balkan region of Southeastern Europe.

Albanian Folk Music.name: Albanian Folk Music
Albanian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Albania, including the area's traditions as well as influence from [Genre26050].

Lab Polyphony.name: Lab Polyphony
Lab Polyphony.description_short: One of several genres of iso-polyphonic music performed in southern Albania, with "iso" referring to the distinctive drone voice used.

Musika popullore.name: Musika popullore
Musika popullore.description_short: Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified [Genre643] usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.

Tosk Polyphony.name: Tosk Polyphony
Tosk Polyphony.description_short: Polyphonic singing in the Toskëri region of southern Albania.

Izvorna bosanska muzika.name: Izvorna bosanska muzika
Izvorna bosanska muzika.description_short: Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.

Sevdalinka.name: Sevdalinka
Sevdalinka.description_short: Melancholic folk song, originating from Bosnia and Herzegovina, typically love-themed and accompanied by instruments like guitar and accordion.

Bulgarian Folk Music.name: Bulgarian Folk Music
Bulgarian Folk Music.description_short: Consists of a variety of traditions and styles, with distinct sounds originating from current and historical regions such as Sofia, Dobrudzha, Macedonia and Thrace.

Klapa.name: Klapa
Klapa.description_short: Traditional form characteristic of the Dalmatia region of Croatia rooted in littoral church singing.

Csango Folk Music.name: Csango Folk Music
Csango Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Csango, an ethnic minority group with Hungarian origins living primarily in the Romanian Moldavia region, but who are also found in the Transylvania, Dobruja, Moldova, the Ukrainian Chernivtsi region, and the Tolna region of Hungary.

Gagauz Folk Music.name: Gagauz Folk Music
Gagauz Folk Music.description_short: Gagauz people are a Turkic group living mostly in the southern Gagauzia region of Moldova, but also nearby areas like southwestern Ukraine and southeastern Romania.

Ganga.name: Ganga
Ganga.description_short: Dissonant form of polyphonic singing from the regions of Herzegovina and Dalmatia.

Aegean Islands Folk Music.name: Aegean Islands Folk Music
Aegean Islands Folk Music.description_short: Music of the Greek Aegean Islands.

Cretan Folk Music.name: Cretan Folk Music
Cretan Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Greek island Crete.

Rizitika.name: Rizitika
Rizitika.description_short: Some of the oldest and most important types of vocal music on the Cretan island, characterized by its dramatic style of singing.

Dimotika.name: Dimotika
Dimotika.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Greek mainland, often using clarinet, guitar, tambourine, and violin as accompaniment, while also incorporating various forms of Greek dance and vocal music.

Ionian Islands Folk Music.name: Ionian Islands Folk Music
Ionian Islands Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] from the Ionian Islands in Greece.

Rembetika.name: Rembetika
Rembetika.description_short: Greek tradition originating in traditional Mikrasiatiki and Smyrnaiki music with elements of other local traditional Greek genres.

Macedonian Folk Music.name: Macedonian Folk Music
Macedonian Folk Music.description_short: Folk music of Macedonians, a South Slavic ethnic group who are primarily associated with the Republic of Macedonia.

Čalgija.name: Čalgija
Čalgija.description_short: Urban folk from Macedonia very popular in the 19th and 20th centuries performed by ensembles called Čalgii.

Muzică lăutărească.name: Muzică lăutărească
Muzică lăutărească.description_short: Strongly influenced by folk from Turkey, Russia, and Western Europe, and even by Byzantine Church music.

Starogradska muzika.name: Starogradska muzika
Starogradska muzika.description_short: Translated as "old city music", this is the urban traditional music of Macedonia and Serbia.

Sutartinės.name: Sutartinės
Sutartinės.description_short: Unique form of polyphonic vocal music originating from a small area of Northeastern Lithuania.

Seto leelo.name: Seto leelo
Seto leelo.description_short: Style of polyphonic singing of the Seto people.

Rune Singing.name: Rune Singing
Rune Singing.description_short: Traditional vocal music of Baltic-Finnic peoples characterized by singing poems, performed solo or in groups.

Trikitixa.name: Trikitixa
Trikitixa.description_short: Form of Basque folk music characterized by the use of accordion and tambourine.

Catalan Folk Music.name: Catalan Folk Music
Catalan Folk Music.description_short: Blend of local styles and influences from the Iberian Peninsula region and the Catalonian area of Southern France.

Sardana.name: Sardana
Sardana.description_short: Traditional dance dating from the 16th century performed by large ensembles called 'Cobla' and danced by people holding hands in a circle.

Valencian Folk Music.name: Valencian Folk Music
Valencian Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Valencian Country.

Celtic Folk Music.name: Celtic Folk Music
Celtic Folk Music.description_short: Derived from Celtic traditions of Ireland, Scotland, Wales, Cornwall, the Isle of Man, Brittany, Galicia, Cantabria, Asturias, and Trás-os-Montes (Portugal).

Breton Celtic Folk Music.name: Breton Celtic Folk Music
Breton Celtic Folk Music.description_short: Movement in the Brittany region of France which translated [Genre642] from Ireland and Scotland into the Celtic Breton language.

Bagad.name: Bagad
Bagad.description_short: Breton style performed by bands featuring bagpipes, bombardes, and percussion.

Cornish Folk Music.name: Cornish Folk Music
Cornish Folk Music.description_short: Musical traditions developed by the Cornish people, mainly found in the county of Cornwall in South West England.

Sean-nós.name: Sean-nós
Sean-nós.description_short: Highly ornamented, unaccompanied singing in the Irish language.

Manx Folk Music.name: Manx Folk Music
Manx Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Isle of Man.

Òrain Ghàidhlig.name: Òrain Ghàidhlig
Òrain Ghàidhlig.description_short: Songs sung in Scottish Gaelic, often but not always unaccompanied.

Òrain luaidh.name: Òrain luaidh
Òrain luaidh.description_short: Rhythmic call-and-response style song form that traditionally accompanied the production of tweed cloth through beating the material by hand to soften it after it came off the loom.

Seinn nan salm.name: Seinn nan salm
Seinn nan salm.description_short: Unaccompanied, rhythmically free-flowing psalm singing in Gaelic practiced by Presbyterian churches, which involves a call-and-response between the precentor and the congregation.

Pipe Band.name: Pipe Band
Pipe Band.description_short: Tradition originating in the Scottish military; standard instruments consist of 6-25 sets of Great Highland bagpipes, 3-10 military snare drums, 1-6 Scottish tenor drums, and one bass drum.

Scots Song.name: Scots Song
Scots Song.description_short: Traditional folk songs usually sung in Lowland Scots, often but not always unaccompanied.

Scottish Country Dance Music.name: Scottish Country Dance Music
Scottish Country Dance Music.description_short: Strict-tempo style played by Scottish country dance bands, led by an accordion or a fiddle and featuring piano, drums and sometimes double bass.

Shetland & Orkney Folk Music.name: Shetland & Orkney Folk Music
Shetland & Orkney Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Shetland and Orkney Islands.

English Folk Music.name: English Folk Music
English Folk Music.description_short: Musical traditions of the English people, primarily divided into dance music and folksongs.

Northumbrian Folk Music.name: Northumbrian Folk Music
Northumbrian Folk Music.description_short: Traditional folk of Northumbria, a region of Northern England consisting of Northumberland and County Durham.

Scrumpy and Western.name: Scrumpy and Western
Scrumpy and Western.description_short: Usually humorous music originating from England's West Country, heavily featuring traditional English folk instruments and often sung in the West Country accent.

Flemish Folk Music.name: Flemish Folk Music
Flemish Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Flanders region in northern Belgium, typically sung in the local Flemish dialect.

French Folk Music.name: French Folk Music
French Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of metropolitan France, including that of its regional cultures.

Breton Folk Music.name: Breton Folk Music
Breton Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Brittany region in France, including [Genre31763] and music in the regional Romance language, Gallo.

Kan ha diskan.name: Kan ha diskan
Kan ha diskan.description_short: Call and response type of folk singing from Brittany.

Corsican Folk Music.name: Corsican Folk Music
Corsican Folk Music.description_short: French folk from Corsica, sung mainly in Corsican and sometimes in French.

Paghjella.name: Paghjella
Paghjella.description_short: Traditional [Genre21012] from Corsica consisting of three registers of vocalists singing in a semicircle.

Musette.name: Musette
Musette.description_short: French popular music which arose in 1880s Paris, performed with the traditional instruments musette, grelottière, and accordion.

Swing musette.name: Swing musette
Swing musette.description_short: Appeared in the 1930s in France, combination of [Genre10447] with [Genre624], mainly focusing on accordion playing.

Occitan Folk Music.name: Occitan Folk Music
Occitan Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of Occitania, sung mainly in Occitan and sometimes in French.

Auvergnat Folk Music.name: Auvergnat Folk Music
Auvergnat Folk Music.description_short: Traditional Folk Music from Auvergne region.

Gascon Folk Music.name: Gascon Folk Music
Gascon Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10437] from the Gascony cultural region in southwest France.

Gstanzl.name: Gstanzl
Gstanzl.description_short: Short improvised traditional song form the larger Bavarian region (Southeastern Germany and Austria), satirical and often being accompanied with dances.

Għana.name: Għana
Għana.description_short: Indigenous Maltese folk which consists of quatrains, ideally improvised, following a rhyme scheme of a-b-c-b, and sung to traditional tunes, usually accompanied by guitars.

Csárdás.name: Csárdás
Csárdás.description_short: Traditional Hungarian dance and music form characterized by tempo variations.

Magyar nóta.name: Magyar nóta
Magyar nóta.description_short: Hungarian genre from the 19th century, combining [Genre20160] with [Genre183] composition techniques.

Canzone napoletana.name: Canzone napoletana
Canzone napoletana.description_short: Sung in the Neapolitan language by a male voice with instrumental accompaniment, originating in the Italian city of Naples and the surrounding regions.

Liscio.name: Liscio
Liscio.description_short: Italian popular genre characterized by the fast execution of solo instruments such as clarinet, saxophone, or the accordion.

Sardinian Folk Music.name: Sardinian Folk Music
Sardinian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Sardinia, an island in the Mediterranean Sea.

Cantu a chiterra.name: Cantu a chiterra
Cantu a chiterra.description_short: Traditional monophonic singing accompanied by a [i]chittera sarda[/i] from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.

Cantu a tenore.name: Cantu a tenore
Cantu a tenore.description_short: Secular [Genre21012] from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.

Stornello.name: Stornello
Stornello.description_short: Italian folk poetry, generally improvised and handed down by street singers, carters or sellers.

Tarantella.name: Tarantella
Tarantella.description_short: Fast upbeat tempo, switching between major and minor modes while gradually increasing in speed.

Pizzica.name: Pizzica
Pizzica.description_short: Italian Folk dance and music from Apulia, belonging to the family of [Genre43955].

Tammurriata.name: Tammurriata
Tammurriata.description_short: Italian folk from Campania, belonging to the family of [Genre43955].

Trallalero.name: Trallalero
Trallalero.description_short: Polyphonic [Genre10448] originating in the Ligurian region of Genoa, in northern Italy.

Neo-Medieval Folk.name: Neo-Medieval Folk
Neo-Medieval Folk.description_short: Emulates [Genre31289] from the Middle Ages, originating in Germany in the 1980s.

Bardcore.name: Bardcore
Bardcore.description_short: Rearranges contemporary music with an array of acoustic instrumentation to evoke the aesthetic of medieval Europe.

Neo-Pagan Folk.name: Neo-Pagan Folk
Neo-Pagan Folk.description_short: Emulates music played by pagan people, particularly from pre-Christian Europe.

Nordic Folk Music.name: Nordic Folk Music
Nordic Folk Music.description_short: Folk of Nordic countries of Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden.

Icelandic Folk Music.name: Icelandic Folk Music
Icelandic Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Iceland, including a variety of styles like the rímur, the kvædaskapur and langspil instrumental music.

Joik.name: Joik
Joik.description_short: Traditional Sami singing style found in northern Finland, Sweden, Norway and Russia.

Nordic Old Time Dance Music.name: Nordic Old Time Dance Music
Nordic Old Time Dance Music.description_short: Meta-genre strongly related to [Genre10117] having less complex structures, easy rhythms, and melodic lines.

Polska.name: Polska
Polska.description_short: Traditional Nordic dance with a 3/4 rhythm.

Hambo.name: Hambo
Hambo.description_short: Traditional Swedish dance with a 3/4 rhythm and an emphasis on the first beat.

Norwegian Folk Music.name: Norwegian Folk Music
Norwegian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Norway, primarily intended as accompaniment for dancing and coming in two main varieties, instrumental and vocal music.

Swedish Folk Music.name: Swedish Folk Music
Swedish Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Swedish people, commonly incorporating fiddle, accordion, flute, nyckelharpa, and/or voice.

Polka.name: Polka
Polka.description_short: Lively style and corresponding dance originating in Central and Eastern Europe, featuring a 2/4 cut time beat and instruments which vary by region.

Polka peruana.name: Polka peruana
Polka peruana.description_short: Peruvian adaptation of European [Genre10136], blending Afro-Peruvian rhythms and criollo melodies.

Cante alentejano.name: Cante alentejano
Cante alentejano.description_short: Traditional [Genre32475] based on vocal music from the Alentejo region.

Chamarrita açoriana.name: Chamarrita açoriana
Chamarrita açoriana.description_short: Refers to a popular folkloric dance, of the Azores islands, as well as the accompanying music.

Desgarrada.name: Desgarrada
Desgarrada.description_short: Improvisational tradition from Northern Portugal where two vocalists address and respond to each other, usually in a joking manner.

Fado.name: Fado
Fado.description_short: Tradition from Portugal originating in the first half of the 19th century, mainly consisting of melancholic songs accompanied by Portuguese guitars or classical guitars.

Fado de Coimbra.name: Fado de Coimbra
Fado de Coimbra.description_short: [Genre640] variant originated in the city of Coimbra, known for its serenades.

Trás-os-Montes Folk Music.name: Trás-os-Montes Folk Music
Trás-os-Montes Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Portuguese province of Trás-os-Montes.

Vira.name: Vira
Vira.description_short: Musical-choreographic genre performed in Portuguese folklore, characteristic of the Minho region.

Bocet.name: Bocet
Bocet.description_short: Traditional Romanian music sung by women mourning at a funeral.

Colinde.name: Colinde
Colinde.description_short: Christmas music from Romanian folklore with ritualistic and pagan roots.

Doină.name: Doină
Doină.description_short: Melancholic, lyrical folk song characterised by its free rhythm.

Belarusian Folk Music.name: Belarusian Folk Music
Belarusian Folk Music.description_short: Eastern [Genre29248], including traditional ceremonial, wedding, and harvest songs.

Czech Folk Music.name: Czech Folk Music
Czech Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Czech people in central Europe.

Goral Music.name: Goral Music
Goral Music.description_short: Music of highlanders occupying Northern Carpathians (Gorals).

Polish Goral Music.name: Polish Goral Music
Polish Goral Music.description_short: Music of indigenous highlanders native to the Western Beskids and the Podhale regions in Southern Poland.

Folklor miejski.name: Folklor miejski
Folklor miejski.description_short: Urban folk street band traditions of Polish cities.

Warsaw City Folk.name: Warsaw City Folk
Warsaw City Folk.description_short: Traditional urban poetry sung in the Warsaw dialect by buskers, and accompanied by street bands.

Kashubian Folk Music.name: Kashubian Folk Music
Kashubian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Kashubian people of northwestern Poland.

Krakowiak.name: Krakowiak
Krakowiak.description_short: Fast, syncopated, duple-time national dance of Poland.

Kujawiak.name: Kujawiak
Kujawiak.description_short: Calm, triple-time national dance of Poland.

Kujon.name: Kujon
Kujon.description_short: Melancholic triple-time folk dance from Łowicz and Łęczyca regions, related to [Genre52573] and [Genre52661].

Kurpian Folk Music.name: Kurpian Folk Music
Kurpian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Kurpian people of eastern Poland.

Oberek.name: Oberek
Oberek.description_short: Fastest triple-time national dance of Poland.

Russian Folk Music.name: Russian Folk Music
Russian Folk Music.description_short: Eastern [Genre29248] native to the Russian people.

Ukrainian Folk Music.name: Ukrainian Folk Music
Ukrainian Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the people of Ukraine.

Duma.name: Duma
Duma.description_short: Type of Ukrainian sung epic poem.

Spanish Folk Music.name: Spanish Folk Music
Spanish Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Spain, widely diverse due to the distinct culture and traditions of the country's different regions.

Andalusian Folk Music.name: Andalusian Folk Music
Andalusian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10093] of Andalusia in southern Spain, rooted in traditional music and dances and developed mostly after the 18th century by the Romani people of Andalusia (known locally as [i]gitanos[/i]).

Saeta.name: Saeta
Saeta.description_short: Traditional religious praise song that originated in Andalusia, Spain towards the end of the late Middle Ages.

Sevillanas.name: Sevillanas
Sevillanas.description_short: Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.

Asturian Folk Music.name: Asturian Folk Music
Asturian Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Asturian people.

Canarian Folk Music.name: Canarian Folk Music
Canarian Folk Music.description_short: Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

Chotis madrileño.name: Chotis madrileño
Chotis madrileño.description_short: Spanish variant of [i]schottisch[/i], a slow version of German [Genre10136] which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local [i]castizo[/i] culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.

Copla.name: Copla
Copla.description_short: Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like [Genre29754] and has strong links to [Genre10093].

Cuplé.name: Cuplé
Cuplé.description_short: Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.

Galician Folk Music.name: Galician Folk Music
Galician Folk Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Galician people.

Pasodoble.name: Pasodoble
Pasodoble.description_short: Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.

Volga-Ural Folk Music.name: Volga-Ural Folk Music
Volga-Ural Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Volga-Ural region in the European Russia.

Bashkir Folk Music.name: Bashkir Folk Music
Bashkir Folk Music.description_short: Traditional folk of the Bashkir people, a Turkic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Bashkortostan (Bashkiria), a federal subject of the Russian Federation, and its neighboring areas on both sides of the Ural mountains.

Udmurt Folk Music.name: Udmurt Folk Music
Udmurt Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Udmurt people inhabiting areas in the Volga-Ural region of Russia.

Volga Tatar Folk Music.name: Volga Tatar Folk Music
Volga Tatar Folk Music.description_short: [genre10448] of the Volga Tatar people native to republics of Tatarstan and Bashkortostan.

Walloon Folk Music.name: Walloon Folk Music
Walloon Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Wallonia, the mostly French-speaking southern region of Belgium which also includes a few Flemish and German minorities.

White Voice.name: White Voice
White Voice.description_short: Traditional form of vocal music of Eastern European peoples.

Yiddish Folksong.name: Yiddish Folksong
Yiddish Folksong.description_short: Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.

Football Chant.name: Football Chant
Football Chant.description_short: Sung by large crowds at association football (soccer) games to celebrate or insult teams.

Hazara Folk Music.name: Hazara Folk Music
Hazara Folk Music.description_short: Folk music of the Hazara people, mainly native to central Afghanistan.

Hispanic American Folk Music.name: Hispanic American Folk Music
Hispanic American Folk Music.description_short: Encompasses many varieties of folk traditions from Hispanic America.

Bambuco.name: Bambuco
Bambuco.description_short: Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.

Candombe.name: Candombe
Candombe.description_short: Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.

Canto a lo poeta.name: Canto a lo poeta
Canto a lo poeta.description_short: Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.

Carranga.name: Carranga
Carranga.description_short: Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.

Chacarera.name: Chacarera
Chacarera.description_short: Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.

Chamamé.name: Chamamé
Chamamé.description_short: Mixes native Guaraní music with [Genre55570] and European schottische music.

Chamarrita rioplatense.name: Chamarrita rioplatense
Chamarrita rioplatense.description_short: Traditional genre and dance featuring similar rhythms to [Genre26356] and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.

Cueca.name: Cueca
Cueca.description_short: Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.

Joropo.name: Joropo
Joropo.description_short: Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.

Malagueña venezolana.name: Malagueña venezolana
Malagueña venezolana.description_short: Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.

Canto cardenche.name: Canto cardenche
Canto cardenche.description_short: Overtly dramatic, and melancholic [Genre10163] performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.

Pirekua.name: Pirekua
Pirekua.description_short: Traditional style of the P’urhépecha people, typically slow and in 3/8 or 6/8 time.

Son calentano.name: Son calentano
Son calentano.description_short: Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.

Son huasteco.name: Son huasteco
Son huasteco.description_short: Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.

Son istmeño.name: Son istmeño
Son istmeño.description_short: Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.

Son jarocho.name: Son jarocho
Son jarocho.description_short: [Genre31874] from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.

Trova yucateca.name: Trova yucateca
Trova yucateca.description_short: Heavily influenced by [Genre32800], freely embracing [Genre10507], clave and [Genre41427].

Milonga.name: Milonga
Milonga.description_short: Characterized by a slow rhythm usually performed on a guitar; generally considered a precursor to [Genre10071].

Muliza.name: Muliza
Muliza.description_short: Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.

Música criolla peruana.name: Música criolla peruana
Música criolla peruana.description_short: Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.

Festejo.name: Festejo
Festejo.description_short: Happy and danceable Afro-Peruvian rhythm originating in the 17th century.

Landó.name: Landó
Landó.description_short: 16th-century Afro-Peruvian dance and music style, played primarily on the cajón and the creole guitar in a 12/8 rhythm.

Marinera.name: Marinera
Marinera.description_short: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

Tondero.name: Tondero
Tondero.description_short: Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

Vals criollo.name: Vals criollo
Vals criollo.description_short: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.

Música llanera.name: Música llanera
Música llanera.description_short: Traditional music originating from the Llanos region of Colombia and Venezuela.

Saya.name: Saya
Saya.description_short: Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.

Tamborito.name: Tamborito
Tamborito.description_short: Folk music and dance from Panama dating back to the 17th century.

Taquirari.name: Taquirari
Taquirari.description_short: Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of [Genre32996], and featuring a syncopated rhythm.

Tonada chilena.name: Tonada chilena
Tonada chilena.description_short: Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.

Yaraví.name: Yaraví
Yaraví.description_short: Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.

Zamacueca.name: Zamacueca
Zamacueca.description_short: Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.

Zamba.name: Zamba
Zamba.description_short: Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian [genre52538] during the 19th century.

Indigenous American Traditional Music.name: Indigenous American Traditional Music
Indigenous American Traditional Music.description_short: Meta-genre encompassing traditions attributed to the indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Athabaskan Fiddling.name: Athabaskan Fiddling
Athabaskan Fiddling.description_short: Fiddle playing of the Northern Athabaskan Dene people of modern-day Alaska, the Yukon, and the Northwest Territories.

Inuit Vocal Games.name: Inuit Vocal Games
Inuit Vocal Games.description_short: Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.

James Bay Fiddling.name: James Bay Fiddling
James Bay Fiddling.description_short: Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.

Mapuche Folk Music.name: Mapuche Folk Music
Mapuche Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.

Powwow Music.name: Powwow Music
Powwow Music.description_short: Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.

Tonada potosina.name: Tonada potosina
Tonada potosina.description_short: Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on [i]charangos[/i] and [i]guitarillas[/i], with a catchy, lively rhythm.

Unakesa.name: Unakesa
Unakesa.description_short: Lay song and dance of the Fulni-ô people.

Indigenous Australian Traditional Music.name: Indigenous Australian Traditional Music
Indigenous Australian Traditional Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders, collectively known as Indigenous Australians.

Djanba.name: Djanba
Djanba.description_short: Sung and composed in the Murrinh-Patha language and consisting of a mixed group of men and women accompanied by bilma and handclaps, typically without didgeridoo.

Wangga.name: Wangga
Wangga.description_short: Originated from the Daly region, consists of performances featuring wood sticks, didgeridoo and voice.

Ladino Folksong.name: Ladino Folksong
Ladino Folksong.description_short: Ladino-language [Genre10448] tunes that were written and preserved by Sephardic Jews.

Ob-Ugric Folk Music.name: Ob-Ugric Folk Music
Ob-Ugric Folk Music.description_short: [genre10448] of the Ob-Ugric people of West Siberia Plain.

Payada.name: Payada
Payada.description_short: Improvised poetry accompanied by a guitar that is tied to gaucho culture, usually performed in duo as a verse duel.

Romani Folk Music.name: Romani Folk Music
Romani Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Romani people, an ethnic group with origins in Northern India, but who have since the Middle Ages settled around Europe, principally Romania, Bulgaria, and Spain, and many other places.

South Asian Folk Music.name: South Asian Folk Music
South Asian Folk Music.description_short: Meta-genre which covers all the [Genre10448] forms from South Asia.

Assamese Folk Music.name: Assamese Folk Music
Assamese Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Assamese people, a people group mostly from the Northeastern Indian state of Assam.

Bengali Folk Music.name: Bengali Folk Music
Bengali Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Bengali people found mainly in the Indian state of West Bengal and the country of Bangladesh.

Baul gaan.name: Baul gaan
Baul gaan.description_short: Songs performed by the Bauls, a movement of mystic entertainers influenced by diverse spiritual traditions.

Bhojpuri Folk Music.name: Bhojpuri Folk Music
Bhojpuri Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Bhojpuri people of India, originally from the states of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.

Biraha.name: Biraha
Biraha.description_short: Call-and-response style of folk music developed from the Ahir and neighboring castes of the Bhojpuri people.

Boduberu.name: Boduberu
Boduberu.description_short: Traditional, percussion-based form of music popular in the Maldives, usually following a crescendo structure.

Burushaski Folk Music.name: Burushaski Folk Music
Burushaski Folk Music.description_short: [genre10448] of the Burusho people of northern Pakistan.

Gujarati Folk Music.name: Gujarati Folk Music
Gujarati Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Gujarati people, who primarily live in the western Indian state of Gujarat.

Kannada Folk Music.name: Kannada Folk Music
Kannada Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Kannada people, a large ethnolinguistic group who mainly inhabit the state of Karnataka in southwestern India.

Kirtan.name: Kirtan
Kirtan.description_short: Call-and-response chanting that involves the singing of devotional mantras and hymns in a bhakti devotional style, occasionally accompanied with traditional folk instrumentation.

Malayali Folk Music.name: Malayali Folk Music
Malayali Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Kerala, India primarily sung in the Malayalam language and known for its drumming and percussion.

Marathi Folk Music.name: Marathi Folk Music
Marathi Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Marathi people, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Maharashtra in western India.

Newa Folk Music.name: Newa Folk Music
Newa Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Newa people, who live in Nepal, performed with mostly percussive instruments and some wind instruments.

Odia Folk Music.name: Odia Folk Music
Odia Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Odia, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Odisha in eastern India.

Pashto Folk Music.name: Pashto Folk Music
Pashto Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Pashtun people of southern Afghanistan and north-western Pakistan.

Punjabi Folk Music.name: Punjabi Folk Music
Punjabi Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Punjabi people, mostly from the Punjab regions of India and Pakistan, covering diverse styles often played with traditional instruments.

Rajasthani Folk Music.name: Rajasthani Folk Music
Rajasthani Folk Music.description_short: Traditions of the Rajasthani people of Western India - who now mostly live in the eponymous Rajasthan state - originated across the various castes that inhabit the region.

Sinhalese Folk Music.name: Sinhalese Folk Music
Sinhalese Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Sinhalese people, the majority ethnic group of Sri Lanka.

Urumi melam.name: Urumi melam
Urumi melam.description_short: Percussive ensemble native to the Tamil Nadu region, taking its name from the [i]urumi[/i] drum.

Telugu Folk Music.name: Telugu Folk Music
Telugu Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Telugu people, one of the largest ethnolinguistic groups of India, mainly living in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

Southeast Asian Folk Music.name: Southeast Asian Folk Music
Southeast Asian Folk Music.description_short: Meta-genre covering all folk forms from Southeast Asia, like [Genre27556], Hmong, Iban, Karen, [Genre20867], Khmer, Lao, Lun Bawang, [Genre25168], and Orang Ulu.

Balitaw.name: Balitaw
Balitaw.description_short: Folk originating in the Visayas islands of the Philippines; dialogue or debate in which a man and a woman compete at improvising romantic verses.

Bamar Folk Music.name: Bamar Folk Music
Bamar Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the majority ethnic group of Myanmar.

Gondang.name: Gondang
Gondang.description_short: Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.

Harana.name: Harana
Harana.description_short: Hispanic-influenced lyrical courtship music traditionally sung by men, accompanied by guitar based on the [i]danza[/i] rhythm.

Hmong Folk Music.name: Hmong Folk Music
Hmong Folk Music.description_short: Folk traditions of the Hmong people, an ethnic group localized in Laos, Vietnam, China, and Thailand.

Khmer Folk Music.name: Khmer Folk Music
Khmer Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Khmer people, who mainly reside in Cambodia.

Kuda kepang.name: Kuda kepang
Kuda kepang.description_short: Accompanies a traditional Javanese dance of the same name, featuring a stripped-back version of a [Genre21370] ensemble that removes softer instruments.

Malay Folk Music.name: Malay Folk Music
Malay Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Malay people, who are native to Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, northern Indonesia, and southern Thailand.

Philippine Rondalla.name: Philippine Rondalla
Philippine Rondalla.description_short: Ensemble of plucked string instruments typically performed for traditional Filipino folk dances; known for its distinct sparkling and tinkling tremolo sound.

Tarawangsa.name: Tarawangsa
Tarawangsa.description_short: Sacred ceremonial music originating in the Rancakalong district, played with the [i]jentreng[i/] harp and the [i]tarawangsa[i/] bowed lute.

West Asian Folk Music.name: West Asian Folk Music
West Asian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of West Asia, a region that covers much of what is commonly known in English as the Middle East (alternatively Southwestern Asia), includes the distinct but interconnected traditions of numerous ethnic groups.

Alevi Folk Music.name: Alevi Folk Music
Alevi Folk Music.description_short: Anatolian folk pioneered by Turkish poets and bards, connected to the Alevist heterodox Islamic tradition.

Armenian Folk Music.name: Armenian Folk Music
Armenian Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.

Kef Music.name: Kef Music
Kef Music.description_short: Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.

Assyrian Folk Music.name: Assyrian Folk Music
Assyrian Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Assyrian or Syriac people, who are indigenous to the Upper Mesopotamian region roughly corresponding to ancient Assyria (which includes modern-day northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, northeastern Syria, and southeastern Turkey).

Israeli Folk Music.name: Israeli Folk Music
Israeli Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Jewish settlers of Eretz Yisra'el.

Luri Folk Music.name: Luri Folk Music
Luri Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Luri people of southwestern Iran.

Turkish Folk Music.name: Turkish Folk Music
Turkish Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music.name: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music.description_short: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.

Zeybek.name: Zeybek
Zeybek.description_short: [Genre10454] music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.

Work Song.name: Work Song
Work Song.description_short: Sung by laborers and prisoners while working in factories and fields.

Sea Shanty.name: Sea Shanty
Sea Shanty.description_short: Songs originally sung by sailors to coordinate work on ships.

Yodeling.name: Yodeling
Yodeling.description_short: Vocal technique that arose in many cultures around the world as a form of calling and communication.

Hip Hop.name: Hip Hop
Hip Hop.description_short: Emerged primarily on the United States east coast in African American communities in the late 1970s; emphasizes rhythmic beat patterns and a type of spoken vocal delivery known as rapping.

Abstract Hip Hop.name: Abstract Hip Hop
Abstract Hip Hop.description_short: Uses much more abstract lyricism than what is considered conventional within the genre, typically through use of metaphors, symbolism, and cryptic meanings.

Afroswing.name: Afroswing
Afroswing.description_short: Emerged in the United Kingdom during the mid-2010s, incorporating influences from [Genre302], [Genre33642], [Genre244], and a variety of [Genre35773].

Afro Trap.name: Afro Trap
Afro Trap.description_short: Centered mostly in France, features production influenced by modern styles developed in West and Central Africa with [Genre31066]-styled vocal flows.

Arabesque Rap.name: Arabesque Rap
Arabesque Rap.description_short: Emerged from Turkey in the late 2000s, based almost exclusively around [Genre20752] samples and featuring aggressive rap vocals.

Bongo Flava.name: Bongo Flava
Bongo Flava.description_short: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of [Genre231], [Genre572], and [Genre302] with native Tanzanian styles like [Genre21473] and [Genre31629].

Boom Bap.name: Boom Bap
Boom Bap.description_short: Production style identified by an acoustic-sounding drum pattern of a kick drum on the downbeat followed by a cracking snare on the upbeat.

Bounce.name: Bounce
Bounce.description_short: Developed in New Orleans in the early 1990s, initially defined by a slow to midtempo beat with a double-time hi-hat on top.

Chipmunk Soul.name: Chipmunk Soul
Chipmunk Soul.description_short: Sped-up vocal samples and slick, soulful production.

Chopped and Screwed.name: Chopped and Screwed
Chopped and Screwed.description_short: Remixing technique that consists of skipping effects ("chopping") and dropping the tempo ("screwing").

Christian Hip Hop.name: Christian Hip Hop
Christian Hip Hop.description_short: Employs lyrics with a pro-Christianity message to profess the performer's faith, often to attract attention from new potential converts.

Cloud Rap.name: Cloud Rap
Cloud Rap.description_short: Emerged in the early 2010s, known for its relaxed, dream-like, and reverb-heavy production style, taking influence from [Genre27390], and producers' obscure sample choices.

Comedy Rap.name: Comedy Rap
Comedy Rap.description_short: Primarily intended to be humorous, through the use of comedic lyrics, production, delivery, or other musical aspects.

Chap Hop.name: Chap Hop
Chap Hop.description_short: Satirises British cultural stereotypes with posh rapping and a distinctive retro aesthetic drawn from the "chap" and steampunk subcultures, often with elements of [Genre30962].

Conscious Hip Hop.name: Conscious Hip Hop
Conscious Hip Hop.description_short: Artists whose lyrics deal with social issues.

Country Rap.name: Country Rap
Country Rap.description_short: Combines the flow, production-emphasis, and demeanor of [Genre11] with the lyrical content and general approach of [Genre166].

Crunk.name: Crunk
Crunk.description_short: Originating from the southern United States and reliant on drum machines and synthesizer stabs to create an energetic, often dance-oriented sound.

Crunkcore.name: Crunkcore
Crunkcore.description_short: Combines rapping, screaming and autotune with synthesizers and [Genre11] beats often influenced by [Genre20].

Detroit Sound.name: Detroit Sound
Detroit Sound.description_short: Upbeat 808 percussion; simple, funky mallet instruments, keys, strings, and synth bass; and street-centric, often punched-in rapping.

Flint Sound.name: Flint Sound
Flint Sound.description_short: Uptempo and repetitive, featuring simple melodies, pitched-up snares, and humorous, punchline-heavy lyrics.

Philly Drill.name: Philly Drill
Philly Drill.description_short: Apocalyptic and haunting choirs, keys, and strings with gruesome narratives and slow, sparse drums.

Digicore.name: Digicore
Digicore.description_short: Developed in the late 2010s and characterized by frantic, bombastic, and glamourous production, usually derived from [Genre31066], that serves to accompany highly melodious, auto-tuned, and hi-pitched vocal performances, often done with breathy voice singing and sing-rapping.

Dirty South.name: Dirty South
Dirty South.description_short: Originated in the Southern US during the mid-1990s, defined by a bouncy rhythm, fast-tempo snares, 808s, heavy bass, and often rapped in a rhythmic delivery consisting of explicit lyrics.

Disco Rap.name: Disco Rap
Disco Rap.description_short: Most prevalent from 1979 to 1982, featuring MCs rapping over popular [Genre417] breaks.

Drill.name: Drill
Drill.description_short: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s; broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms coupled with gang-oriented, street-conscious, and violent lyrics.

Chicago Drill.name: Chicago Drill
Chicago Drill.description_short: Bass-heavy, dense, and typically syncopated percussion, featuring ticking hi-hats and gunshot-like snare rolls, usually accompanied by menacing synth melodies and violent [Genre109] lyricism.

Bop.name: Bop
Bop.description_short: Grew out of the [Genre54887] scene in the early 2010s, characterized by autotuned vocals and upbeat synth melodies.

Free Car Music.name: Free Car Music
Free Car Music.description_short: Chaotic and metallic percussion with clanging rides, rapid hi hat rolls, and tense kick buildups typically coupled with staggered, punched-in rapping.

Jersey Drill.name: Jersey Drill
Jersey Drill.description_short: Mixes [Genre36339] and [Genre35601] production, characterized by an energetic sound and distinct syncopated rhythms.

New York Drill.name: New York Drill
New York Drill.description_short: Emerged in the late 2010s, characterized by energetic, bouncy tresillo rhythms, creating a warmer, more booming tone than [genre41478], which prominently inspired it.

Sample Drill.name: Sample Drill
Sample Drill.description_short: Prominent, recognizable samples set to tresillo-styled [Genre36339] hi-hats and counter snares.

Sexy Drill.name: Sexy Drill
Sexy Drill.description_short: Emotive and sensual melodies, samples, and basslines set to driving stomps and bouncy [Genre36339] percussion typically joined by lyrical themes of sex, love, clubbing, and heartbreak.

UK Drill.name: UK Drill
UK Drill.description_short: Deep bass and complex rhythm which denotes a [Genre26] influence in the production.

Drumless.name: Drumless
Drumless.description_short: Stripped-down production style pioneered in the early 2010s and identified by a lack of drums or minimal, subtle percussion left untouched from the original sample or filtered out.

Emo Rap.name: Emo Rap
Emo Rap.description_short: Moody, melancholic production combining atmospheric [Genre31219], and [Genre31066]'s typical drum programming, with sampling from [Genre116], [Genre27516], [Genre25494], and [Genre280].

Experimental Hip Hop.name: Experimental Hip Hop
Experimental Hip Hop.description_short: Incorporates experimental and eccentric elements considered unconventional or unorthodox compared to more traditional hip hop.

Industrial Hip Hop.name: Industrial Hip Hop
Industrial Hip Hop.description_short: Incorporates harsh elements inspired by [Genre336] music such as blaring, noisy synths, distorted and metallic percussion, as well as more aggressive and off-kilter rapping styles.

Genge.name: Genge
Genge.description_short: Combines elements of [Genre302] with various traditions of Kenya.

Gengetone.name: Gengetone
Gengetone.description_short: Takes strong influence from [Genre590] and modern [Genre302], featuring more explicit lyrics and harder beats.

G-Funk.name: G-Funk
G-Funk.description_short: Relaxed and organic sound featuring live instrumentation, use of [Genre10482] samples, and high-pitched synth lines.

Hardcore Hip Hop.name: Hardcore Hip Hop
Hardcore Hip Hop.description_short: Confrontation and aggression, whether in the lyricism, vocal delivery, hard beats, heavy production, or any combination thereof.

Britcore.name: Britcore
Britcore.description_short: British subgenre from the late 1980s and early 1990s featuring fast breakbeats and rapping.

Mafioso Rap.name: Mafioso Rap
Mafioso Rap.description_short: Themed around organized crime, particularly the Mafia, often featuring cinematic production and lavish aesthetics.

Road Rap.name: Road Rap
Road Rap.description_short: Emerged in the mid 2000s from Brixton and Peckham featuring abrasive tones, prominent [Genre26] influence, and lyrics depicting circumstances of street gang violence in the UK.

Scam Rap.name: Scam Rap
Scam Rap.description_short: Lyrics that focus on various forms of fraudulent activities.

Horrorcore.name: Horrorcore
Horrorcore.description_short: Lyrical and aesthetic focus on the macabre and morbid, with production generally of a darker nature than is typically found in other [Genre11].

Memphis Rap.name: Memphis Rap
Memphis Rap.description_short: Minimalistic half-time drum machine programming with droning bass, often paired with aggressive rapping and a double time flow.

Dungeon Rap.name: Dungeon Rap
Dungeon Rap.description_short: Combines the dark production of [genre20720] with the fantasy aesthetics and sound design of [genre31103].

Phonk.name: Phonk
Phonk.description_short: Modernized, eclectic take on classic [Genre20720] production, featuring various influences from other [Genre11] genres, especially drum programming inspired by other [genre30] as well as frequent jazzy, funky elements somewhat akin to [Genre29] and from [genre82] music.

Mid-School Hip Hop.name: Mid-School Hip Hop
Mid-School Hip Hop.description_short: Based around heavy, stripped-down drum machine beats.

Trap Metal.name: Trap Metal
Trap Metal.description_short: Loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.

Hipco.name: Hipco
Hipco.description_short: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

Hyphy.name: Hyphy
Hyphy.description_short: Party-focused style with upbeat tempos, heavy bass and prominent synths, all underpinned by a distinctive West Coast-style rhythm, claps on beats 2 and 4, and a strong kick drum on beats 1, 2, and either 3 or 4.

Jerk Rap.name: Jerk Rap
Jerk Rap.description_short: Sparse beats, simple melodies, and party-centric lyrics geared towards a style of dance called “jerkin’.”

Instrumental Hip Hop.name: Instrumental Hip Hop
Instrumental Hip Hop.description_short: Can take the form of instrumental versions of songs that normally feature rapping, or hip hop originally released and always intended to be instrumental.

Rare Phonk.name: Rare Phonk
Rare Phonk.description_short: Primarily features eclectic sampling and lush, jazzy beats, usually set to [Genre31066] rhythms with prominent influences of [Genre20720].

Jazz Rap.name: Jazz Rap
Jazz Rap.description_short: Incorporates elements of [Genre6] through the use of samples or live instrumentation.

Jerk.name: Jerk
Jerk.description_short: Sparse, snare-heavy drum patterns loosely inspired by [Genre27204], which take major elements from other prominent 2010s and 2020s underground hip hop genres like [Genre46816].

Jersey Club Rap.name: Jersey Club Rap
Jersey Club Rap.description_short: Incorporates [Genre35601]'s distinct kick-heavy rhythms, which are modified to better suit rapping, featuring less sampling and more atmospheric production than earlier Jersey club.

Jigg.name: Jigg
Jigg.description_short: Club-oriented genre characterized by heavy 808-driven beats, imposing synthesized brasses and an uptempo rhythm.

Latin Rap.name: Latin Rap
Latin Rap.description_short: Primarily done in Spanish; incorporates [Genre519] elements into its sound.

Lo-Fi Hip Hop.name: Lo-Fi Hip Hop
Lo-Fi Hip Hop.description_short: Relaxed, laid-back form of [Genre11], typically instrumental and influenced by [Genre18] and [Genre10013].

Lowend.name: Lowend
Lowend.description_short: Rhythms driven by steady eighth-note digital handclaps, rattling bass, fast tempos, upbeat sound, and laid-back flows.

Mobb Music.name: Mobb Music
Mobb Music.description_short: San Francisco Bay Area production style building on slowed down [Genre255] (often utilizing live elements).

Motswako.name: Motswako
Motswako.description_short: Mainly rapped in a mixture of Setswana and English, incorporating additional languages and local South African and Botswanan influences, particularly [Genre20939].

Nerdcore Hip Hop.name: Nerdcore Hip Hop
Nerdcore Hip Hop.description_short: Themes touch on such nerd mainstays as science, computers, and science fiction.

Nervous Music.name: Nervous Music
Nervous Music.description_short: Dark, sinister and menacing sound, heavy sub-basses, simple melodies and slow, sparse and slamming drums.

Philly Club Rap.name: Philly Club Rap
Philly Club Rap.description_short: Mixes the fast and energetic production of [Genre43857] with similarly frantic and fast rapping.

Political Hip Hop.name: Political Hip Hop
Political Hip Hop.description_short: Features explicitly political lyrics and themes.

Pop Rap.name: Pop Rap
Pop Rap.description_short: Fuses [Genre11]'s rapping and production traits with [Genre36] elements such as melodious vocals and light, catchy tunes.

Frat Rap.name: Frat Rap
Frat Rap.description_short: Light-hearted and laid-back with lyrical focuses on subjects such as partying and college life.

Ratchet.name: Ratchet
Ratchet.description_short: Club-oriented style defined by a repeated synth melody and a sparse drum pattern often accompanied by a "hey" chant.

Snap.name: Snap
Snap.description_short: Prominent 808 bass and finger snaps, with lyrics primarily focused on nightclub topics (such as sex, drugs, and alcohol).

Trap.name: Trap
Trap.description_short: Originated in Atlanta in the early 2000s; distinctive fast hi-hat sound and heavy bass at moderate tempos.

New Jazz.name: New Jazz
New Jazz.description_short: Colorful, repetitive synths and synthetic instruments, playful vocal chops, and wonky bass selections set to bouncy [Genre31066] drums.

No Melody.name: No Melody
No Melody.description_short: Usage of minimalistic, repetitive midtempo drum patterns, and simple, prominent 808s.

Plugg.name: Plugg
Plugg.description_short: Use of sparse and compact drum and hi-hat patterns, subby 808s and heavy low end; commonly features piano samples, airy pads, and icy synths.

Ambient Plugg.name: Ambient Plugg
Ambient Plugg.description_short: Strong atmosphere and texture taken from [Genre84] music; featuring tight drums and minimal low-end and 808s.

Dark Plugg.name: Dark Plugg
Dark Plugg.description_short: Ominous, sinister synth pads and lead melodies, skittering hi-hats, and fast percussion and snare rolls.

PluggnB.name: PluggnB
PluggnB.description_short: Emphasizes more melodic and layered synth leads, denser and faster drum programming, and a lesser reliance on the laid-back, minimalistic atmosphere of earlier [Genre46816] styles.

Asian Rock.name: Asian Rock
Asian Rock.description_short: Dense [Genre52381] percussion in combination with airy bells, synth plucks, and soaring synthetic guitar leads.

Terror Plugg.name: Terror Plugg
Terror Plugg.description_short: Harsher and noisier, with 808s distorted to create a high-frequency sound.

Rage.name: Rage
Rage.description_short: Dense, buzzing synth work with repetitive chord progressions and melodic synth leads.

Regalia.name: Regalia
Regalia.description_short: Lush, sweeping string arrangements, dreamy piano passages, and other orchestral instrumentation set to cinematic [Genre31066] percussion.

Sigilkore.name: Sigilkore
Sigilkore.description_short: Dark and hyperactive production, featuring rapping laced with layers of effects.

Trap latino.name: Trap latino
Trap latino.description_short: Distinguished by its [Genre590] and [Genre532] roots, with smooth and moody production inspired by [Genre35856] and [Genre244].

Trap Soul.name: Trap Soul
Trap Soul.description_short: Mixes passionate vocals derived from [genre244] with laid-back, nocturnal and atmospheric [genre31066] production.

Tread.name: Tread
Tread.description_short: Icy or futuristic synths with busy and high-tempo drum programming using distinctive 808 patterns.

Trap shaabi.name: Trap shaabi
Trap shaabi.description_short: Combining [Genre31066] percussion and rhythms with Egyptian [Genre25623] and especially [Genre38606].

Turntablism.name: Turntablism
Turntablism.description_short: Manipulating and re-appropriating vinyl records using a turntable and DJ mixer in a [genre11] context, often featuring constant scratching and beat juggling between two or more recordings into original, distinctive tracks.

Industrial & Noise.name: Industrial & Noise
Industrial & Noise.description_short: Umbrella encompassing [Genre342] and [Genre336], as well as later derivatives that combine the latter aesthetics with other styles and in more accessible directions which fall under [Genre38714].

Post-Industrial.name: Post-Industrial
Post-Industrial.description_short: Umbrella group of genres that combine the dark, mechanical aesthetic of early [Genre336] music with more accessible genres, such as [Genre5] and [Genre31431].

Industrial Metal.name: Industrial Metal
Industrial Metal.description_short: Incorporates the abrasive and heavy sound of [Genre336] into [Genre137], using elements like synthesizers and drum machines.

Cyber Metal.name: Cyber Metal
Cyber Metal.description_short: Originated around 1999, influenced by [Genre337] and [Genre20845] with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.

Neue Deutsche Härte.name: Neue Deutsche Härte
Neue Deutsche Härte.description_short: [Genre491] and [Genre438] that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically [Genre31431].

Industrial Rock.name: Industrial Rock
Industrial Rock.description_short: Incorporates abrasive guitars and synthesizers inspired by [Genre336] and various [Genre38714] styles.

Martial Industrial.name: Martial Industrial
Martial Industrial.description_short: Incorporates elements of traditional European military marches with [Genre26102], [Genre245], [Genre336], and [Genre411].

Jazz.name: Jazz
Jazz.description_short: Originating in African American communities in the Southern United States around the turn of the 20th century, building on [Genre34407] ensemble and influences from [Genre328] and [Genre131] to become a very popular style by the emergence of [Genre624] in the 1930s.

Avant-Garde Jazz.name: Avant-Garde Jazz
Avant-Garde Jazz.description_short: Combines traditional or mainstream [Genre6] stylings with non-traditional techniques of avant-garde art music by experimenting with characteristics such as rhythm, harmony, structure, melody, and instrumentation.

Experimental Big Band.name: Experimental Big Band
Experimental Big Band.description_short: Dispensing with traditional [Genre6] structures and [Genre624] sounds, instead performing [Genre68] and pushing the boundaries of the medium.

Free Jazz.name: Free Jazz
Free Jazz.description_short: Attempts to break free from the conventions and patterns of earlier [Genre6] subgenres through the use of elements such as dissonance, atonality, and free-flowing rhythmic structures.

European Free Jazz.name: European Free Jazz
European Free Jazz.description_short: Arose in Europe in the late 1960s and early 1970s, moving even further from the [Genre6] tradition by often dropping the swinging rhythm, taking liberties with the use of atonality and noise.

Bebop.name: Bebop
Bebop.description_short: Fast tempos, improvisation, irregular melodic phrasing, and complex harmonies and chord structures.

Big Band.name: Big Band
Big Band.description_short: Commonly associated with the golden era of [Genre624] in the 1930s and 1940s, performed by a large ensemble including brass, woodwinds, and usually a rhythm section.

British Dance Band.name: British Dance Band
British Dance Band.description_short: Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on [Genre6] with the [Genre30962] tradition.

Bulawayo Jazz.name: Bulawayo Jazz
Bulawayo Jazz.description_short: Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.

Cape Jazz.name: Cape Jazz
Cape Jazz.description_short: Developed parallel to American [Genre6] in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.

Cartoon Music.name: Cartoon Music
Cartoon Music.description_short: Zany and uptempo; incorporated elements of [Genre183] and [Genre201] into frantic [Genre315] arrangements, playfully chaotic to match the on-screen actions of cartoon characters and the beat of their movements.

Chamber Jazz.name: Chamber Jazz
Chamber Jazz.description_short: Made by mostly small acoustic-based ensembles with emphasized improvisation and influenced by [Genre10315] and [Genre10448].

Cool Jazz.name: Cool Jazz
Cool Jazz.description_short: Developed in the late 1940s alongside and in response to [Genre69], featuring a more restrained, emotionally "cool" style.

Crime Jazz.name: Crime Jazz
Crime Jazz.description_short: Gritty, moody style that emerged in the mid-1950s to accompany film noir movies and hard-boiled detective/crime-themed TV shows.

Dark Jazz.name: Dark Jazz
Dark Jazz.description_short: Melancholic and gloomy [Genre20026]-inspired atmosphere and influence from [Genre53533] and [Genre245].

Dixieland.name: Dixieland
Dixieland.description_short: Developed in New Orleans in the 1910s, incorporating influences from [Genre328] and [Genre131] into cacophonous, polyphonic arrangements with instruments trading places between accompaniment and soloist.

ECM Style Jazz.name: ECM Style Jazz
ECM Style Jazz.description_short: Primarily associated with ECM Records, combining elements of [Genre75] with the subdued atmosphere of [Genre71] and the [Genre183] bent of [Genre317].

Flamenco Jazz.name: Flamenco Jazz
Flamenco Jazz.description_short: Combination of [Genre6] with [Genre20421], the contemporary style of [Genre10093], which was pioneered in the late 1960s.

Hard Bop.name: Hard Bop
Hard Bop.description_short: A continuation of [Genre69] that reintroduces more traditional African-American musical features, such as bluesy melodies, slow to medium tempos, and a more groove-oriented sound, while retaining the expressive improvisation.

Indo Jazz.name: Indo Jazz
Indo Jazz.description_short: Fuses the various musical traditions of the Indian subcontinent with jazzy musical structures.

Jazz Fusion.name: Jazz Fusion
Jazz Fusion.description_short: Near-universal usage of electric guitars and keyboards coupled with influences from genres such as [Genre5], [Genre231], [Genre255], and [Genre10448], and a relative degree of harmonic simplicity.

Jazz Poetry.name: Jazz Poetry
Jazz Poetry.description_short: Emerged in the 1920s, incorporating the style and rhythms of [Genre6] as both art forms spread throughout African-American communities in the United States.

Latin Jazz.name: Latin Jazz
Latin Jazz.description_short: Fusion with Latin American rhythms, especially those of African origin.

Afro-Cuban Jazz.name: Afro-Cuban Jazz
Afro-Cuban Jazz.description_short: Combines [Genre6] with the rhythms of Afro-Cuban music.

Samba-jazz.name: Samba-jazz
Samba-jazz.description_short: [Genre6] genre from Brazil that incorporates [Genre554] and/or [Genre526] elements.

Marabi.name: Marabi
Marabi.description_short: South African [Genre6] with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.

Kwela.name: Kwela
Kwela.description_short: Influenced by Zulu music, characterized by its happy melodies, played by pennywhistle flutes and accompanied by a banjo or a guitar.

Mbaqanga.name: Mbaqanga
Mbaqanga.description_short: Emerged from the traditional [Genre25080] [Genre6] and [Genre624] as well as [Genre25079] popular South African genres.

Modal Jazz.name: Modal Jazz
Modal Jazz.description_short: Utilizes musical modes as harmonic framework over traditionally used chord progressions.

Jazz Mugham.name: Jazz Mugham
Jazz Mugham.description_short: Combines [Genre6] with elements of [Genre51189], featuring jazz-inspired instrumental compositions, improvisations, wind and vocal elements, as well as modal scales and ornamentation techniques for emotional depth.

Post-Bop.name: Post-Bop
Post-Bop.description_short: Grew out of [Genre465] in the early to mid-1960s incorporating certain untraditional elements inspired largely in part from [Genre68], [Genre77] and eventually, [Genre468], such as non-diatonic chord progressions, irregular rhythms and amelodic forms.

Smooth Jazz.name: Smooth Jazz
Smooth Jazz.description_short: Simple melodies and slick production influenced by [Genre36] and [Genre31829].

Soul Jazz.name: Soul Jazz
Soul Jazz.description_short: Appeared during the 1950s when [Genre10014], [Genre231] and later [Genre235] started to influence the style of prolific [Genre6] musicians.

Spiritual Jazz.name: Spiritual Jazz
Spiritual Jazz.description_short: Emerged in the 1960s, marked by a mixture of [Genre6] with approximations of ethnic styles, religious music of non-Christian traditions, and the ecstatic, transcendental aspects of [Genre468].

Spy Music.name: Spy Music
Spy Music.description_short: Meant to evoke the action and drama of spy films.

Stride.name: Stride
Stride.description_short: Early form of [Genre328]-derived [Genre6] with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.

Swing.name: Swing
Swing.description_short: Distinctive rhythm and large backing rhythm section over which solos are performed.

Swing Revival.name: Swing Revival
Swing Revival.description_short: Born out of 1990s alternative music; sometimes incorporating elements from newer genres such as [Genre60], [Genre145], and [Genre160].

Third Stream.name: Third Stream
Third Stream.description_short: A fusion of [Genre6] and [Genre183], with improvisation as a vital component.

Vocal Jazz.name: Vocal Jazz
Vocal Jazz.description_short: Focused on vocals, generally using a more traditional, poppy strong structure and reducing the role of improvisation.

Vocalese.name: Vocalese
Vocalese.description_short: Newly written lyrics set to the melody of an existing instrumental solo, often in a [Genre69] or [Genre315] style, and characterized by syllabic phrasing.

Metal.name: Metal
Metal.description_short: Driving and distorted riffs, aggressive drumming, vigorous vocals, and an all-around show of brute force in its early days, since branching into dozens of subgenres.

Alternative Metal.name: Alternative Metal
Alternative Metal.description_short: Mid-tempo style emphasizing melodicism and rhythmic heaviness; branches outside of the stylistic conventions of [genre137].

Funk Metal.name: Funk Metal
Funk Metal.description_short: Melds [Genre407] grooves with slap basslines and metallic guitarwork.

Nu Metal.name: Nu Metal
Nu Metal.description_short: Emphasizes bouncy, drop-tuned riffs, alternating vocal styles, and genre-bending, often incorporating [Genre11] and [Genre440] elements.

Rap Metal.name: Rap Metal
Rap Metal.description_short: Features rapped vocals, typically formed around heavy, mid-tempo, and groove-oriented playing in addition to elements of [Genre11] beats such as record scratching.

Avant-Garde Metal.name: Avant-Garde Metal
Avant-Garde Metal.description_short: Often breaking the bounds of the genre through experimental structures and instrumentation, or by incorporating outside influences.

Black Metal.name: Black Metal
Black Metal.description_short: Highly distorted, treble-heavy guitars, tremolo-picked riffs, blast beats and double bass drumming, shrieked vocals, and raw, lo-fi production; often focuses on occult, dark imagery and atmosphere.

Atmospheric Black Metal.name: Atmospheric Black Metal
Atmospheric Black Metal.description_short: Repetitive riffs and melodies, slower tempos, synthesized ambient textures, and guitar effects creating atmospheric soundscapes.

Blackgaze.name: Blackgaze
Blackgaze.description_short: Fuses tremolo-picked riffing, intense drumming and harsh vocal techniques with mellow, dreamy textures, major-key melodies and extended build-ups.

Dissonant Black Metal.name: Dissonant Black Metal
Dissonant Black Metal.description_short: Dissonant atonal riffing, cleaner production style, and complex song structures.

DSBM.name: DSBM
DSBM.description_short: Lethargic, melancholic, and repetitive sound; depressive and misanthropic themes; vocals ranging from high-pitched wails and screams to strained cleans; often featuring non-distorted sections.

Hellenic Black Metal.name: Hellenic Black Metal
Hellenic Black Metal.description_short: Black metal scene in Greece with more mid-tempo songwriting and pronounced [Genre472] influence.

Melodic Black Metal.name: Melodic Black Metal
Melodic Black Metal.description_short: Cleaner production, more diverse arrangements, and a stronger emphasis on melody than is typical for [Genre189].

Pagan Black Metal.name: Pagan Black Metal
Pagan Black Metal.description_short: Incorporates acoustic guitar and traditional instrument passages, cleanly sung vocals, folk songs' melodies, and paganistic themes.

Symphonic Black Metal.name: Symphonic Black Metal
Symphonic Black Metal.description_short: Symphonic soundscapes, typically but not always synthesized.

War Metal.name: War Metal
War Metal.description_short: Aggressive, chaotic, and heavily [Genre138]-influenced, featuring muddy, bass-heavy production and often incorporating war-themed lyrics.

Death Metal.name: Death Metal
Death Metal.description_short: Heavily distorted, down-tuned guitars, palm-muted, tremolo-picked riffs, double-kick and blast beat percussion, chromatic chord progressions, minor keys, abrupt changes in tempo, and guttural vocals.

Brutal Death Metal.name: Brutal Death Metal
Brutal Death Metal.description_short: Emphasizes abrasiveness, chunky rhythmic atonal riffs, and low guttural vocals.

Slam Death Metal.name: Slam Death Metal
Slam Death Metal.description_short: Focuses on slow or midtempo (as well as breakdown-style) sections built on chromatic, palm-muted riffs - so-called "slams".

Death 'n' Roll.name: Death 'n' Roll
Death 'n' Roll.description_short: Incorporates a groove-oriented, [Genre67]-influenced approach while retaining heavily distorted rhythm guitars and gruff or occasionally growled vocals.

Deathgrind.name: Deathgrind
Deathgrind.description_short: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of [Genre482] with the technicality and low guttural vocals of [Genre138].

Melodic Death Metal.name: Melodic Death Metal
Melodic Death Metal.description_short: Utilizes the guitar harmonies and melodic focus of [Genre472] while generally retaining down-tuned, heavily distorted guitars and a harsh, aggressive sound.

Technical Death Metal.name: Technical Death Metal
Technical Death Metal.description_short: Focuses on challenging, demanding songwriting and instrumental skill.

Dissonant Death Metal.name: Dissonant Death Metal
Dissonant Death Metal.description_short: Emphasizes discordant, dense songwriting and utilizes pinch harmonics, scratchy guitar leads, and atonality.

Djent.name: Djent
Djent.description_short: Groovy polymeters, syncopated power chord chugs, palm-muted, distorted guitars, and significant focus on production and tone.

Thall.name: Thall
Thall.description_short: Utilizes rapid release bends and a precise playstyle while contrasting pitch-shifted high and low notes, with ambient sections for atmosphere and buildup.

Doom Metal.name: Doom Metal
Doom Metal.description_short: Plodding tempos, repeated chords, and thick, distorted, down-tuned guitars in a style focused on foreboding, atmosphere, and tension.

Death Doom Metal.name: Death Doom Metal
Death Doom Metal.description_short: Fuses down-tuned guitars, growled vocals, and aggressive, often double-kick drumming with a mournful, somber atmosphere and plodding tempos.

Funeral Doom Metal.name: Funeral Doom Metal
Funeral Doom Metal.description_short: Features exceptionally slow, funeral dirge-like tempos; crushing, sluggish guitars; mournful, melancholic atmosphere; and distant, hushed growls and grunts.

Traditional Doom Metal.name: Traditional Doom Metal
Traditional Doom Metal.description_short: Monotonous and heavy playing style; repetitive, rough, and sometimes atonal guitar riffs; a "rocking to sleep" bass; and influences from both [Genre156] and [Genre361].

Drone Metal.name: Drone Metal
Drone Metal.description_short: Extremely slow tempos, highly sustained, repetitive guitar notes, and minimalist song structures often omitting a traditional rhythm section and vocals.

Folk Metal.name: Folk Metal
Folk Metal.description_short: Features influences from various types of [Genre10448] expressed through melodies and/or traditional instrumentation, notably having a large scene in Europe.

Mittelalter-Metal.name: Mittelalter-Metal
Mittelalter-Metal.description_short: Emerged as a metallic style in the mid-to-late 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement.

Gothic Metal.name: Gothic Metal
Gothic Metal.description_short: Features heavy, low-mid tempo riffs, somber, gloomy atmosphere accentuated by ethereal keyboards and synthesizer layers, and vocal styles ranging from raspy growls to female operatic singing.

Grindcore.name: Grindcore
Grindcore.description_short: Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.

Cybergrind.name: Cybergrind
Cybergrind.description_short: Standard conventions of [Genre482] taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added [Genre82] dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.

Goregrind.name: Goregrind
Goregrind.description_short: [Genre138]-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.

Pornogrind.name: Pornogrind
Pornogrind.description_short: Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.

Mincecore.name: Mincecore
Mincecore.description_short: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on [genre38713] structures while including political and socially aware themes.

Noisegrind.name: Noisegrind
Noisegrind.description_short: [Genre342]-driven, defined by its rawness, feedback usage, and very brief song structures.

Groove Metal.name: Groove Metal
Groove Metal.description_short: Midtempo riffs influenced by [Genre140] but with a greater focus on rhythmic syncopation and heaviness over speed.

Heavy Metal.name: Heavy Metal

Rigsar.description_short: Dominant form of popular music in Bhutan which broke traditions to move towards a more Western and Indian approach.

Rumba catalana.name: Rumba catalana
Rumba catalana.description_short: Cheerful Catalan genre that takes influences from [Genre21309], Andalusian [Genre26259], and [Genre36].

Russian Chanson.name: Russian Chanson
Russian Chanson.description_short: Divided into lyrical and criminal chanson, it is best described as narrative-driven popular music inspired by crime and prison.

Schlager.name: Schlager
Schlager.description_short: Light, sentimental, melodic pop music common mainly in northern and central Europe.

Humppa.name: Humppa
Humppa.description_short: Finnish music related to [Genre6] and the foxtrot.

Levenslied.name: Levenslied
Levenslied.description_short: Dutch genre that enjoyed widespread popularity in the pre-[Genre55] era. with simple melody and rhythm and lyrics composed of couplets and refrains.

Volkstümliche Musik.name: Volkstümliche Musik
Volkstümliche Musik.description_short: Light [Genre36] with borrowings from [Genre39541] (volksmusik), often misleadingly labeled as being volksmusik.

Sertanejo romântico.name: Sertanejo romântico
Sertanejo romântico.description_short: Electric instrumentation and romantic lyrics, made popular nationwide during the mid-to-late 1980s.

Sertanejo universitário.name: Sertanejo universitário
Sertanejo universitário.description_short: Modernized style combining rural themes and acoustic instrumentation with commercial production and [Genre82] instrumentation.

Arrocha sertanejo.name: Arrocha sertanejo
Arrocha sertanejo.description_short: Merged the [genre43326] style with the younger audience creating a more energetic and more danceable rhythm.

Funknejo.name: Funknejo
Funknejo.description_short: Incorporates the rhythms, production, and idioms of [Genre21335] into the universitário genre.

Sophisti-Pop.name: Sophisti-Pop
