Sophisti-Pop.description_short: Incorporates influences from [Genre6], classic [Genre31829] and [Genre235] along with a slick, polished production style while retaining elements from its [Genre129] roots.

Soviet Estrada.name: Soviet Estrada
Soviet Estrada.description_short: Emerged in the USSR during the early 1930s, and encompassed the dominating popular music style composed by government-approved songwriters and the primary repertoire of professionally trained performers.

Sunshine Pop.name: Sunshine Pop
Sunshine Pop.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1960s, characterized by a cheerful or wistful sound, light, lush production, and prominent vocal harmonies.

Teen Pop.name: Teen Pop
Teen Pop.description_short: Oriented to teen audiences and almost always sung by teens.

Toytown Pop.name: Toytown Pop
Toytown Pop.description_short: Niche offshoot of British [Genre362] most popular in the late 1960s and early 70s; typically featuring strong influence from [Genre30962] and [Genre426], as well as the culture of Victorian and Edwardian Britain, and characterised by a whimsical, childlike atmosphere.

T-Pop.name: T-Pop
T-Pop.description_short: Mainstream [Genre36] from Thailand made popular since the early 1980s, predominantly sung in Central Thai dialect and featuring westernized compositions ranging within various styles.

Traditional Pop.name: Traditional Pop
Traditional Pop.description_short: Predominant form of Western commercial popular music in the pre-[Genre55] era, particularly in the USA and starting with [Genre55519]; typically vocal-oriented with an orchestral arrangement.

Romanţe.name: Romanţe
Romanţe.description_short: Expressive and poetic Romanian style, generally sung similar to a [Genre10046] and composed for piano and guitar orchestral arrangements.

Standards.name: Standards
Standards.description_short: Traditional compositions originating from the 1910s and onward which have become widely known, performed, and recorded across the world.

Tin Pan Alley.name: Tin Pan Alley
Tin Pan Alley.description_short: Early era of popular song in the USA, broadly from the 1890s-1930s; influences include [Genre328], [Genre10146], and [Genre58547].

Turkish Pop.name: Turkish Pop
Turkish Pop.description_short: Started in the late 1950s, when Turkish artists started to write their own lyrics to Western popular tunes.

Yé-yé.name: Yé-yé
Yé-yé.description_short: Upbeat, trendy [Genre36] that emerged in Southern Europe in the early 1960s, focusing on image and risqué lyrics.

Psychedelia.name: Psychedelia
Psychedelia.description_short: Umbrella of styles intended to replicate or enhance the altered state of consciousness brought on by the use of psychedelic drugs, originating in the 1960s.

Neo-Psychedelia.name: Neo-Psychedelia
Neo-Psychedelia.description_short: Developments in [Genre37294] since the early 1980s, building on the drug-inspired styles developed in the 1960s.

Baggy.name: Baggy
Baggy.description_short: Blends [Genre35195] and [Genre255]-based grooves with a laid-back, psychedelic atmosphere; frequently features jangly guitars, looping basslines, four-bar drum patterns, and a hypnotic, carefree feel that originated in the [Genre61009] scene of the late 1980s.

Dream Pop.name: Dream Pop
Dream Pop.description_short: Reverberated guitars, effects-laden vocals, and dense productions, creating a psychedelic, spacious, and dreamlike sound.

Hypnagogic Pop.name: Hypnagogic Pop
Hypnagogic Pop.description_short: 21st century style that refracts the pop culture of past decades through surreal, low-fidelity production and emulation of outdated media formats or equipment.

Space Rock Revival.name: Space Rock Revival
Space Rock Revival.description_short: Draws from the aesthetics and atmospheric soundscapes of [Genre81] combined with the more minimal, back-to-basics approach of the [Genre332] era.

Psychedelic Rock.name: Psychedelic Rock
Psychedelic Rock.description_short: [Genre5] which emerged in the mid-1960s that often attempts to emulate or enhance the effects of psychedelic drugs.

Acid Rock.name: Acid Rock
Acid Rock.description_short: Heavier with an emphasis on instrumental jamming and "wah" guitar effects.

Garage Psych.name: Garage Psych
Garage Psych.description_short: Emerged from mid-1960s US [Genre401]; characterised by fuzz guitars, cheap organs, experimentation with psychedelic effects and surreal lyricism, and a retained emphasis on raw energy and the pop song format.

Heavy Psych.name: Heavy Psych
Heavy Psych.description_short: Developed in the late 1960s with influence from [Genre156], such as heavy dependence on riffs and willingness to improvise, adding crushing levels of heaviness with thick fuzzy guitars to create a doomy and morose atmosphere.

Raga Rock.name: Raga Rock
Raga Rock.description_short: Influenced by [Genre622], featuring a droning compositional quality and commonly incorporating instruments like sitar, tambura, and tablas.

Space Rock.name: Space Rock
Space Rock.description_short: Heavy use of synthesizers and guitar effects to create dense atmospheric soundscapes intended to evoke images of outer space and science fiction scenarios.

Xian Psych.name: Xian Psych
Xian Psych.description_short: Portrays Christian and biblical themes through a surreal, transcendent atmosphere, occasionally drawing influence from [Genre10269].

Zamrock.name: Zamrock
Zamrock.description_short: Developed in the Copperbelt region of Zambia in the 1970s, characterized by its blend of local sounds with influence from [Genre255], [Genre67], and [Genre156].

Psychedelic Soul.name: Psychedelic Soul
Psychedelic Soul.description_short: [Genre235] which incorporates the effects and instrumentation of [Genre361].

Psychploitation.name: Psychploitation
Psychploitation.description_short: Short-lived genre seeking to capitalise on the popularity of [Genre37294] in the 1960s, featuring quickly and cheaply recorded material played by session musicians and put out by budget labels.

Stoner Rock.name: Stoner Rock
Stoner Rock.description_short: Psychedelic timbres, raw production, and stylistic influence from [Genre139] and [Genre10282].

Tropicália.name: Tropicália
Tropicália.description_short: Blends Brazilian popular styles with the influence of Anglo-American [genre37294]; emerged as part of Brazil's late-1960s counterculture.

Punk.name: Punk
Punk.description_short: Musical and cultural product of [Genre160] known for its simplistic, brash playstyle and anti-establishment themes.

Art Punk.name: Art Punk
Art Punk.description_short: Combines the stripped-down aggression of rudimentary [genre160] with frequent experimentation ranging from instrumental interplay, noise, dissonance, and/or influences from other genres such as [genre6] or [genre255].

Egg Punk.name: Egg Punk
Egg Punk.description_short: Originated in the early 2010s; features lo-fi production, eccentric lyrics, quick tempos, nasally vocals, and cheap keyboard sounds.

Cowpunk.name: Cowpunk
Cowpunk.description_short: Mixes together [Genre121], [Genre60], and [Genre209] with the familiar punk sound.

Emo.name: Emo
Emo.description_short: Focuses on emotional lyrics, expressive vocals, melodic songwriting, and dynamic song structures.

Emocore.name: Emocore
Emocore.description_short: Emerged primarily in Washington D.C. in 1985 as a reaction to the stagnant [Genre333] scene, with a less aggressive style that was more melodic and often featured emotional, introspective lyrics.

Emo-Pop.name: Emo-Pop
Emo-Pop.description_short: Mainstream derivative of [Genre48], puts more emphasis on the poppy sensibilities of [Genre116] and [Genre280].

Mall Screamo.name: Mall Screamo
Mall Screamo.description_short: Heavy instrumentation, melodic verse-chorus songwriting, and expressive singing contrasted with screaming vocals.

Midwest Emo.name: Midwest Emo
Midwest Emo.description_short: Characterized by shifts between loud and soft dynamics, off-key, strained and emotional vocals, sometimes with intricate instrumental arrangements and layered arpeggiated guitar parts.

Screamo.name: Screamo
Screamo.description_short: Intense, aggressive and complex approach to [Genre48] featuring higher levels of abrasiveness and dissonance, accompanied by guitar-focused melodicism and harsh vocals.

Emoviolence.name: Emoviolence
Emoviolence.description_short: Shorter length and volatile song structures, while borrowing techniques from [Genre648] such as blast beats, unconventional screaming and noisier sounds.

Folk Punk.name: Folk Punk
Folk Punk.description_short: Influenced by various forms of [Genre26677], including [Genre10448] as well as [Genre209] and [Genre66].

Gypsy Punk.name: Gypsy Punk
Gypsy Punk.description_short: Strong Eastern European influences, especially various kinds of [Genre21774] and [Genre10392] as well as [Genre10027].

Hardcore [Punk].name: Hardcore [Punk]
Hardcore [Punk].description_short: Broad genre which encompasses the first wave of [Genre333] beginning in the 1970s, as well as its derivative styles that incorporate diverse musical influences and stray away from the core [Genre160] sound.

Beatdown Hardcore.name: Beatdown Hardcore
Beatdown Hardcore.description_short: Heavy, urban-inspired and breakdown-oriented with strong relations to [Genre545].

Easycore.name: Easycore
Easycore.description_short: Combines the pop choruses, high-pitched vocals, and playful nature of [Genre280] with heavy, metallic breakdowns and occasional unclean vocals akin to [Genre545] and [Genre49].

Electronicore.name: Electronicore
Electronicore.description_short: Hybrid of [Genre545] and/or [Genre49] with various [Genre31431] styles, utilizing [Genre82] instrumentation and occasional [Genre35195] beats.

Hardcore Punk.name: Hardcore Punk
Hardcore Punk.description_short: Emerged in the late 1970s, often featuring extensive use of yelling or screaming, a stripped-down production style, and very short songs.

Burning Spirits.name: Burning Spirits
Burning Spirits.description_short: Emphasis on delivering a very energetic and triumphant sound with flashy and soaring [Genre137] solos, "melodramatic" or "uplifting" chord progressions, and singalong, over the top, harsh vocals.

Crust Punk.name: Crust Punk
Crust Punk.description_short: Metallic outgrowth of [Genre488] featuring a down-tuned, high-gain guitar sound, frequent [Genre503] drum patterns, guttural vocals, and politically-charged lyrics often featuring apocalyptic imagery.

Blackened Crust.name: Blackened Crust
Blackened Crust.description_short: Borrows heavily from [Genre189] production, blast beats, tremolo guitar, and vocals, while retaining the core [Genre335] sound, lyrical themes, and aesthetic.

Neocrust.name: Neocrust
Neocrust.description_short: Melodic, dark, and atmospheric style that often incorporates influences from [genre437], [genre41581], [genre189], and [genre496].

D-Beat.name: D-Beat
D-Beat.description_short: Emerged in the early 1980s, features [Genre137] influences, shouted vocals, and a distinct drum style known as the D-beat.

Melodic Hardcore.name: Melodic Hardcore
Melodic Hardcore.description_short: Emerged in the USA in the early to mid-1980s, placing emphasis on melodic vocals and technical guitar riffs rather than raw aggression.

Skacore.name: Skacore
Skacore.description_short: Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.

Crack Rock Steady.name: Crack Rock Steady
Crack Rock Steady.description_short: Incorporates elements of [genre335] and sometimes [Genre137], coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.

Street Punk.name: Street Punk
Street Punk.description_short: Driven by [Genre334] style group vocals, catchy melodies, and aggressive songwriting akin to [Genre160] of the 1970s fused with [Genre333] of the 1980s.

Thrashcore.name: Thrashcore
Thrashcore.description_short: Fast tempos, brief song structures, and the occasional use of blast beats.

Powerviolence.name: Powerviolence
Powerviolence.description_short: Originated from the West Coast California [Genre333] scene in the late 1980s, utilizing strong elements of [Genre405] and abrupt tempo changes.

Noisecore.name: Noisecore
Noisecore.description_short: Short blasts of riff-less, [Genre342]-driven music accompanied with chaotic drums and screamed vocals.

Post-Hardcore.name: Post-Hardcore
Post-Hardcore.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1980s from [Genre333] that expanded on its aggression and dynamics through longer and more complex arrangements.

Swancore.name: Swancore
Swancore.description_short: High-register clean vocals and technical instrumentation drawn from [Genre101] and [Genre97].

Sass.name: Sass
Sass.description_short: Emerged from [Genre49] in the early 2000s; characterized by sassy vocal styles and chaotic, erratic instrumentals.

Mod Revival.name: Mod Revival
Mod Revival.description_short: Late 1970s and early 1980s revival of [Genre126] fashion and music, featuring influence from the nascent [Genre160] scene.

Pigfuck.name: Pigfuck
Pigfuck.description_short: Sloppy, abrasive and feedback-laden riffing with vulgar and edgy lyricism, informed by [Genre49]'s aggression and [Genre332]'s rhythm section.

Post-Punk.name: Post-Punk
Post-Punk.description_short: Emerged alongside the initial [Genre160] explosion in the mid-to-late 1970s, putting a greater emphasis on frequent experimentation, atmosphere, generally stripped-back instrumentation and, at times, angular-sounding guitars, throbbing bass lines, and interlocked drumming.

Coldwave.name: Coldwave
Coldwave.description_short: Originated in Europe in the late 1970s and early 1980s and is known for its generally dark, gloomy atmosphere and heavy reliance on synthesizers.

Dance-Punk.name: Dance-Punk
Dance-Punk.description_short: Mixes the energy of [Genre160] with the danceable rhythms of [Genre255] and [Genre417].

Dance-Punk Revival.name: Dance-Punk Revival
Dance-Punk Revival.description_short: Punchy and danceable variant of [Genre33122] that features [Genre82] instrumentation and influence from [Genre418].

Gothic Rock.name: Gothic Rock
Gothic Rock.description_short: Combines drama and a dark atmosphere with effects-laden guitars, prominent basslines, propulsive drums, and occasional keyboards and drum machines.

Deathrock.name: Deathrock
Deathrock.description_short: More [Genre38713]-oriented offshoot of [Genre595] that emphasizes energy and an effect-laden sound over pure atmosphere.

Positive Punk.name: Positive Punk
Positive Punk.description_short: Early goth scene in London that grew out of the [Genre488] movement and promoted themes of virtue and mysticism; commonly features wailing vocals, screeching guitars, prominent basslines, and eclectic drum patterns.

Post-Punk Revival.name: Post-Punk Revival
Post-Punk Revival.description_short: Incorporating the sounds and aesthetics of [Genre332] into [Genre103], with jagged guitarwork, a dominant and danceable rhythm section, clean production, and poppy song structures.

Proto-Punk.name: Proto-Punk
Proto-Punk.description_short: Used to describe what influenced or in some way resembled [Genre160] before that genre's commercial breakthrough in 1976.

Punk Blues.name: Punk Blues
Punk Blues.description_short: Fusion of the instrumentation and scales of [Genre156] with [Genre38713].

Punk Rock.name: Punk Rock
Punk Rock.description_short: Fast tempos, loud and distorted riffs, simple songs, frequent use of power chords, and shouted vocals, originating in the mid-1970s in response to commercial, sentimental, and complex [Genre5].

Anarcho-Punk.name: Anarcho-Punk
Anarcho-Punk.description_short: Intentionally rougher and sloppier sound, with lyrics pertaining to anarchist ideology and sociopolitical injustices.

Deutschpunk.name: Deutschpunk
Deutschpunk.description_short: Partly a reaction to the commercialization of the German movement [Genre10170]; characterized by extreme speed, consciously basic songwriting, crude musicianship, and radical leftism.

Garage Punk.name: Garage Punk
Garage Punk.description_short: Combination of the raw fuzztones of the original [Genre401] bands of the 1960s with the tempo and attitude of [Genre160].

Glam Punk.name: Glam Punk
Glam Punk.description_short: Contrasts a snotty, nihilistic, and combative attitude of punk with theatrics and flamboyance.

Horror Punk.name: Horror Punk
Horror Punk.description_short: Thematically and lyrically derived from [Genre20017] movies, typically with a nostalgic and campy attitude.

Könsrock.name: Könsrock
Könsrock.description_short: Inspired by [Genre332] but with a more bizarre atmosphere with unusual or comic vocal techniques and a lyrical focus on the offensive and scatological.

Oi!.name: Oi!
Oi!.description_short: Rejection of perceived intellectualism and elitism in [genre332] and [genre452], characterized by a return to a straightforward, melodic [genre160] sound, sing-along choruses, and a lyrical focus on working class youth culture.

Pop Punk.name: Pop Punk
Pop Punk.description_short: Blends the loud, fast-paced, and sometimes sloppy sound of [Genre160] with the catchy sound and songwriting of [Genre36].

Seishun Punk.name: Seishun Punk
Seishun Punk.description_short: Short-lived Japanese style popular in the early 2000s, characterized by a raw and abrasive style, [Genre26677]-inspired songwriting, and youth-oriented straightforward lyrics.

Ska Punk.name: Ska Punk
Ska Punk.description_short: Up-tempo skank rhythms, catchy horn sections, and spirited guitar work; delivered with a fun and rebellious energy.

Skate Punk.name: Skate Punk
Skate Punk.description_short: Combines the speed of [Genre10020] with the catchiness of [Genre280], finding a middle ground between the two.

Vikingarock.name: Vikingarock
Vikingarock.description_short: Incorporates influences from [Genre10117] and the imagery of Viking romanticism and Norse mythology.

R&B.name: R&B
R&B.description_short: Umbrella of styles covering the most popular forms of Black American music from the late 1940s, when the term [Genre231] first appeared; includes the developments of [Genre235] and [Genre255] in the '60s and '70s, and the [Genre244] of the 1980s onward.

Acid Jazz.name: Acid Jazz
Acid Jazz.description_short: Eclectic scene consisting of influences from [Genre6], [Genre255], [Genre11], [Genre235], and various styles of [Genre35195] that gained popularity during the 1990s.

Beach Music.name: Beach Music
Beach Music.description_short: Danceable 4/4 "blues shuffle" rhythmic structure, vocal harmonies, and moderate tempos.

Contemporary R&B.name: Contemporary R&B
Contemporary R&B.description_short: Soulful, passionate and melismatic vocals originally derived from popular [Genre235] and [Genre417], and by smooth, lush and often synthezised production variously influenced by [Genre11], [Genre255], and related strands of [Genre36].

Alternative R&B.name: Alternative R&B
Alternative R&B.description_short: Deviating from the traditional styles of [Genre244] and featuring smooth, reverberated, [Genre82]-influenced production with heavy bass and often reverberated vocals.

Hip Hop Soul.name: Hip Hop Soul
Hip Hop Soul.description_short: [Genre11]-oriented style that evolved out of [Genre10318] in the early 1990s.

New Jack Swing.name: New Jack Swing
New Jack Swing.description_short: Mixes light [Genre11] & [Genre255] production techniques with [Genre244] vocals and melodies as well as swinging and danceable drum grooves.

UK Street Soul.name: UK Street Soul
UK Street Soul.description_short: Emerged in the late 1980s and early 1990s; combines raw basslines and breakbeats with [Genre244]/[Genre235] vocals.

Doo-Wop.name: Doo-Wop
Doo-Wop.description_short: Heavy emphasis on male four-part harmonies and light instrumentation; peaked in popularity in the 1950s.

Funk.name: Funk
Funk.description_short: Danceable, syncopated grooves carried by bass and drums alongside percussive guitar, keyboard, and/or horn parts, with rhythmic emphasis on the downbeat.

Afro-Funk.name: Afro-Funk
Afro-Funk.description_short: Strongly mixed with traditional and more modern genres in sub-Saharan West Africa.

Britfunk.name: Britfunk
Britfunk.description_short: Energetic, up-tempo style born out of late-1970s British [Genre10279] nightclubs.

Deep Funk.name: Deep Funk
Deep Funk.description_short: Focuses more on grooves and rhythm than songwriting.

Go-Go.name: Go-Go
Go-Go.description_short: Dominated by drums and percussion (primarily congas) with heavily syncopated rhythms, bursts of horns, and call-and-response vocals.

Bounce Beat.name: Bounce Beat
Bounce Beat.description_short: Modernized, youth oriented form heavily utilizing rototoms, timbale and keyboards for grooves.

P-Funk.name: P-Funk
P-Funk.description_short: Features a "fat", monotonic drum sound, spaced-out synthesizers, "squelchy" basslines, tight, syncopated horns, and sometimes heavy guitars.

Porn Groove.name: Porn Groove
Porn Groove.description_short: Primarily found in the soundtracks to [Genre20071] films of the 1970s; characterized by a wah-wah electric guitar sound, slapped basslines, and minimal drums.

Synth Funk.name: Synth Funk
Synth Funk.description_short: Stripped-down and futuristic, driven by synthesizer melodies and often incorporating drum machines.

Minneapolis Sound.name: Minneapolis Sound
Minneapolis Sound.description_short: Emerged in late 1970s Minneapolis, characterized by glossy [Genre244]-influenced production techniques, angular [Genre129]-inspired rhythms, and a larger emphasis on electric guitar layers.

New Orleans R&B.name: New Orleans R&B
New Orleans R&B.description_short: Increased rhythmic complexity with added focus on piano and horns.

Rhythm & Blues.name: Rhythm & Blues
Rhythm & Blues.description_short: Predominantly African American style that retains the defined backbeats, [genre131] chord progressions/melodies and passionate singing/shouting of [genre238], while appealing more to an urban audience with smaller bands and reduced [genre6] influence.

British Rhythm & Blues.name: British Rhythm & Blues
British Rhythm & Blues.description_short: A style infusing [Genre5] and [Genre31829] that was hugely popular in the United Kingdom between 1963 and 1966.

Swamp Pop.name: Swamp Pop
Swamp Pop.description_short: Uniquely Cajun style of [Genre231] distinguished by tripleted pianos and a slow [Genre131] structure.

Twist.name: Twist
Twist.description_short: Simple, fast, and energetic dance popular in the early 1960s.

West Side Sound.name: West Side Sound
West Side Sound.description_short: Created in the 1950s by working-class Mexican-American teenagers in San Antonio, Texas, as a result of significant stylistic cross-pollination and an accommodating racial climate; features prominent tenor sax sections and Hammond organs.

Soul.name: Soul
Soul.description_short: Originated in the African American culture of the 20th century, resulting from the combination of the ecstatic vocals of [Genre10014] with the upbeat instrumentation of [Genre231], consisting of guitar, bass and percussion.

Chicago Soul.name: Chicago Soul
Chicago Soul.description_short: Combination of the hard, groove-oriented rhythms of [Genre240] and the sophisticated gloss of the [Genre42751] which was developed in Chicago.

Country Soul.name: Country Soul
Country Soul.description_short: Combining the gritty horn-driven sound of [Genre240] with the textures and aesthetics of [Genre166].

Deep Soul.name: Deep Soul
Deep Soul.description_short: Draws on the typical [Genre240] groove and accentuates the [Genre10014] and [Genre131] influence, particularly [Genre291].

Neo-Soul.name: Neo-Soul
Neo-Soul.description_short: Emerged during the mid-to-late 1990s; defined by a combination of [Genre235] with the rhythmic percussion and groove of [Genre11].

Philly Soul.name: Philly Soul
Philly Soul.description_short: Defined by lush arrangements, often borrowing upon the orchestral instrumentation seen on productions from the 1960s, with the commercial atmosphere exemplified by [Genre242] and the [Genre42751].

Progressive Soul.name: Progressive Soul
Progressive Soul.description_short: Greater harmonic complexity, less conventional song structures, and conceptual, socially conscious or introspective lyrical themes, incorporating diverse influences and instrumentation from [Genre6], [Genre255], [Genre5], and beyond.

Smooth Soul.name: Smooth Soul
Smooth Soul.description_short: Slow tempo ballads with silky, often sensual, vocals and light, polished arrangements, creating an intimate, romantic atmosphere.

Southern Soul.name: Southern Soul
Southern Soul.description_short: [Genre235] primarily from the American South that was popular in the 1960s and 1970s, with a gritty and raw sound that places an emphasis on the groove, making it highly danceable.

Reggae / Ska / Dancehall.name: Reggae / Ska / Dancehall
Reggae / Ska / Dancehall.description_short: Umbrella for related forms of [Genre10229] which have grown beyond their regional roots to become global phenomena.

Dancehall.name: Dancehall
Dancehall.description_short: Developed from [Genre144] in the late 1970s, when [Genre148] became more stripped-down, with an increased emphasis on pure rhythm.

Digital Dancehall.name: Digital Dancehall
Digital Dancehall.description_short: First, pre-[Genre589] style of [Genre302] to popularize [Genre82] rhythms that arose in the mid-1980s.

Gommance.name: Gommance
Gommance.description_short: Emerged in Réunion, mixing Caribbean, African and Afro-Dutch influences.

Ragga.name: Ragga
Ragga.description_short: Hardcore style with a deejay (equivalent to an MC in [Genre11]) rapping over predominantly [Genre82] rhythms.

Shatta.name: Shatta
Shatta.description_short: French Caribbean [Genre302] subgenre with a focus on sparse percussion, heavy basslines and lyrics revolving around partying and sensuality, often in Creole.

Zess.name: Zess
Zess.description_short: Trinidadian style that originated in the country's slums in the late 2010s, defined by its sexual, violent, and occasionally gang-related lyrics and its influence from [Genre10305], as well as occasional influences from [Genre11] and [Genre21335].

Reggae.name: Reggae
Reggae.description_short: Developed in the 1960s; shuffling "bubble" and offbeat rhythms played on an organ, and staccato guitar and piano chords known as "skank."

Deejay.name: Deejay
Deejay.description_short: [Genre144] in which a deejay (similar to an MC in [Genre11]) talks or chants lyrics over a pre-recorded reggae rhythm.

Dub.name: Dub
Dub.description_short: Primarily instrumental [Genre144] which developed from the extensive use of studio techniques and effects like reverb and delay.

Lovers Rock.name: Lovers Rock
Lovers Rock.description_short: Smooth, quiet [Genre144] beats with lyrics focusing on romance and love.

Pacific Reggae.name: Pacific Reggae
Pacific Reggae.description_short: Developed in Pacific island communities, incorporating elements from local [Genre50665] styles.

Roots Reggae.name: Roots Reggae
Roots Reggae.description_short: Primarily defined through the political, spiritual, and socially conscious messages of its lyrics.

Dub Poetry.name: Dub Poetry
Dub Poetry.description_short: [genre141] with [genre150] and [genre144] backing rhythms, originating in Jamaica in the 1970s.

Seggae.name: Seggae
Seggae.description_short: Fusion of [Genre21700] and [Genre144], popular on Mauritius and other Mascarene Islands.

Skinhead Reggae.name: Skinhead Reggae
Skinhead Reggae.description_short: Early subgenre prominent from 1968 to 1971; known for its high tempos and driving rhythms compared with the more languid pace of most later styles.

Rocksteady.name: Rocksteady
Rocksteady.description_short: Jamaican popular music that blossomed briefly between 1966 and 1968 as an evolution of [Genre145], being slower, more relaxed, and soulful.

Ska.name: Ska
Ska.description_short: Originated in Jamaica in the late 1950s, characterized by a signature off-beat rhythm (referred to as the ‘skank’ rhythm), chop-style guitar work, busy bass lines and a use of horn sections.

2 Tone.name: 2 Tone
2 Tone.description_short: Combines 1960s [Genre21931] with [Genre160] and [Genre129] to create tracks played at faster tempos and with a harder edge than the original Jamaican records.

Jamaican Ska.name: Jamaican Ska
Jamaican Ska.description_short: Originated in Jamaica with groups who combined [Genre6] and [Genre231] with rhythms of traditional [Genre10164] like [Genre10245] and [Genre10154].

New Tone.name: New Tone
New Tone.description_short: Musically and socio-politically progressive movement noted for combatting prejudices and mixing together different styles of music, such as [Genre82], [Genre11], or [Genre48].

Spouge.name: Spouge
Spouge.description_short: Fusion of [Genre10154] and [Genre145] originating in Barbados during the 1960s and 70s.

Third Wave Ska.name: Third Wave Ska
Third Wave Ska.description_short: Expanded on the [Genre10222] period, adding further [Genre5] elements resulting in a heavier sound.

Regional Music.name: Regional Music
Regional Music.description_short: Music of regional cultural traditions, that is or was predominantly played and produced in these regions.

African Music.name: African Music
African Music.description_short: All forms with roots in Africa.

Cape Verdean Music.name: Cape Verdean Music
Cape Verdean Music.description_short: Music developed in the archipelago of Cape Verde.

Coladeira.name: Coladeira
Coladeira.description_short: Originated as a more uptempo and lively form of [Genre21471] before bringing in outside influences.

Funaná.name: Funaná
Funaná.description_short: Upbeat Cape Verdean style which developed on the island of Santiago, based around the diatonic accordion and rhythm provided by the ferrinho.

Morna.name: Morna
Morna.description_short: Slow tempo, monotonality, and the use of the violão, the Cape Verdean classical guitar, as the main instrumental accompaniment.

Central African Music.name: Central African Music
Central African Music.description_short: Music of the areas speaking Adamawa-Eastern languages and many Bantu languages, through most of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, all of Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, the islands of São Tomé and Príncipe, Republic of the Congo, most of the Central African Republic, and large parts of Cameroon, Angola, and the northern parts of Zambia.

Assiko.name: Assiko
Assiko.description_short: Music and dance of the Bassa people of southern Cameroon, which features a singer accompanied by a guitarist and improvised percussion.

Banda Music.name: Banda Music
Banda Music.description_short: Music of the Banda people, a Central African ethnic group mostly residing in the Central African Republic and its neighboring countries.

Bend-skin.name: Bend-skin
Bend-skin.description_short: Most closely linked to the Bamileke people of the Western Province of Cameroon; drums and improvised maracas are the sole instrumentation backing up a vocalist who alternates between rapping and singing.

Bikutsi.name: Bikutsi
Bikutsi.description_short: Developed from the [Genre10448] of the Ewondo people in Cameroon, with a name translating as "let's beat the earth" that comes from the stomping dance style that often accompanies it.

Congolese Rumba.name: Congolese Rumba
Congolese Rumba.description_short: Blend of Congolese musical elements with [genre32800] (specifically [genre21417] and  [genre21309]) popular between the 1940s and early 1970s.

Kalindula.name: Kalindula
Kalindula.description_short: Features multiple rumba-like lead guitars and quick steady basslines, while mixing together elements of other percussion-heavy Zambian styles.

Kizomba.name: Kizomba
Kizomba.description_short: Combines elements of Angolan [Genre25036] and French Caribbean [Genre10506].

Tarraxinha.name: Tarraxinha
Tarraxinha.description_short: Heavy-hitting beats and electronic bass, putting less emphasis on melodies and vocals.

Makossa.name: Makossa
Makossa.description_short: Similar to [Genre10087], but makes more use of a horn section and bass rhythm.

Mangambeu.name: Mangambeu
Mangambeu.description_short: Celebratory style featuring mbira-like instruments and polyrhythms, from western Cameroon.

Mbolé.name: Mbolé
Mbolé.description_short: Festive, energetic and urban, influenced by [Genre27118], [Genre27182] and [Genre25972]; mainly based on hand-clapping and drumming accompanied by rhythmic singing.

Puxa.name: Puxa
Puxa.description_short: Energetic dance style that combines solid bass lines with subtle melodies and harmonies of São Toméan music.

Semba.name: Semba
Semba.description_short: Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.

Soukous.name: Soukous
Soukous.description_short: Danceable, guitar-based style from the Congo area.

Kwassa kwassa.name: Kwassa kwassa
Kwassa kwassa.description_short: Faster form of [Genre10087] that was pioneered in the late 1980s and early 1990s, named after a popular dance.

Tradi-moderne congolais.name: Tradi-moderne congolais
Tradi-moderne congolais.description_short: Updates traditional Congolese music with electric instrumentation.

Twa Music.name: Twa Music
Twa Music.description_short: Music of the Great Lakes Twa people.

East African Music.name: East African Music
East African Music.description_short: Traditions which originate from the eastern subregion of the African continent, encompassing a wide variety of cultures and styles.

Acholi Music.name: Acholi Music
Acholi Music.description_short: Music of the Acholi people, who inhabit a region known as “Acholiland,” spanning parts of northern Uganda and southern South Sudan.

Baganda Music.name: Baganda Music
Baganda Music.description_short: Music of the Baganda people, a Bantu ethnic group indigenous to Uganda.

Kadongo kamu.name: Kadongo kamu
Kadongo kamu.description_short: Oldest form of mainstream music in Uganda, dating back to the early 1950s, translating to “one little guitar” from the Luganda language.

Mataali.name: Mataali
Mataali.description_short: Islamic praise genre of the Muslim community of Buganda, named after the frame drum on which the rhythm is played.

Benga.name: Benga
Benga.description_short: Kenyan popular music based around the [Genre10448] of the Luo people from the area.

Beni.name: Beni
Beni.description_short: Festive Zanzibari [Genre54112] music that emerged in the late 19th century.

Comorian Music.name: Comorian Music
Comorian Music.description_short: Music of the Comoros Islands and Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa, combining influences from other [Genre39268] and [Genre33355].

Dinka Music.name: Dinka Music
Dinka Music.description_short: Music of the Dinka people, the most populous ethnic group of South Sudan.

Gogo Music.name: Gogo Music
Gogo Music.description_short: Music of the Gogo People (Wagogo), who inhabit Central Tanzania.

Kapuka.name: Kapuka
Kapuka.description_short: Includes elements from [Genre11] and [Genre144], as well as Kenyan traditions.

Kidandali.name: Kidandali
Kidandali.description_short: Popular form of Ugandan music, originally derived from [genre52665] and [genre10087].

Kidumbak.name: Kidumbak
Kidumbak.description_short: Centered on two small [i]kidumbak[/i] drums, fiddle, and singer; closely related to [Genre21473].

Marrabenta.name: Marrabenta
Marrabenta.description_short: Fast, guitar driven, urban dance music from Mozambique that originated in Maputo in the 1950s, taking cues from Mozambican folk and a variety of foreign sounds.

Mchiriku.name: Mchiriku
Mchiriku.description_short: Pairs amplified keyboards with hectic, intricate percussion and vocals drawn from earlier Tanzanian styles.

Muziki wa dansi.name: Muziki wa dansi
Muziki wa dansi.description_short: Popular in Tanzania with strong connections to [Genre10087] and often associated with [Genre6], whose name means "dance music" in Swahili.

Omutibo.name: Omutibo
Omutibo.description_short: Mid-20th century Kenyan popular music which centres around a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.

Shilluk Music.name: Shilluk Music
Shilluk Music.description_short: All musical forms of the Shilluk people of the Upper Nile region of South Sudan.

Soga Music.name: Soga Music
Soga Music.description_short: Music of the Soga people, a Bantu ethnic group residing in Eastern Uganda.

Taarab.name: Taarab
Taarab.description_short: Prominent violin, qanun (an Egyptian zither-like instrument), and sung Swahili poetry, often accompanied by African drums and other percussion.

Timbila.name: Timbila
Timbila.description_short: Tradition of the Chopi people of the Inhambane province of Mozambique, named for the [i]mbila[/i], the wooden xylophone-like instrument on which it is played.

Salegy.name: Salegy
Salegy.description_short: Features rich, harmonized vocals and chiming guitar lines.

Tsapiky.name: Tsapiky
Tsapiky.description_short: Very fast and jerky rhythms, guitar duets, and polyharmonic chants.

Amazigh Music.name: Amazigh Music
Amazigh Music.description_short: Music of the Amazigh people, the indigenous people of Northwest Africa (with main hubs in Morocco and Algeria) and certain parts of West Africa.

Ahwash.name: Ahwash
Ahwash.description_short: Associated with the Tashelhit-speaking peoples of southern and central Morocco, and performed in large groups, combining singing, poetry and drumming.

Izlan.name: Izlan
Izlan.description_short: Uses sung poetry with a focus on love themes.

Kabyle Music.name: Kabyle Music
Kabyle Music.description_short: Music of the Kabyle Amazigh people.

Sahrawi Music.name: Sahrawi Music
Sahrawi Music.description_short: Music of the Sahrawi people, an ethnic group who inhabit the westernmost areas of the Sahara Desert.

Staïfi.name: Staïfi
Staïfi.description_short: Festive Chaoui genre that mixes local rural music with the zendali rhythm and modern instruments.

Tuareg Music.name: Tuareg Music
Tuareg Music.description_short: [Genre26710] by the nomadic Tuareg people who live through the Saharan desert in North Africa, encompassing various types of traditions and popular styles.

Takamba.name: Takamba
Takamba.description_short: Traditionally performed with a singer only accompanied by a guitar named tehardent, handclaps as percussion, and dancers; now usually performed by a band consisting of two tehardents, bass and solo, calabashes, a singer and dancers.

Tishoumaren.name: Tishoumaren
Tishoumaren.description_short: Electric guitar-led North African music emerging from traditional [Genre26533] in the 1980s.

Egyptian Music.name: Egyptian Music
Egyptian Music.description_short: Music of the people of Egypt.

Coptic Music.name: Coptic Music
Coptic Music.description_short: Church music specifically made for worship in the Coptic (Egyptian) Orthodox Church.

Shaabi.name: Shaabi
Shaabi.description_short: Developed in Egypt during the early 1970s, typically created by and for the urban working class with witty lyrics that reflect this.

Mahraganat.name: Mahraganat
Mahraganat.description_short: Draws elements from [Genre11], featuring auto-tuned vocals, rapping, [Genre82] production, and explicit lyrics.

Maghrebi Music.name: Maghrebi Music
Maghrebi Music.description_short: Western region of the Arab world, encompassing the modern countries of Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, and the disputed territory of Western Sahara.

Algerian Chaabi.name: Algerian Chaabi
Algerian Chaabi.description_short: Features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.

Banga.name: Banga
Banga.description_short: Sufi ritual trance music of southern Tunisia performed by Black communities.

Malhun.name: Malhun
Malhun.description_short: Moroccan sung poetry with instrumental accompaniment.

Moroccan Chaabi.name: Moroccan Chaabi
Moroccan Chaabi.description_short: Upbeat style of Moroccan popular music played in streets, cafés, weddings, and festivals.

Raï.name: Raï
Raï.description_short: Originated in Algeria in the 1920s as a form of [Genre56490], blending influences from various rural and urban genres.

Traditional Raï.name: Traditional Raï
Traditional Raï.description_short: Original folk of the popular Algerian [Genre573], combining various rural and cabaret styles with Bedouin rhythms.

Moorish Music.name: Moorish Music
Moorish Music.description_short: Music of the Moors, the largest ethnic group in Mauritania.

Afar Music.name: Afar Music
Afar Music.description_short: Music of the Afar people, who inhabit an area spanning parts of Ethiopia, Eritrea and Djibouti.

Beja Music.name: Beja Music
Beja Music.description_short: Music of the Beja people of Africa’s Eastern Desert region.

Ethiopic Music.name: Ethiopic Music
Ethiopic Music.description_short: Music made by people who speak Ethiopian Semitic languages.

Azmari.name: Azmari
Azmari.description_short: Ethiopian/Eritrean singer/songwriters or minstrels equivalent to the Western European bard, the West African [i]griot[/i] or the Romanian wandering [i]taraf[/i].

Ethiopian Church Music.name: Ethiopian Church Music
Ethiopian Church Music.description_short: Sacred tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, sung in an ancient Semitic language called Ge'ez and credited with assembling the current Ethiopian notation system.

Gurage Music.name: Gurage Music
Gurage Music.description_short: Music of the Gurage people of Central Ethiopia.

Manzuma.name: Manzuma
Manzuma.description_short: Melodic, devotional music performed by Sufi Islami communities in Ethiopia and neighboring countries

Tigrinya Music.name: Tigrinya Music
Tigrinya Music.description_short: Music of the Tigrinya, an ethnic group mainly found in Eritrea and Northern Ethiopia, the Tigray region more specifically.

Tizita.name: Tizita
Tizita.description_short: Melancholy song popular in Ethiopia and Eritrea, using the [i]qegnet[/i] mode and tuning system.

Nubian Music.name: Nubian Music
Nubian Music.description_short: Music of Nubia, a region centered along the Nile River in northern Sudan and southern Egypt.

Nuer Music.name: Nuer Music
Nuer Music.description_short: Music of the Nuer people of Eastern South Sudan and Western Ethiopia.

Oromo Music.name: Oromo Music
Oromo Music.description_short: Music of the Oromo people, a Cushitic ethnolinguistic group, who primarily live in the Oromia region of Ethiopia and Northern Kenya.

Somali Music.name: Somali Music
Somali Music.description_short: Music developed by the Somali people.

Belwo.name: Belwo
Belwo.description_short: Somali poems with themes of love and romance and brief, syncopated tunes.

Dhaanto.name: Dhaanto
Dhaanto.description_short: Song and dance that originally featured no instruments, but later transformed into a style featuring prominent rhythms and slow grooves.

Qaraami.name: Qaraami
Qaraami.description_short: Dates back to the 1940s and carries regional features such as the use of a pentatonic scale and having the oud as the primary instrument.

Seychelles & Mascarene Islands Music.name: Seychelles & Mascarene Islands Music
Seychelles & Mascarene Islands Music.description_short: Styles from La Réunion, Mauritius, Rodrigues, and Seychelles.

Maloya.name: Maloya
Maloya.description_short: Originated in slave communities on La Réunion; based on a call and response structure and use of traditional instruments.

Maloya élektrik.name: Maloya élektrik
Maloya élektrik.description_short: Prominent in La Réunion island from the 1970s until the 1990s; drew influences from [Genre255], [Genre37294], and [Genre572].

Santé engagé.name: Santé engagé
Santé engagé.description_short: Emerged in Mauritius in the 1970s, blending the popular [Genre21700] style with outside influences.

Séga.name: Séga
Séga.description_short: Mascarene Islands and Seychelles genre featuring a distinctive 6/8 rhythm.

Southern African Music.name: Southern African Music
Southern African Music.description_short: Encompasses [Genre32188] and more modern genres, consisting in a specific style of a worldwide popular genre mixed with or rooted in a local traditional folk genre, through South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Eswatini, Namibia, southern Angola, and Matabeleland region in southern Zimbabwe.

Famo.name: Famo
Famo.description_short: Popular and danceable style from Lesotho and the surrounding Sotho-speaking region of South Africa, often featuring the accordion as the lead instrument.

Isicathamiya.name: Isicathamiya
Isicathamiya.description_short: [Genre10163] Zulu style, which takes a softer, more melodious approach, in contrast to the powerful, loud sound of the earlier [Genre25306] style.

Jit.name: Jit
Jit.description_short: Guitar-driven electric pop from Zimbabwe that draws influence from Central and East African rumba, South African jive and local music.

Maskandi.name: Maskandi
Maskandi.description_short: Zulu style of music usually led by a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.

Mbube.name: Mbube
Mbube.description_short: [Genre10163] Zulu genre, performed in a powerful and loud manner by an all-male choir.

Shona Music.name: Shona Music
Shona Music.description_short: Music of the Shona people, a Bantu ethnic group who form a majority population in Zimbabwe.

Chimurenga.name: Chimurenga
Chimurenga.description_short: Popular style from Zimbabwe based on the traditional mbira thumb piano, but with electric instrumentation as well.

Shona Mbira Music.name: Shona Mbira Music
Shona Mbira Music.description_short: Traditional music based on cyclical patterns played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.

Sungura.name: Sungura
Sungura.description_short: Zimbabwean style combining the guitar work of [Genre10087] with the speed and texture of [Genre36655] and the strong bass of [Genre34262].

Township Jive.name: Township Jive
Township Jive.description_short: Originating in the townships of South Africa, similar to [Genre10231] but bringing in Western pop elements.

Tsonga Disco.name: Tsonga Disco
Tsonga Disco.description_short: Drum machines, synthesizers, and male vocals backed by a female choir, singing in a call and response style.

West African Music.name: West African Music
West African Music.description_short: Traditional and regional popular music from the Western portion of Sub-Saharan Africa.

Afrobeat.name: Afrobeat
Afrobeat.description_short: Merges West African styles such as traditional [Genre35745] and [Genre10089] with elements of [Genre255] and  [Genre6], typically resulting in extended improvisatory jams with call-and-response vocals.

Afro-Rock.name: Afro-Rock
Afro-Rock.description_short: Incorporates West African influences; initially emerged in the early 1970s.

Akan Music.name: Akan Music
Akan Music.description_short: Music of the Akan people of Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire, including a variety of traditional and neo-traditional styles which are based on some of the oldest traditions in West Africa.

Zoblazo.name: Zoblazo
Zoblazo.description_short: Ivorian dance music combining traditional instruments and synthesizers that emerged in the late 1980s.

Ewe Music.name: Ewe Music
Ewe Music.description_short: Music of the Ewe people, found in southern Togo, southeastern Ghana and southwestern Benin.

Agbadza.name: Agbadza
Agbadza.description_short: National dance-drumming tradition of the Ewe people in Ghana.

Agbekor.name: Agbekor
Agbekor.description_short: War dance of the Ewe people utilizing various percussive instruments and polyrhythms.

Fon Music.name: Fon Music
Fon Music.description_short: The traditions of the Fon people, originating in central and southeastern Benin as well as the southwestern region of Nigeria.

Tchink System.name: Tchink System
Tchink System.description_short: Urban version of [Genre35284] featuring traditional tchinkoumé rhythms, derived from zinli, and including contemporary instrumentation from the influence of [Genre31829], [Genre36] and [Genre5].

Fula Music.name: Fula Music
Fula Music.description_short: Music of the Fula, Fulani, or Fulɓe people, one of the largest ethnic groups in the Sahel region, present from the far West African countries of Senegal and Mauritania to Central African Cameroon with the biggest population located in Nigeria.

Griot Music.name: Griot Music
Griot Music.description_short: Type of hereditary professional caste in [Genre35773] culture that preserves tradition.

Gumbe.name: Gumbe
Gumbe.description_short: Vocal and percussive tradition from Guinea-Bissau developed in the 1970s as a fusion of various traditional genres in the country; sometimes used as a catch-all term for the music of Guinea-Bissau in general.

Hausa Music.name: Hausa Music
Hausa Music.description_short: Hausa are one of the largest ethnic groups in Africa, living mainly in northern Nigeria and southern Niger in west Africa.

Highlife.name: Highlife
Highlife.description_short: Originally began along the Ghanaian coast in the 1920s as a blend of western brass band instrumentation and rhythms with traditional [Genre34176] and [Genre33830].

Burger-Highlife.name: Burger-Highlife
Burger-Highlife.description_short: Created by Ghanaian immigrants to Germany in the late 1970s, generally employing synthesizers and Western post-production techniques alongside guitar-driven [Genre10089] instrumentation.

Igbo Music.name: Igbo Music
Igbo Music.description_short: Music of the Igbo people, who live mainly in a region of southeastern Nigeria often known as "Igboland".

Ogene Music.name: Ogene Music
Ogene Music.description_short: Traditional acoustic music performed by Igbo groups in southeastern Nigeria centered on call-and-response vocals alongside instrumentation from iron bells, wooden whistles, and jug drums.

Kru Music.name: Kru Music
Kru Music.description_short: Music of the Kru peoples indigenous to Liberia and Ivory Coast.

Alloukou.name: Alloukou
Alloukou.description_short: Created by the Bété people of Côte d'Ivoire, featuring a distinctive rhythm that uses polyrhythms and triplets.

Palm Wine Music.name: Palm Wine Music
Palm Wine Music.description_short: Fusion of the [Genre10517] of the region with imported Caribbean [Genre10154].

Ziglibithy.name: Ziglibithy
Ziglibithy.description_short: Ivorian mid-1970s dance music created after the country's independence, influenced by post-colonial trends in [Genre10505].

Mande Music.name: Mande Music
Mande Music.description_short: Encompasses the diverse forms of the Mande peoples, a group of West African ethnic groups who speak any of the Mande languages.

Mossi Music.name: Mossi Music
Mossi Music.description_short: Music of the Mossi people of Burkina Faso.

Songhai Music.name: Songhai Music
Songhai Music.description_short: Music of the Songhai people of Mali, who descend from the ancient Songhai Empire which once ruled most of interior West Africa.

Tradi-moderne ivoirien.name: Tradi-moderne ivoirien
Tradi-moderne ivoirien.description_short: Blends traditional Ivorian songs, rhythms and instruments with modern electric and electronic instruments.

Wassoulou.name: Wassoulou
Wassoulou.description_short: Traditionally sung by women and containing lyrics relating to women's issues such as childbearing and fertility.

Wolof Music.name: Wolof Music
Wolof Music.description_short: Music of the Wolof people of Senegal and The Gambia comprising a wide variety of [Genre35773] traditions influenced by nearby cultures.

Mbalax.name: Mbalax
Mbalax.description_short: Rooted in njuup, a Serer ritual tradition incorporating influences from Cuban, Congolese, and American popular music.

Tassu.name: Tassu
Tassu.description_short: Rhythmic poetry that has been a part of Senegalese culture since ancient times.

Yoruba Music.name: Yoruba Music
Yoruba Music.description_short: Music of the Yoruba people of southwestern Nigeria and Benin, comprising a variety of ancient and modern traditions crucial to [Genre35773].

Fuji.name: Fuji
Fuji.description_short: Combines the ajisaari/wéré tradition of improvisational music performed during Ramadan with other Islamic styles like [Genre25007] and sakara.

Jùjú.name: Jùjú
Jùjú.description_short: [Genre35745] that emerged during the 1920s in urban settings across Nigeria, especially in Lagos.

Santería Music.name: Santería Music
Santería Music.description_short: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

Waka.name: Waka
Waka.description_short: Islamic [Genre35745] originally rooted in Hausa traditions and adopted by the Yoruba in the early 19th century.

Yoruba Folk Opera.name: Yoruba Folk Opera
Yoruba Folk Opera.description_short: Musical play involving traditional and popular music.

Zouglou.name: Zouglou
Zouglou.description_short: Ivorian dance music that began in the early 1990s, with socially conscious lyrics and driving rhythms.

Ancient Music.name: Ancient Music
Ancient Music.description_short: Umbrella term encompassing all the genres coming after the [Genre31785] and before the Medieval music eras from ancient civilizations, roughly before 500 CE, following the [Genre183] point of view with the date of the Roman Empire fall (476 CE).

Ancient Chinese Music.name: Ancient Chinese Music
Ancient Chinese Music.description_short: Covers a very large era of creation from approximately 2100 BCE to 200 CE.

Mesopotamian Music.name: Mesopotamian Music
Mesopotamian Music.description_short: Music of Mesopotamia, a historical region situated in West Asia within the Tigris–Euphrates river system, comprises the heritage of Sumerians and Akkadians.

Arabic Music.name: Arabic Music
Arabic Music.description_short: Originating with and primarily performed by the Arab people.

Al-Jadīd.name: Al-Jadīd
Al-Jadīd.description_short: Modern Arabic music that emerged in the mid-20th century, blending traditional Arabic modes and vocal styles with Western harmonic, orchestral, and structural elements.

Bedouin Music.name: Bedouin Music
Bedouin Music.description_short: Music made by the Bedouin, nomadic Arab tribes that have historically inhabited desert regions all across the Arab world.

Samri.name: Samri
Samri.description_short: Traditional dance from Najd, Saudi Arabia, performed by two opposing rows of men who face each other, dancing and moving to the rhythm, in addition to a percussion ensemble.

Shilla.name: Shilla
Shilla.description_short: Traditional style of sung Nabati poetry, prevalent across the Arabian Peninsula.

Khaliji Music.name: Khaliji Music
Khaliji Music.description_short: Musical traditions of Eastern Arabia and the Persian Gulf region, roughly covering the Arabic-speaking people of the modern countries of the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Iraq, and Iran.

Shehhi Music.name: Shehhi Music
Shehhi Music.description_short: Musical traditions of the Shihuh, an Arabian tribe native to the United Arab Emirates and Oman.

Levantine Arabic Music.name: Levantine Arabic Music
Levantine Arabic Music.description_short: The musical traditions of the Levantine Arabs, roughly covering the Arabic people of the modern countries of Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, and Syria.

Dabke.name: Dabke
Dabke.description_short: Fast-paced dance and music style, most commonly performed in the Levant.

Druze Music.name: Druze Music
Druze Music.description_short: Musical traditions of the Druze people.

Orkes gambus.name: Orkes gambus
Orkes gambus.description_short: Indonesian songs based on Arabic hits, adapted for a small ensemble featuring the gambus lute, percussion, and electric instruments.

Zajal.name: Zajal
Zajal.description_short: Style of recited poetry found across the Arab world, notably written in colloquial dialects.

Asian Music.name: Asian Music
Asian Music.description_short: Rooted in the traditions of Asian peoples.

Buddhist Music.name: Buddhist Music
Buddhist Music.description_short: Encompassing the various musical practices that have developed throughout Buddhist history and across the many regions Buddhism spread to.

Beompae.name: Beompae
Beompae.description_short: Korean genre of Buddhist chants and songs performed by monks while celebrating religious rituals in temples.

Chöd.name: Chöd
Chöd.description_short: Tibetan Buddhist and Bönpo practice incorporating ritualized liturgical chants and instrumental accompaniment from the [i]chöd damaru[/i], [i]drilbu[/i], and [i]kangling[/i].

Central Asian Music.name: Central Asian Music
Central Asian Music.description_short: Music of the former Soviet Central Asian republics, Mongolia, Western China and related neighbouring peoples.

Altai Music.name: Altai Music
Altai Music.description_short: Music of the Altai people, an ethnic group who live in central Russia near the border of Mongolia and Kazakhstan.

Central Asian Throat Singing.name: Central Asian Throat Singing
Central Asian Throat Singing.description_short: Shared polyphonic vocal tradition of Mongolia and southern Siberia characterised by complex manipulation of harmonics.

Mongolian Throat Singing.name: Mongolian Throat Singing
Mongolian Throat Singing.description_short: Traditional music from Mongolia characterized by many throat singing techniques.

Tuvan Throat Singing.name: Tuvan Throat Singing
Tuvan Throat Singing.description_short: Traditional style of singing found in Tuva, an autonomous region of the Russian Federation situated in southern Siberia.

Karakalpak Traditional Music.name: Karakalpak Traditional Music
Karakalpak Traditional Music.description_short: Traditions of the Karakalpak people, located in northwestern Uzbekistan.

Khakas Traditional Music.name: Khakas Traditional Music
Khakas Traditional Music.description_short: Traditions of the Khakas Republic (part of the Russian Federation), a form of Turkic music related to the musics of neighboring Tuva, Altai and Mongolia.

Kyrgyz Traditional Music.name: Kyrgyz Traditional Music
Kyrgyz Traditional Music.description_short: Traditions of Kyrgyzstan, a mountainous nation in Central Asia.

Bogino duu.name: Bogino duu
Bogino duu.description_short: [Genre28307] with tuneful composition and simple structure.

Kalmyk Music.name: Kalmyk Music
Kalmyk Music.description_short: Music of the Kalmyks, a Mongol Buddhist ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Kalmykia, a federal subject of the Russian Federation.

Urtiin duu.name: Urtiin duu
Urtiin duu.description_short: Mongolian tradition in which sung syllables are extended into long, meditational, vibrato notes called shuranhai; accompanied by traditional Mongolian instruments such as the morin khuur and limbe.

Zohioliin duu.name: Zohioliin duu
Zohioliin duu.description_short: Mixes modern [Genre36] with [Genre28307], using local and western instruments.

Pamiri Music.name: Pamiri Music
Pamiri Music.description_short: Music of the Pamiri people native to the Badakhshan region in the Pamir Mountains.

Falak.name: Falak
Falak.description_short: Songs that reflect the state of living for those indigenous to the Pamir mountains ranges, often sung in high registers.

Tibetan Music.name: Tibetan Music
Tibetan Music.description_short: Traditional and modern music of the Tibetan peoples, mainly produced in Tibet and also practiced in Bhutan, Nepal, and northern India, and influential on the traditions of Burma.

Zhabdro gorgom.name: Zhabdro gorgom
Zhabdro gorgom.description_short: Lively, rhythmic and informal Bhutanese folk music of Tibetan origin.

Uyghur Music.name: Uyghur Music
Uyghur Music.description_short: Music of the Uyghur people native to Xinjiang in western China.

East Asian Music.name: East Asian Music
East Asian Music.description_short: Covers the different forms of music with origins in Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam.

Ainu Music.name: Ainu Music
Ainu Music.description_short: Music of the Ainu people from Hokkaidō, the Kuril Islands, and part of Sakhalin.

Upopo.name: Upopo
Upopo.description_short: Ainu everyday traditional song (as opposed to [Genre35006]'s sacred leanings).

Yukar.name: Yukar
Yukar.description_short: Oral literature pertaining to Ainu culture and mythology.

Chinese Music.name: Chinese Music
Chinese Music.description_short: Music of the Chinese people, which is primarily derived from the culture of the Han Chinese.

Chinese Opera.name: Chinese Opera
Chinese Opera.description_short: Traditional Chinese theatre, existing in several regional variations, combining traditional instruments and vocals along with other art forms like [Genre141], dance, acrobatics, and martial arts.

Henan Opera.name: Henan Opera
Henan Opera.description_short: Originated in the central Chinese province of Henan, known for its fast-paced, easy to understand dialogue, high pitched singing and strong rhythm.

Kunqu Opera.name: Kunqu Opera
Kunqu Opera.description_short: Old and influential style originating from Kunshan; known for its delicate symbolic gestures, graceful singing, and literary repertoire.

Peking Opera.name: Peking Opera
Peking Opera.description_short: Distinguishable from most types of Chinese opera by its instrumentation, 2 distinct types of melodies, and alternative Chinese pronunciation.

Korean Revolutionary Opera.name: Korean Revolutionary Opera
Korean Revolutionary Opera.description_short: Heavily influenced by Chinese [Genre51798] and supported by the North Korean government.

Revolutionary Opera.name: Revolutionary Opera
Revolutionary Opera.description_short: Popular during China's Cultural Revolution and upholds China's working class and the People's Liberation Army as the forces that brought socialism to China.

Shaoxing Opera.name: Shaoxing Opera
Shaoxing Opera.description_short: Exclusively performed by women in modern times with a focus on lyricism.

Yangzhou Opera.name: Yangzhou Opera
Yangzhou Opera.description_short: Originated in Yangzhou, and popular in some parts of Jiangsu and Anhui province, as well as Shanghai.

Quyi.name: Quyi
Quyi.description_short: Category of traditional Chinese storytelling, featuring a narrative structure and a combination of speaking and singing.

Shidaiqu.name: Shidaiqu
Shidaiqu.description_short: Fusion of Chinese popular music and [Genre6] that began in the 1920s in Shanghai.

Sizhu Music.name: Sizhu Music
Sizhu Music.description_short: Traditional string and wind instrument based chamber music ensembles, prevalent in Southern China.

Guangdong yinyue.name: Guangdong yinyue
Guangdong yinyue.description_short: Cantonese instrumental ensemble music played on varying stringed instruments, woodwinds and percussions; known for its bright tone, flowing melodies, and lively rhythms.

Nanyin.name: Nanyin
Nanyin.description_short: Long-lasting tradition originating from southern Fujian; known for its delicate aesthetic, slow tempo, ancient repertoire, and distinctive instrumentation.

Taoist Ritual Music.name: Taoist Ritual Music
Taoist Ritual Music.description_short: Originating in chants and instrumental accompaniment for Taoist ritual practice.

Zhongguo feng.name: Zhongguo feng
Zhongguo feng.description_short: Inspired by traditional elements of [genre46918] with lyrical themes constantly revolving around Chinese culture and tales.

Japanese Music.name: Japanese Music
Japanese Music.description_short: Japanese meta-genre covers all forms of music, traditional or contemporary, rooted in [Genre22229].

Eleki.name: Eleki
Eleki.description_short: Japanese [Genre80] that emerged during the early to mid-1960s, incorporating elements of [genre22229].

Enka.name: Enka
Enka.description_short: Evolved from [Genre26308] in the mid-1950s, based around the pentatonic scale and with a lyrical focus on expressive and emotional topics such as love, loss, loneliness, and death.

Ryūkōka.name: Ryūkōka
Ryūkōka.description_short: Uses elements of [Genre183], and adopts the legato style of singing.

Changjak gugak.name: Changjak gugak
Changjak gugak.description_short: Emerged in the mid-twentieth century as an attempt to preserve the sound of Korea's traditional music while adapting it to modern sensibilities and Western compositional norms.

Fusion Gugak.name: Fusion Gugak
Fusion Gugak.description_short: Traditional [genre28306] and [genre31619] combined with elements taken from contemporary styles of popular music and Western music.

Trot.name: Trot
Trot.description_short: Considered the oldest form of Korean pop, which derives its name from the foxtrot-inspired beat, and might be influenced by Japanese [Genre20930].

Ryukyuan Music.name: Ryukyuan Music
Ryukyuan Music.description_short: Music of the Ryukyuan people of the Ryukyu Islands in the southwest of Japan.

Okinawan Music.name: Okinawan Music
Okinawan Music.description_short: Music of the Okinawa Islands in Japan.

Bolero Việt Nam.name: Bolero Việt Nam
Bolero Việt Nam.description_short: Romantic Vietnamese popular music, originating from standards mixing Latin American [Genre10507] with local music.

Cải lương.name: Cải lương
Cải lương.description_short: Blends classical [Genre42536] with southern [Genre30426] and colonial French spoken melodrama.

Ca trù.name: Ca trù
Ca trù.description_short: Sung poetry from northern Vietnam, performed by a female vocalist to the accompaniment of a three-stringed lute and percussion.

Ngâm thơ.name: Ngâm thơ
Ngâm thơ.description_short: Vietnamese [Genre141] recitation backed by traditional instruments.

Nhạc đỏ.name: Nhạc đỏ
Nhạc đỏ.description_short: Vietnamese revolutionary music, which may contain elements of [Genre183], [Genre41522], and [Genre30426], and usually political and war-themed lyrics.

Nhạc tiền chiến.name: Nhạc tiền chiến
Nhạc tiền chiến.description_short: Popular music with romantic and poetic lyrics largely written between 1930s and 1940s.

Nhạc vàng.name: Nhạc vàng
Nhạc vàng.description_short: Made largely from the 1950s till the 1970s; introspective and sentimental lyrical themes.

Tân cổ giao duyên.name: Tân cổ giao duyên
Tân cổ giao duyên.description_short: Mixes the [i]vọng cổ[/i] musical structure with popular, non-traditional Vietnamese music.

Ghazal.name: Ghazal
Ghazal.description_short: Developed in Arabia with further evolutions in Persia and the Indian subcontinent; based on rhyming couplets with intricate schemes and deal with romance, loss, and religion.

North Asian Music.name: North Asian Music
North Asian Music.description_short: Music of the indigenous peoples of Siberia, the Russian Far East, and outlying islands.

Nivkh Music.name: Nivkh Music
Nivkh Music.description_short: Music of the Nivkh people inhabiting northern Sakhalin, the adjacent coast of the Russian Far East, and regions around the Amur River.

Sakha Traditional Music.name: Sakha Traditional Music
Sakha Traditional Music.description_short: Traditional music of Sakha (a.k.a. Yakut) people, mostly living in their homeland - Republic of Sakha (Yakutia) (part of Russian Federation).

South Asian Music.name: South Asian Music
South Asian Music.description_short: Traditional and modern regional music of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka, which culturally have close connections.

Adhunik geet.name: Adhunik geet
Adhunik geet.description_short: Nepali popular music which fuses elements of light [Genre10480], [Genre33485] and Western music.

Baila.name: Baila
Baila.description_short: Sri Lankan popular music and dance genre that is believed to have its origins in Afro-Portuguese performance traditions brought to Sri Lanka during the Portuguese occupation.

Bhajan.name: Bhajan
Bhajan.description_short: Song-based form of devotional music within Dharmic religions, with lyrical themes having an emphasis on deep adoration for a deity.

Bhangra.name: Bhangra
Bhangra.description_short: Percussion-driven blend of [Genre42535] with modern [Genre36], with its name coming from a traditional folk dance celebrating the harvest.

Folkhop.name: Folkhop
Folkhop.description_short: Influenced by [Genre11], including looped beats with [Genre10479] instrumentation and rapped vocals.

Dhol tasha.name: Dhol tasha
Dhol tasha.description_short: Energetic, dense rhythms played on the dhol and tasha drums, which the genre is named after.

Filmi.name: Filmi
Filmi.description_short: Music of films in the Indian subcontinent, representing the shared styles of the linguistically segregated industries in India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nepal.

Garba.name: Garba
Garba.description_short: Swinging rhythms and use of clapping/stomping; traditionally performed with the instruments dhol, dholak, tabla, harmonium, and naal, though newer productions can contain [Genre82] elements.

Ginan.name: Ginan
Ginan.description_short: Form of musical recitation sacred to Nizari Ismaili Muslims.

Sufi Rock.name: Sufi Rock
Sufi Rock.description_short: Pakistani subgenre rooted in Sufi tradition, featuring South Asian instruments like the dhol, tabla, and sitar within a [genre5] band format with lyrics and imagery inspired by traditional Sufi poets.

Vedic Chant.name: Vedic Chant
Vedic Chant.description_short: Sacred Hindu chants rooted in the ancient [i]Vedas[/i], and primarily recited as mantras, requiring strict precision and diligence.

Southeast Asian Music.name: Southeast Asian Music
Southeast Asian Music.description_short: Geographic meta-parent that covers different forms with origins in Burma, Cambodia, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, East Timor, Laos, Singapore, and Brunei.

Bamar Music.name: Bamar Music
Bamar Music.description_short: Music of the Bamar people, the majority ethnic group of Myanmar.

Mono.name: Mono
Mono.description_short: Employs Burmese melodies and modes of singing accompanied by Western instrumentation.

Hill Tribe Music.name: Hill Tribe Music
Hill Tribe Music.description_short: Music of the various ethnic groups residing in the hills of Mainland Southeast Asia and Southwest China, also known as the region of Zomia.

Lisu Music.name: Lisu Music
Lisu Music.description_short: Rooted in the traditions of the Lisu people, an ethnic minority of southern China, Myanmar, Thailand and Arunachal Pradesh, India.

Indonesian Music.name: Indonesian Music
Indonesian Music.description_short: Music of the Indonesian people, including those of the majority groups residing in Java, Sumatra, Kalimantan, Bali and other major native areas.

Kecak.name: Kecak
Kecak.description_short: Balinese dance-drama and its associated musical style, with a choir performing a polyrhythmic style of vocal music somewhat similar in structure to [Genre21370].

Batak Music.name: Batak Music
Batak Music.description_short: Music of the Batak people, an Austronesian people native to Sumatra.

Gambang kromong.name: Gambang kromong
Gambang kromong.description_short: Betawi traditional music which combines elements of [Genre21370], Western music and a Chinese-derived pentatonic scale.

Campursari.name: Campursari
Campursari.description_short: Javanese form of popular music originating as a mixture of local [genre21370] with Western elements.

Langgam Jawa.name: Langgam Jawa
Langgam Jawa.description_short: Solonese development of [Genre20867] using a [Genre28685] scale known as [i]pélog[/i].

Keroncong.name: Keroncong
Keroncong.description_short: Early form of popular [genre48085] from the 19th-20th century, inspired by Portuguese sailor songs brought to the archipelago during the colonial era.

Cilokaq.name: Cilokaq
Cilokaq.description_short: Sasak traditions from Lombok incorporating elements of Javanese [Genre20867], Balinese [Genre21370], and [Genre43109].

Qasidah modern.name: Qasidah modern
Qasidah modern.description_short: Islamic pop that emerged on the Indonesian island of Java during the 1970s, updating a form of classic Arabic [Genre141] known as "qasidah".

Rapai dabõih.name: Rapai dabõih
Rapai dabõih.description_short: Religious music meant to accompany the [i]dabõih[/i] ceremony of the Acehnese people.

Jaipongan.name: Jaipongan
Jaipongan.description_short: Sundanese performance music; uses instruments typical for [Genre21370] ensembles, but expands the drum section.

Ketuk tilu.name: Ketuk tilu
Ketuk tilu.description_short: Traditional village dance and its accompanying music, which is played by a small gong-chime ensemble and accompanied by a Sundanese singer.

Kliningan.name: Kliningan
Kliningan.description_short: Sundanese vocal music accompanied by [Genre21370] instrumentation, typically of the [i]gamelan saléndro[/i] variety.

Tanjidor.name: Tanjidor
Tanjidor.description_short: Betawi form of street music ensemble derived from colonial [genre54112]s.

Khmer Music.name: Khmer Music
Khmer Music.description_short: Music of the Khmer people, the majority ethnic group of Cambodia.

Kantruem.name: Kantruem
Kantruem.description_short: Form of fast-paced dance music played by the Khmer people of northeast Thailand.

Dikir barat.name: Dikir barat
Dikir barat.description_short: Vocal [Genre55079] that revolves around group singing, often for the purpose of competitions.

Dondang sayang.name: Dondang sayang
Dondang sayang.description_short: Typically performed by two vocalists of opposite gender, featuring a musical dialogue of Malay vocal poetry on topics of love and romance.

Molam.name: Molam
Molam.description_short: Native to Laos and the Isan region, wherein a singer is accompanied traditionally by a bamboo mouth organ called the khaen, nowadays mostly by larger ensembles.

Molam sing.name: Molam sing
Molam sing.description_short: Modernized form featuring a faster pace and mostly electric instrumentation.

Igorot Music.name: Igorot Music
Igorot Music.description_short: Traditions of the Igorot people of the Cordillera region in the northern Philippines, known for their gong ensembles.

Ilocano Music.name: Ilocano Music
Ilocano Music.description_short: Music by the Ilocano people, an ethnic group residing in the northwestern tip of Luzon.

Kundiman.name: Kundiman
Kundiman.description_short: Traditional Filipino love songs usually sung in Tagalog.

Pinoy Folk Rock.name: Pinoy Folk Rock
Pinoy Folk Rock.description_short: Typically sung in Tagalog and pioneered in the 1970s, incorporating elements of indigenous music such as [Genre27186] gong music and the [i]kubing[/i] bamboo jaw harp.

Luk krung.name: Luk krung
Luk krung.description_short: Ballads influenced by [Genre6] styles like [Genre624] and [Genre315], as well as [Genre519] infused with Thai melodic and rhythmic sensibilities.

Lilat.name: Lilat
Lilat.description_short: Unifies the danceable rhythms heard in [Genre30388], [Genre524], [i]foxtrot[/i] and [i]beguine[/i] into a Thai context.

Luk thung.name: Luk thung
Luk thung.description_short: Slow tempo and vibrato singing, featuring a fusion of traditional Thai instrumentation, rhythms, and melodies with influences from Japan, Indonesia, Latin America, and the United States.

Phleng phuea chiwit.name: Phleng phuea chiwit
Phleng phuea chiwit.description_short: Political Thai [Genre66] born out of the 1973 student uprising, with a name translating to "songs for life".

Wong shadow.name: Wong shadow
Wong shadow.description_short: Small, short-lived guitar [Genre36] movement in Thailand in the 1960s, fusing [Genre80]  with local melodies.

West Asian Music.name: West Asian Music
West Asian Music.description_short: Music of West Asia, a region covering most of what is commonly known as the Middle East but not extending into North Africa.

Armenian Church Music.name: Armenian Church Music
Armenian Church Music.description_short: One of the oldest branches of Christian culture, this is the predominantly vocal music of the Armenian Apostolic Church.

Azerbaijani Music.name: Azerbaijani Music
Azerbaijani Music.description_short: Music of the Azerbaijani people, who inhabit the modern day country of Azerbaijan, along with a significant population in the neighboring country of Iran.

Caucasian Music.name: Caucasian Music
Caucasian Music.description_short: Music of the region of the Caucasus, a mountainous region bordered by Russia to the north and Turkey/Iran to the south, with the Black and Caspian seas to its sides.

Karachay-Balkarian Music.name: Karachay-Balkarian Music
Karachay-Balkarian Music.description_short: Music of the Karachay and Balkar peoples of the Northwestern Caucasus, who reside in the republics of Karachay-Cherkessia and Kabardino-Balkaria.

Gilaki Music.name: Gilaki Music
Gilaki Music.description_short: Music of the Gilak people of northern Iran.

Kurdish Music.name: Kurdish Music
Kurdish Music.description_short: Traditional music of the Kurds, a distinct ethnic group inhabiting the region of Kurdistan, characterized by its mountainous terrain spanning southeastern Turkey, northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, and northeastern Syria.

Maftirim.name: Maftirim
Maftirim.description_short: Paraliturgical songs of Sephardi Jews who lived in Ottoman Empire.

Muzika mizrahit.name: Muzika mizrahit
Muzika mizrahit.description_short: Middle Eastern-flavored Israeli popular music, usually performed by Mizrahi Jews, and combining aspects of the music of the North African, Middle Eastern, and Central Asian countries from which they descended.

Muzikat dika'on.name: Muzikat dika'on
Muzikat dika'on.description_short: Depressing, somber lyrics and dramatic deliveries, more influenced by [Genre26050] and [Genre25757] in comparison to the lighthearted, playful, later varieties of [Genre20713].

Achomi Music.name: Achomi Music
Achomi Music.description_short: Musical traditions of the Achomi people, an Iranian people native to the Persian Gulf coast.

Bandari.name: Bandari
Bandari.description_short: Iranian dance music, often festive and energetic and set in 6/8, that traditionally makes primary use of Iranian bagpipes ([i]ney-anbān[/i]).

Koche bazari.name: Koche bazari
Koche bazari.description_short: Style of popular music that combines traditional elements of Iranian music with upbeat rhythms & instrumentation, humorous/socially relevant lyrics, and influence from [Genre25757].

Turkish Music.name: Turkish Music
Turkish Music.description_short: Traditions developed by the Turkish people.

Anatolian Rock.name: Anatolian Rock
Anatolian Rock.description_short: Incorporates elements of [Genre10454], particularly traditional instruments such as the bağlama and saz alongside traditional scales and melodies.

Arabesk.name: Arabesk
Arabesk.description_short: Arabic-style productions by Turkish musicians, who also draw influence from their native forms, including [Genre10454], [Genre31781], and [Genre10250].

Fantezi.name: Fantezi
Fantezi.description_short: Incorporates influences from [Genre20728] and [Genre10454] within a more accessible, commercial, and unorthodox context.

Ottoman Military Music.name: Ottoman Military Music
Ottoman Military Music.description_short: Considered the oldest military marching band in the world; instruments used are cymbals, trumpet, kös drum, kettle drum, naqareh, bells, and cevgen.

Özgün Müzik.name: Özgün Müzik
Özgün Müzik.description_short: Expansion of [Genre10454] with overtones from contemporary genres.

Austronesian Music.name: Austronesian Music
Austronesian Music.description_short: Music developed by Austronesian ethnic groups.

Pakacaping Music.name: Pakacaping Music
Pakacaping Music.description_short: Traditional genres of music found among the ethnicities of Indonesian archipelago, particularly on South Sulawesi, Borneo and North Sumatra.

Vude.name: Vude
Vude.description_short: Blends traditional local music with elements of [Genre417], [Genre166] and [Genre5].

Hawaiian Music.name: Hawaiian Music
Hawaiian Music.description_short: Includes a variety of syncopated rhythms, percussion and vocal styles, including chanting ([i]mele[/i]) and falsetto.

Hapa haole.name: Hapa haole
Hapa haole.description_short: Hawaiian musical traditions adapted to popular American [Genre6] and [Genre36] styles.

Slack-Key Guitar.name: Slack-Key Guitar
Slack-Key Guitar.description_short: Originated in Hawaii and typically played with one's thumb in an alternating-bass pattern on the lower two or three strings.
