Himene tarava.name: Himene tarava
Himene tarava.description_short: Protestant choral songs in Tahiti and other southern Polynesian islands.

Māori Music.name: Māori Music
Māori Music.description_short: Music of the indigenous Māori people of New Zealand.

Caribbean Music.name: Caribbean Music
Caribbean Music.description_short: Meta-genre covering all forms with roots in the Caribbean region.

Aleke.name: Aleke
Aleke.description_short: Derived from traditional Surinamese Maroon music, especially [i]aukansi[/i], features distinct faster rhythms.

Bachata.name: Bachata
Bachata.description_short: Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.

Brukdown.name: Brukdown
Brukdown.description_short: Belizean Creole genre typified by the use of accordion, banjo, and a distinctive percussion section.

Bullerengue.name: Bullerengue
Bullerengue.description_short: Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.

Calypso.name: Calypso
Calypso.description_short: Genre from Trinidad and Tobago featuring a brass section and percussion.

Calipso venezolano.name: Calipso venezolano
Calipso venezolano.description_short: Derived from Trinidadian [genre10154], popular in the eastern region of Venezuela and associated with Carnival.

Champeta.name: Champeta
Champeta.description_short: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

Cuban Music.name: Cuban Music
Cuban Music.description_short: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

Changüí.name: Changüí
Changüí.description_short: One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.

Conga.name: Conga
Conga.description_short: Evolved alongside [Genre21309] in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.

Cuban Charanga.name: Cuban Charanga
Cuban Charanga.description_short: Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by [Genre21417] but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.

Cubaton.name: Cubaton
Cubaton.description_short: Rhythmically and vocally inspired by major elements of [Genre32800].

Reparto.name: Reparto
Reparto.description_short: Incorporating [Genre32800] elements, resulting in dynamic rhythms and a sound palette that typically features  [Genre524]-like guitar picking.

Danzón.name: Danzón
Danzón.description_short: Development on [Genre20753] in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

Descarga.name: Descarga
Descarga.description_short: Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of [Genre6] and Afro-Cuban music.

Filin.name: Filin
Filin.description_short: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of [Genre227].

Guajira.name: Guajira
Guajira.description_short: Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by [Genre30625].

Guaracha.name: Guaracha
Guaracha.description_short: Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.

Habanera.name: Habanera
Habanera.description_short: Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.

Mambo.name: Mambo
Mambo.description_short: Dance-oriented evolution from [Genre33259] during the late 1930s.

Mozambique.name: Mozambique
Mozambique.description_short: Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.

Pachanga.name: Pachanga
Pachanga.description_short: Combination of [Genre10299], [Genre33267], [Genre21309], and [Genre10047]; fast, festive, and playful.

Pilón.name: Pilón
Pilón.description_short: Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.

Rumba cubana.name: Rumba cubana
Rumba cubana.description_short: Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.

Guaguancó.name: Guaguancó
Guaguancó.description_short: Emerged after the abolition of slavery in Cuba in 1886; usually features a lead singer, accompanied by three large drums, known as tumbadoras or congas, and a call-and-response chorus.

Son cubano.name: Son cubano
Son cubano.description_short: Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.

Bolero son.name: Bolero son
Bolero son.description_short: Blend of [Genre10507] and [Genre21417] that appeared during the 1920s.

Son montuno.name: Son montuno
Son montuno.description_short: Developed in the 1940s, characterized by more elaborate instrumental arrangements and larger ensembles typically adding a horn section, conga drums, and piano.

Songo.name: Songo
Songo.description_short: Cuban style originating in the late 1960s, combining elements from [Genre21309] and [Genre21417] with [Genre6] and [Genre255].

Timba.name: Timba
Timba.description_short: Combines [Genre524] with other genres such as [Genre11], [Genre417], [Genre255], [Genre6] and [Genre5].

Trova.name: Trova
Trova.description_short: One of the most ancient expressions of [Genre32800], based around lone singer/songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.

Nueva trova.name: Nueva trova
Nueva trova.description_short: Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original [Genre33509].

Tumba francesa.name: Tumba francesa
Tumba francesa.description_short: Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.

Cumbia colombiana.name: Cumbia colombiana
Cumbia colombiana.description_short: Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

Dembow.name: Dembow
Dembow.description_short: Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to [Genre11] and a style drawing on [Genre302], particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.

French Caribbean Music.name: French Caribbean Music
French Caribbean Music.description_short: Music from the French Antilles (Martinique, Guadeloupe, Dominica, Saint Lucia) and from Haiti.

Biguine.name: Biguine
Biguine.description_short: Dating back to the 19th century; originating as a fusion of traditional [Genre53342] music with [Genre10136].

Bouyon.name: Bouyon
Bouyon.description_short: With a name translating to "broth", this fast-paced genre from Dominica originated as a blend of various traditional and modern Caribbean styles.

Cadence lypso.name: Cadence lypso
Cadence lypso.description_short: Caribbean genre originating in the 1970s, combining elements of Haiti's [Genre31171] and [Genre20729] with Trinidad's [Genre10154].

Dennery Segment.name: Dennery Segment
Dennery Segment.description_short: Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan [Genre21264], as well as incorporating elements of [Genre10506] and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).

Gwo ka.name: Gwo ka
Gwo ka.description_short: Developed in the island of Guadeloupe; driven by a group of gwo ka drums.

Haitian Music.name: Haitian Music
Haitian Music.description_short: Encompasses the styles of music developed by the Haitian people.

Cadence rampa.name: Cadence rampa
Cadence rampa.description_short: Developed in parallel with [Genre20729], based on [Genre31351] with a stronger Cuban influence.

Compas.name: Compas
Compas.description_short: Popular genre from Haiti, updating the older [Genre31351] style with influences from [Genre521] and [Genre6].

Rabòday.name: Rabòday
Rabòday.description_short: Fast-paced rhythm inspired by [Genre31332], with [Genre82] instrumentation and humorous sexual and political lyrics.

Rara.name: Rara
Rara.description_short: Derived from the [genre54151] tradition, often played at street festivals and carnivals and usually having celebratory or political lyrics.

Rasin.name: Rasin
Rasin.description_short: Blends the highly rhythmic drumming of traditional Haitian [i]Vodou[/i] music with [Genre5]-influenced electric instrumentation such as guitar, keyboard, and bass.

Twoubadou.name: Twoubadou
Twoubadou.description_short: Pastoral, often satirical Haitian style usually performed by small groups centered around the acoustic guitar.

Tumbélé.name: Tumbélé
Tumbélé.description_short: Combines Haitian [Genre20729], [Genre10087] and Cuban [Genre27810] with the local style of [Genre31208].

Zouk.name: Zouk
Zouk.description_short: Fast-paced danceable pop that began in early 1980s French Antilles, merging and updating more traditional local genres.

Cabo-Zouk.name: Cabo-Zouk
Cabo-Zouk.description_short: Popular in Cape Verde and the Cape Verdean diaspora in Europe and North America, with a slow and sensuous tempo, and favoring more sophisticated studio productions.

Zouk Love.name: Zouk Love
Zouk Love.description_short: More sentimental form of [Genre10506] which emerged in the mid-1980s.

Goombay.name: Goombay
Goombay.description_short: Bahamian music centered around the drum known as the goombay, a sort of membranophone.

Baithak gana.name: Baithak gana
Baithak gana.description_short: Indo-Caribbean genre from Suriname, consisting of [Genre42812] with local Caribbean influence.

Chutney.name: Chutney
Chutney.description_short: Indo-Caribbean genre developing as a fusion of [genre42812] with traditional Caribbean songs; later influenced by [genre10154], [genre10305] and [genre582].

Chutney Soca.name: Chutney Soca
Chutney Soca.description_short: Mixture of [genre10305] rhythms with [genre27736]'s Indo-Caribbean traits and instrumentation.

Tassa.name: Tassa
Tassa.description_short: Drum ensemble descended from a mixture of northern Indian drumming traditions.

Jamaican Music.name: Jamaican Music
Jamaican Music.description_short: Regional music of Jamaica ranges from its cultural origins in traditional and religious folk of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the international popularity of [Genre144] from the 1970s onwards.

Nyahbinghi.name: Nyahbinghi
Nyahbinghi.description_short: Performed at Rastafari religious ceremonies, consisting of tripartite hand-drumming and often accompanied by vocal chants.

Junkanoo.name: Junkanoo
Junkanoo.description_short: Highly rhythmic Bahamian style which traditionally accompanies the arts festival and street parade of the same name.

Kaseko.name: Kaseko
Kaseko.description_short: Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

Merengue.name: Merengue
Merengue.description_short: Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.

Mambo urbano.name: Mambo urbano
Mambo urbano.description_short: Rhythmically simpler and more eclectic style, absorbing influences from [Genre11], [Genre590], and other modern genres, particularly in regards to vocals.

Merenhouse.name: Merenhouse
Merenhouse.description_short: Popularized by Dominican-American artists of the 1990s, blending modern [genre10299] with electronic instrumentation and the combination of rapping/singing vocals.

Tecnomerengue.name: Tecnomerengue
Tecnomerengue.description_short: Fuses basic [genre10299] rhythms with influences from [genre10047] and [genre21316], being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.

Palo de mayo.name: Palo de mayo
Palo de mayo.description_short: Upbeat music accompanying maypole dancing from the Caribbean coast of Central America.

Parang.name: Parang
Parang.description_short: Latin-Caribbean genre central to Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela traditionally used for nighttime celebrations in Trinidadian towns.

Porro.name: Porro
Porro.description_short: Lively [Genre519] and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

Punta.name: Punta
Punta.description_short: Garifuna music with influences from other Caribbean genres such as [Genre144], [Genre10305], and [Genre10506], as well as [Genre519].

Soca.name: Soca
Soca.description_short: Upbeat, poppy and danceable style rooted in [genre10154] and [genre55057]; developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s in Trinidad and Tobago.

Bashment Soca.name: Bashment Soca
Bashment Soca.description_short: Highly energetic, [Genre302]-influenced form of [Genre10305] developed in Barbados featuring dancefloor-oriented lyrics delivered in an aggressive chanting style.

Power Soca.name: Power Soca
Power Soca.description_short: Often at a tempo of 160 BPM and incorporating hard, frantic rhythms, highly synthesized production, and call-and-response vocals.

Rapso.name: Rapso
Rapso.description_short: Fusion of [Genre10305] and [Genre11] unique to Trinidad and Tobago.

Steel Band.name: Steel Band
Steel Band.description_short: Ensembles made out of steel drums that often perform [Genre424,pop standards], [Genre10154, calypsos], and [Genre183,western classical music] with densely rhythmic and colorful arrangements.

Tropicanibalismo.name: Tropicanibalismo
Tropicanibalismo.description_short: Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.

Vallenato.name: Vallenato
Vallenato.description_short: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.

Central American Music.name: Central American Music
Central American Music.description_short: Music from the Central American region (including Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama).

Tamborera.name: Tamborera
Tamborera.description_short: Panamanian popular genre which mixes local [Genre32545] with [Genre32800] rhythms featuring the tambora as the main percussion instrument.

Xuc.name: Xuc
Xuc.description_short: Danceable style from El Salvador developed in the 1940s.

Christian Liturgical Music.name: Christian Liturgical Music
Christian Liturgical Music.description_short: Traditionally accompanies church services, as well as extra-liturgical functions such as processionals and sermons.

Anglican Chant.name: Anglican Chant
Anglican Chant.description_short: Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.

Kyivan Chant.name: Kyivan Chant
Kyivan Chant.description_short: Chant form inspired by [Genre39537] that's characterized by simplified melodic and rhythmic structures.

Russian Orthodox Liturgical Music.name: Russian Orthodox Liturgical Music
Russian Orthodox Liturgical Music.description_short: Tradition of the Russian Orthodox Church, implemented with the Christianization of Kievan Rus' in 988.

Znamenny Chant.name: Znamenny Chant
Znamenny Chant.description_short: Prototypical liturgical chant of the Russian Orthodox Church.

Syriac Chant.name: Syriac Chant
Syriac Chant.description_short: Liturgical chant repertoire practiced within Syriac Christianity, comprising the East Syrian and West Syrian liturgical rites.

European Music.name: European Music
European Music.description_short: Regional styles with roots in the European continent and surrounding islands.

Alpenrock.name: Alpenrock
Alpenrock.description_short: Mixes [Genre67] and [Genre156] with traditional [Genre10359] elements such as [Genre354] and use of the accordion.

Ashkenazi Music.name: Ashkenazi Music
Ashkenazi Music.description_short: Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.

Ashkenazi Cantorial Music.name: Ashkenazi Cantorial Music
Ashkenazi Cantorial Music.description_short: Artistic, refined form of [Genre43949] that greatly borrows from and implements elements of [Genre183] and [Genre10269] into the context of liturgical singing and chanting.

Klezmer.name: Klezmer
Klezmer.description_short: Secular [Genre42926] traditionally used in ceremonies such as weddings and bar and bat mitzvahs.

Balkan Music.name: Balkan Music
Balkan Music.description_short: Meta-genre covering all forms developed in the Balkan Peninsula.

Entechna.name: Entechna
Entechna.description_short: First appeared in Greece in the late 1950s, featuring orchestrated arrangements with influence from [Genre30639] and the popular [Genre10251] style.

Entechna laika.name: Entechna laika
Entechna laika.description_short: Artistic side of [Genre10251] played mainly but not always with the basic instruments of it, the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras, sometimes with the accompaniment of orchestras.

Neo Kyma.name: Neo Kyma
Neo Kyma.description_short: First appeared in the middle of the 1960s, rooted in [Genre30944], taking major inspiration from French [Genre10046].

Laika.name: Laika
Laika.description_short: Greek popular music played with local instruments like the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras.

Yu-Mex.name: Yu-Mex
Yu-Mex.description_short: Style of popular music from former Yugoslavia that incorporates elements of [Genre20941].

British Music.name: British Music
British Music.description_short: Music of Great Britain, including the music of the English, Welsh and Scottish people.

British Brass Band.name: British Brass Band
British Brass Band.description_short: An ensemble consisting of a standardized range of brass and percussion instruments whose performances are based on the British tradition established in the early 19th century.

British Folk Rock.name: British Folk Rock
British Folk Rock.description_short: Developed in the late 1960s; influenced by traditional British folk music, particularly [Genre27764].

Change Ringing.name: Change Ringing
Change Ringing.description_short: English tradition of ringing tuned bells in accordance with mathematically-derived patterns, creating a distinctive cascading effect.

Concertina Band.name: Concertina Band
Concertina Band.description_short: Ensemble consisting of concertinas of various pitches and percussion instruments originating in 19th-century England.

Celtic Rock.name: Celtic Rock
Celtic Rock.description_short: Incorporates influences from [Genre642] and its regional variants.

Chanson.name: Chanson
Chanson.description_short: French-language [Genre558]s for whom the quality of the text is essential and where the rhythm follows that of the text.

Chanson alternative.name: Chanson alternative
Chanson alternative.description_short: Usually politically engaged and humorous with eclectic influences of [Genre32988], especially [Genre31575], [Genre10447], [Genre10411] and [Genre21774].

Chanson à texte.name: Chanson à texte
Chanson à texte.description_short: French-language songs emphasising sophisticated and poetic lyricism.

Chanson québécoise.name: Chanson québécoise
Chanson québécoise.description_short: French-language music of the Québécois singer-songwriters.

Chanson réaliste.name: Chanson réaliste
Chanson réaliste.description_short: Very popular in France in the late 19th century up to World War II, typically performed by female singers in a [Genre10155] or [Genre10146] style and featuring "realist" lyrics.

Nouvelle chanson française.name: Nouvelle chanson française
Nouvelle chanson française.description_short: Both a subgenre of [Genre10046] and a specific scene from the 1990s incorporating alternative trends from this period and new and unusual ways within [Genre10046] tradition.

Crimean Tatar Music.name: Crimean Tatar Music
Crimean Tatar Music.description_short: Music of the Crimean Tatar people, a Turkic ethnic group indigenous to the Crimean Peninsula, located in southern Ukraine.

Dechovka.name: Dechovka
Dechovka.description_short: Brass band genre popular in Czechia and Slovakia, characterized by lively brass instrumentation, infectious rhythms, and vibrant melodies.

Fanfare.name: Fanfare
Fanfare.description_short: Brass-led tradition originating in Western Europe, commonly performed during important public events, typically featuring a ceremonious, triumphant, or uplifting sound.

Finnish Tango.name: Finnish Tango
Finnish Tango.description_short: Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key [Genre10422] melodies and the rhythms of German marches.

German Music.name: German Music
German Music.description_short: Music of the German-speaking people, spanning predominately central Europe, primarily Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, among others.

Guggenmusik.name: Guggenmusik
Guggenmusik.description_short: Alemannic type of [Genre54112] played at carnival events, featuring a cacophonous, seemingly "out of tune" sound.

Liedermacher.name: Liedermacher
Liedermacher.description_short: German style having its origins in literature and theatre rather than American forms like [Genre131] or [Genre5].

Euskal kantagintza berria.name: Euskal kantagintza berria
Euskal kantagintza berria.description_short: Basque genre born during the 1960s inspired by [Genre27423] and [Genre10046].

Nova cançó.name: Nova cançó
Nova cançó.description_short: Arose in Catalonia during the Franco dictatorship, sung in Catalan as a way to resist restrictions placed on regional languages in Spain and retain a regional identity.

Música de intervenção.name: Música de intervenção
Música de intervenção.description_short: Wave of Portuguese singer-songwriters in the 1960s and 1970s who agitated against the Estado Novo regime and the colonial war waged by Portugal against national liberation fronts.

Pimba.name: Pimba
Pimba.description_short: Humorous lyrics and a basic harmonic structure.

Bolero español.name: Bolero español
Bolero español.description_short: Spanish genre originating in the 18th century, based around moderate tempos in a 3/4 time signature accompanied by a dance of the same name.

Flamenco.name: Flamenco
Flamenco.description_short: Traditional Spanish style based around fiery acoustic guitar rhythms, emotional vocals, and accompaniment from traditional percussion and dance.

Bulería.name: Bulería
Bulería.description_short: Fast flamenco made up of a 12 beat cycle characterized by its vibrant, spontaneous and festive style.

Flamenco nuevo.name: Flamenco nuevo
Flamenco nuevo.description_short: Contemporary style of [Genre10093] which departs from tradition by incorporating influences from other genres like [Genre6], [Genre131], and [Genre5].

Rumba flamenca.name: Rumba flamenca
Rumba flamenca.description_short: [Genre10093] subgenre, derived from the exchange of influences between Spain and Latin America.

Nueva canción española.name: Nueva canción española
Nueva canción española.description_short: Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by [Genre27423]'s reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.

Rock andaluz.name: Rock andaluz
Rock andaluz.description_short: Emerged during the mid-1970s in Spain; primarily utilizes [Genre10093] and often [Genre383] elements.

Villancico.name: Villancico
Villancico.description_short: Style of polyphonic lyric poetry popular between the 14th and 18th centuries that developed in Spain, Portugal, and their associated colonies.

Canzone d'autore.name: Canzone d'autore
Canzone d'autore.description_short: Music of the Italian [Genre558]s that emerged in the 1960s and early 1970s, initially influenced by French [Genre10046] with the addition of uniquely Italian sensibilities.

Lauda.name: Lauda
Lauda.description_short: Vernacular, devotional sung poetry, composed in Italy in the late Medieval and Renaissance periods.

Kleinkunst.name: Kleinkunst
Kleinkunst.description_short: Dutch-language genre from the Netherlands and Flanders with influences from [Genre10155], protest songs, [Genre10046], and folk.

Mittelalter-Rock.name: Mittelalter-Rock
Mittelalter-Rock.description_short: Emerged in the 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement, incorporating medieval instruments with [Genre5] music.

Nordic Music.name: Nordic Music
Nordic Music.description_short: Music from the Nordic countries, including Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and Finland.

Greenlandic Music.name: Greenlandic Music
Greenlandic Music.description_short: Majorly from Inuit ethnic groups in Greenland, a large island between the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

Kalattut.name: Kalattut
Kalattut.description_short: Distinctive [Genre26677] tradition shaped by European cultural exchanges and indigenous Greenlandic heritage.

Tivaner inngernerlu.name: Tivaner inngernerlu
Tivaner inngernerlu.description_short: Pre-colonial Inuit [Genre26677] tradition centered around the [i]qilaat[/i] (drum).

Uaajeerneq.name: Uaajeerneq
Uaajeerneq.description_short: Ancient Greenlandic-Inuit dramatic performance characterized by percussion and idiosyncratic expression.

Vaigat.name: Vaigat
Vaigat.description_short: Contemporary popular music shaped by American cultural exchanges and indigenous Greenlandic heritage.

Rautalanka.name: Rautalanka
Rautalanka.description_short: Nordic guitar style mainly influenced by [Genre55], and traditional European [Genre431].

Visa.name: Visa
Visa.description_short: Nordic balladry focusing on lyrical content and simple vocal melodies.

Nòva cançon.name: Nòva cançon
Nòva cançon.description_short: Arose in the Occitania region of southern France, sung in the Occitan language as a way to preserve their culture and resist forced usage of French.

Polish Music.name: Polish Music
Polish Music.description_short: Music rooted in the traditions of the Poles.

Mazur.name: Mazur
Mazur.description_short: Lively triple-time national dance with folk origins, popular with the nobility and in the 19th century ballrooms.

Mazurka.name: Mazurka
Mazurka.description_short: Folk or folk-inspired form based on the triple-time rhythm of [Genre52864], [Genre52573] and [Genre52661].

Miejski folk.name: Miejski folk
Miejski folk.description_short: Alternative and [Genre38713] music influenced by [Genre53208] and [Genre209].

Poezja śpiewana.name: Poezja śpiewana
Poezja śpiewana.description_short: Polish sung poetry; the poem is the centerpiece of a song, often with sparse instrumental accompaniment.

Polonaise.name: Polonaise
Polonaise.description_short: Stately national dance with music in triple meter and moderate tempo.

Romanian Etno Music.name: Romanian Etno Music
Romanian Etno Music.description_short: Romanian style which emerged in the early 1990s as a revival of [Genre10556], blending traditional music with dance-pop rhythms.

Avtorskaya pesnya.name: Avtorskaya pesnya
Avtorskaya pesnya.description_short: Originating in the Soviet Union taking cues from forms of [Genre38011] and Russian poetry with the main focus on lyrics.

Russian Romance.name: Russian Romance
Russian Romance.description_short: Popular Russian genre of melancholy balladry.

Trampská hudba.name: Trampská hudba
Trampská hudba.description_short: Associated with the tramping lifestyle, typically mixing acoustic guitar driven [Genre209] with strong [Genre166] influences and vocal harmonies in peaceful, simple and relatively short songs.

Waltz.name: Waltz
Waltz.description_short: Typically in a 3/4 time signature and popular in the 18th century in central Europe, as it accompanied the ballroom dance of the same name.

Vals venezolano.name: Vals venezolano
Vals venezolano.description_short: Venezuelan dance music that employs heavy use of syncopation, complex rhythms, and regional instruments.

Hispanic Music.name: Hispanic Music
Hispanic Music.description_short: Music of Hispanic America and Spain, and the genres shared between them.

Hispanic American Music.name: Hispanic American Music
Hispanic American Music.description_short: Includes all genres created by Hispanic Americans.

Argentine Music.name: Argentine Music
Argentine Music.description_short: Music developed by the Argentine people.

Cuarteto.name: Cuarteto
Cuarteto.description_short: Originated in the Argentinian province of Córdoba, usually with an upbeat rhythm and originally performed with a four-piece band.

Cumbia argentina.name: Cumbia argentina
Cumbia argentina.description_short: Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

Cumbia santafesina.name: Cumbia santafesina
Cumbia santafesina.description_short: Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later [Genre20948].

Cumbia turra.name: Cumbia turra
Cumbia turra.description_short: [Genre20948] heavily influenced by [Genre590] and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

Cumbia villera.name: Cumbia villera
Cumbia villera.description_short: Developed in the [i]villa miserias[/i] (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.

Guaracha santiagueña.name: Guaracha santiagueña
Guaracha santiagueña.description_short: Fast, upbeat and danceable rhythm originated in the province of Santiago del Estero, Argentina as a fusion of [Genre20896] and [Genre21732].

Nuevo Cancionero.name: Nuevo Cancionero
Nuevo Cancionero.description_short: Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "[i]la música popular nativa[/i]" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.

RKT.name: RKT
RKT.description_short: Emerged in the early 2010s, characterized by minimalistic, rhythm-centric production heavily influenced by [Genre30866] and other [Genre20948] styles.

Avanzada.name: Avanzada
Avanzada.description_short: Fusion of [genre55570] and [genre21317] with elements of [genre526] and [genre602].

Bailecito.name: Bailecito
Bailecito.description_short: Agile and lively dance derived from [Genre52538], typical of the western and central region of Bolivia.

Bolero.name: Bolero
Bolero.description_short: Ballad with a 2/4 time signature that appeared in eastern Cuba towards the end of the 19th century.

Boogaloo.name: Boogaloo
Boogaloo.description_short: Upbeat fusion of American [Genre231] and [Genre6] with [Genre21417] which originated in the early 1960s in New York City and became popular with both its Black and Latino communities.

Caporal.name: Caporal
Caporal.description_short: Bolivian neofolkloric dance music characterized by a double beat bass drum pattern that emerged in the latter half of the twentieth century.

Carnaval cruceño.name: Carnaval cruceño
Carnaval cruceño.description_short: Danceable genre, similar to the [Genre10136], from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.

Chilean Music.name: Chilean Music
Chilean Music.description_short: Music developed by the Chilean people.

Cumbia chilena.name: Cumbia chilena
Cumbia chilena.description_short: Incorporates [Genre55943] into the traditional sound of [Genre10047].

Nueva cumbia chilena.name: Nueva cumbia chilena
Nueva cumbia chilena.description_short: [Genre5]-infused instrumentation, incorporating an eclectic repertoire of influences, such as [Genre145], [Genre524], [Genre10037], [Genre144], and [Genre10507].

Jazz guachaca.name: Jazz guachaca
Jazz guachaca.description_short: Encompasses [Genre6] influences with [Genre519] styles such as [Genre27045], [Genre10507], [Genre10071] and [Genre31234].

Mambo chileno.name: Mambo chileno
Mambo chileno.description_short: Emerged in the early 2010s in Chile, characterized by upbeat rhythms and rapping, usually on topics of parties, dancing, and urban life.

Música típica chilena.name: Música típica chilena
Música típica chilena.description_short: Incorporation of rural folklore music to urban fields, adding vocal groups accompanied mainly by guitar and a "[i]huaso[/i]" symbolism.

Nueva canción chilena.name: Nueva canción chilena
Nueva canción chilena.description_short: Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.

Chuntunqui romántico.name: Chuntunqui romántico
Chuntunqui romántico.description_short: Vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

Conjunto andino.name: Conjunto andino
Conjunto andino.description_short: Urban folk ensembles using musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association; despite frequent association with Indigenous villages, they bear little resemblance to the Indigenous expressions of the Southern Andes.

Cumbia.name: Cumbia
Cumbia.description_short: Danceable folk genre formed during the 19th century in Colombia and eastern Panama.

Cumbia mexicana.name: Cumbia mexicana
Cumbia mexicana.description_short: Incorporation of [Genre55], Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.

Cumbia sonidera.name: Cumbia sonidera
Cumbia sonidera.description_short: [Genre29656] from Mexico City that developed in the 1990s as discomóviles (analogous to DJs) experimented with slowing down original cumbia to fit the popular dance tempos.

Cumbia rebajada.name: Cumbia rebajada
Cumbia rebajada.description_short: Based on [Genre54694] slowed down to around 76 bpm, with a lower timbre and less joyful sound.

Cumbia peruana.name: Cumbia peruana
Cumbia peruana.description_short: Developed in Peru and diversified into various subgenres, each with its own regional influences.

Chicha.name: Chicha
Chicha.description_short: Emerged during the Andean migration to the Peruvian coast between the 1960s and 1980s; largely influenced by [Genre21936] and occasionally [Genre361]

Cumbia amazónica.name: Cumbia amazónica
Cumbia amazónica.description_short: Mixes [Genre20971] with selvatic dances, Afro-Latin rhythms, [Genre80], and [Genre361] between the 1960s and 1980s.

Cumbia norteña peruana.name: Cumbia norteña peruana
Cumbia norteña peruana.description_short: Developed on the Peruvian coast, with influences from [Genre54694] and cumbia ecuatoriana and lyrics mostly about love and heartbreak.

Currulao.name: Currulao
Currulao.description_short: Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.

Gaita zuliana.name: Gaita zuliana
Gaita zuliana.description_short: Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging [Genre21077] and Venezuelan Christmas carols.

Guarania.name: Guarania
Guarania.description_short: Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.

Huayno.name: Huayno
Huayno.description_short: Andean dance music that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.

Bolivian Huayño.name: Bolivian Huayño
Bolivian Huayño.description_short: One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.

Carnavalito.name: Carnavalito
Carnavalito.description_short: Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.

Chimaychi.name: Chimaychi
Chimaychi.description_short: Slower variant, traditionally lacking guitar or mandolin, found in the eastern provinces of Áncash department.

Latin Alternative.name: Latin Alternative
Latin Alternative.description_short: Incorporates common elements from [Genre519] like [Genre10047], [Genre10071] or [Genre20941] into [Genre5].

Latin Rock.name: Latin Rock
Latin Rock.description_short: Fusion of [Genre5], often [Genre361], with Latin American rhythms, especially Afro-Latin genres.

Mexican Music.name: Mexican Music
Mexican Music.description_short: Music of Mexico and those deeply rooted in Mexican traditions.

Bandas de viento de México.name: Bandas de viento de México
Bandas de viento de México.description_short: Mexican ensemble with many regional variations dating back to the 1860s and 1870s, when locals attempted to imitate the military bands that were present in the country.

Banda sinaloense.name: Banda sinaloense
Banda sinaloense.description_short: Performed with militaristic-type arrangements of traditional [Genre33966], with prominence on the tuba/sousaphone backing and tenor tuned horns.

Movimiento alterado.name: Movimiento alterado
Movimiento alterado.description_short: Arose from Sinaloa in the late 2000s; radicalizes some of the characteristics of [Genre527] and [Genre28467].

Tecnobanda.name: Tecnobanda
Tecnobanda.description_short: Emerged in the mid-1980s from the [Genre527] tradition, replacing certain instruments with synthesizers and electric instruments, allowing for faster tempos.

Chilena.name: Chilena
Chilena.description_short: Developed when music from the Costa Chica of Guerrero and Oaxaca in Mexico mixed with [Genre27045] brought by Chilean sailors to the region in the 19th century.

Corrido.name: Corrido
Corrido.description_short: Narrative ballad which arose in the late 18th century and flourished after the Mexican Independence War, originally meant for folk singers to spread news throughout Mexico accompanied by a guitar.

Cumbiatón.name: Cumbiatón
Cumbiatón.description_short: Combining [Genre590]  with [Genre29656], and less frequently with other forms of traditional [Genre20941].

Mariachi.name: Mariachi
Mariachi.description_short: Mexican style performed in unique costumes by ensembles known as mariachi bands, with a distinctive sound combining high, bright tones with low and rich voicings.

Norteño.name: Norteño
Norteño.description_short: More traditional, rural version of [Genre525] whose name translates to "northern".

Duranguense.name: Duranguense
Duranguense.description_short: Features aspects of banda music, sped up, with the addition of synthesizers.

Sierreño.name: Sierreño
Sierreño.description_short: [Genre28467] that is mainly played with guitars, as opposed to the traditional bajo sexto used in norteño.

Corrido tumbado.name: Corrido tumbado
Corrido tumbado.description_short: Modern take of regional Mexican music derived from [Genre43639] with heavy influence from the atmosphere of [Genre31066] music, while not engaging in that genre's characteristic sound.

Ranchera.name: Ranchera
Ranchera.description_short: Originating in rural Mexico in the 19th century and popularized in the 1930s; emphasizes passionate and emotional performances and love-focused lyrics, often performed with a [Genre529] ensemble.

Tejano Music.name: Tejano Music
Tejano Music.description_short: Mexican-American style infusing the conjunto [Genre28467] ensemble with European dances and American popular music.

New Mexico Music.name: New Mexico Music
New Mexico Music.description_short: Derived from the [Genre10448] of New Mexico mixed with influences from [Genre307], [Genre166] and [Genre28467], particularly associated with Spanish-speaking Nuevomexicanos.

Nueva canción latinoamericana.name: Nueva canción latinoamericana
Nueva canción latinoamericana.description_short: Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and [Genre21396] expressions.

Onda nueva.name: Onda nueva
Onda nueva.description_short: Based on [Genre25226], it incorporates elements of [Genre526] and [Genre6].

Pasillo.name: Pasillo
Pasillo.description_short: Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European [Genre29770] and often performed with guitar and mandolin.

Peruvian Music.name: Peruvian Music
Peruvian Music.description_short: Music developed by the Peruvian people.

Huaylarsh.name: Huaylarsh
Huaylarsh.description_short: Festive Andean music with vibrant rhythm featuring saxophones and violins, typical of the central Peruvian region.

Tunantada.name: Tunantada
Tunantada.description_short: Originating in the central Peruvian region, characterized by cheerful and festive rhythm, with indigenous and mestizo influences.

Polka paraguaya.name: Polka paraguaya
Polka paraguaya.description_short: Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.

Reggaetón.name: Reggaetón
Reggaetón.description_short: Rooted in [Genre302] and mainly characterized by its heavy emphasis on the "dembow" rhythm; developed in Puerto Rico in the early 1990s under heavy influence from [Genre11].

Bachatón.name: Bachatón
Bachatón.description_short: Mixes [Genre10461] melodies and instrumentation with [Genre590] rhythms, rapping, and DJing.

Neoperreo.name: Neoperreo
Neoperreo.description_short: Heavy emphasis on rhythm, influence from global trends in club music, and generally progressive lyrics.

Romantic Style.name: Romantic Style
Romantic Style.description_short: Melodic and sentimental style characterized by emotive vocals and mellow sound with a less explicit tone, emphasizing romantic love themes, blending [Genre244], [Genre583] and romantic ballad influences, popularized during early 2000s to 2010s.

Rhumba.name: Rhumba
Rhumba.description_short: Commercial adaptation of various Latin American genres; developed during the 1930s as the so-called "rhumba craze" unfolded in the United States.

Rioplatense Music.name: Rioplatense Music
Rioplatense Music.description_short: Music developed by the people of the Rio de la Plata region.

Candombe beat.name: Candombe beat
Candombe beat.description_short: Fusion of Uruguayan [Genre10518] with elements of [Genre5] music.

Tango.name: Tango
Tango.description_short: Melancholic sound generally led by a guitar or bandoneon, originating in Buenos Aires by the late 19th century and gaining worldwide popularity from the 1920s to the 1950s.

Tango nuevo.name: Tango nuevo
Tango nuevo.description_short: Adds new elements into traditional Argentine [Genre10071], most importantly the incorporation of [Genre6] and [Genre183].

Rock andino.name: Rock andino
Rock andino.description_short: Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from [Genre10037] within a [Genre5] format.

Salsa.name: Salsa
Salsa.description_short: Often incorporating congas, timbales and bongos as well as smaller instruments, such as maracas, clave and güiro.

Salsa choke.name: Salsa choke
Salsa choke.description_short: Colombian style that takes heavy influence from [Genre590], [Genre463], [Genre11], and various Afro-Colombian and Colombian Pacific styles.

Salsa dura.name: Salsa dura
Salsa dura.description_short: Earlier form of [Genre524], usually less rigid in structure allowing for extended jam sessions; lyrical themes revolve around the "barrio" way of life and Latin American traditions.

Salsa romántica.name: Salsa romántica
Salsa romántica.description_short: [Genre524] following a stronger influence from [Genre36], typically sharing shorter, conventional structures and romantic lyricism.

Romance.name: Romance
Romance.description_short: Form of narrative sung [Genre141] rooted in medieval Spanish oral tradition, characterized by octosyllabic verses and assonant rhyme. Evolving from epic [Genre43687], and later spread across Hispanic America.

Indigenous American Music.name: Indigenous American Music
Indigenous American Music.description_short: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Americas.

Indigenous Andean Music.name: Indigenous Andean Music
Indigenous Andean Music.description_short: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Andes.

Baguala.name: Baguala
Baguala.description_short: Slow, triple-meter form of traditional [Genre10037] originally performed by Diaguita people in present-day North-Western Argentina.

Harawi.name: Harawi
Harawi.description_short: Repeating phrases of sung poetry dealing with emotional topics.

Morenada.name: Morenada
Morenada.description_short: Vibrant and culturally significant music originating in Bolivia and characterized by the sound of the matraca and a marked and rigid duple meter with a slow march-like tempo.

Indigenous North American Music.name: Indigenous North American Music
Indigenous North American Music.description_short: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of present-day Canada, the United States and northwestern Mexico.

Inuit Music.name: Inuit Music
Inuit Music.description_short: Traditions of the Inuit people, the aboriginal peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland.

Métis Music.name: Métis Music
Métis Music.description_short: Music of the indigenous Métis people of Canada and the United States.

Pueblo Music.name: Pueblo Music
Pueblo Music.description_short: Rooted in the traditions of the Pueblo peoples, who are indigenous to the southwest United States.

Mesoamerican Music.name: Mesoamerican Music
Mesoamerican Music.description_short: Diverse styles and genres developed by the Indigenous peoples of Mesoamerica, a cultural region extending from central and southern Mexico through parts of Central America.

Nahua Music.name: Nahua Music
Nahua Music.description_short: Musical traditions of the Nahuas, a major grouping of indigenous peoples inhabiting various regions in Mesoamerica, most notably Mexico.

Islamic Religious Music & Recitation.name: Islamic Religious Music & Recitation
Islamic Religious Music & Recitation.description_short: Music and melodic recitation involved in the Islamic faith, such as the reading of the Qur'an with its melodic component (qira'ah), the adhan call to prayer, and the elements often used in the practice of dhikr (particularly in Sufism).

Maddahi.name: Maddahi
Maddahi.description_short: Singing for Shia Muslims to mourn in religious death anniversaries.

Shoor.name: Shoor
Shoor.description_short: Mourning eulogy characterized by an intense emotional fervor and rhythmic delivery.

Nasheed.name: Nasheed
Nasheed.description_short: Vocal songs popular throughout the Islamic world, mostly performed [Genre10163] though sometimes featuring light instrumentation.

Jewish Music.name: Jewish Music
Jewish Music.description_short: Different Jewish forms coming from different regions of the world, influenced by local cultures.

Hasidic Music.name: Hasidic Music
Hasidic Music.description_short: Covers the music of Hasidic Jews, primarily characterized by spiritual, intense, and devotional, singing and melodies.

Nigun.name: Nigun
Nigun.description_short: Form of spiritual, repetitive and immersive tunes that developed in Hasidic Jewish communities, typically vocal-led.

Jewish Liturgical Music.name: Jewish Liturgical Music
Jewish Liturgical Music.description_short: Employed for different purposes in the practices of Jewish religion, such as the [Genre20921] of biblical verses during synagogue services.

Chazzanut.name: Chazzanut
Chazzanut.description_short: Traditions used by the Jewish cantor, the [i]chazzan[/i] when reciting and chanting different parts of the Jewish prayer in [Genre43013].

Kriyat haTorah.name: Kriyat haTorah
Kriyat haTorah.description_short: Practice of ritual liturgical chanting of the Masoretic text of the Tanakh, often done during synagogue services.

Piyyut.name: Piyyut
Piyyut.description_short: Liturgical Jewish poems that are chanted or recited during religious occasions such as daily prayers and holidays.

Muzika yehudit mekorit.name: Muzika yehudit mekorit
Muzika yehudit mekorit.description_short: Rooted in traditional [Genre20711], especially [Genre55977]; incorporates modern influences, typically written on subjects of devotion and religion.

Oriental Jewish Music.name: Oriental Jewish Music
Oriental Jewish Music.description_short: Comprises the many traditions and styles of the various groups of Jews from the cultural East, loosely covering the Jewish groups of the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia.

Sephardic Music.name: Sephardic Music
Sephardic Music.description_short: Encompasses the various musical traditions of Sephardi Jews.

Northern American Music.name: Northern American Music
Northern American Music.description_short: Regional styles with roots in Northern America (America north of Mexico, including Canada, United States, Greenland, Saint-Pierre and Miquelon, and Bermuda), typically drawing from [Genre31289] and [Genre27640] as well as [Genre35773] and [Genre48035] influences.

Americana.name: Americana
Americana.description_short: Incorporates a broad swath of [Genre31697] and [Genre209] influences, evolving alongside [Genre174].

Barbershop.name: Barbershop
Barbershop.description_short: Harmonized singing consisting of four vocal elements: the 'lead' (2nd tenor), the 1st tenor, the baritone, and the bass.

Jubilee.name: Jubilee
Jubilee.description_short: Rooted in African-American culture, characterized by complex rhythms and call-and-response vocals.

Coon Song.name: Coon Song
Coon Song.description_short: Lyrical trend popular in the United States from around 1880 to 1920 that presents a racist and highly stereotyped image of African Americans connected with the subject matter and style of minstrel shows.

Country Rock.name: Country Rock
Country Rock.description_short: Combination of contemporary [Genre5] with more traditional American [Genre166].

Cosmic Country.name: Cosmic Country
Cosmic Country.description_short: Synthesizes various American musical influences and the exploratory ethoses of [Genre37294] and [Genre21632] to create an ethereal and more experimental sound still rooted in traditional [Genre166].

Cowboy Poetry.name: Cowboy Poetry
Cowboy Poetry.description_short: Descended from the oral traditions of cowboys and ranchers, written with traditional use of rhyme and meter, using humor and slang, and primarily concerning the cowboy profession, lifestyle, and legacy.

Louisiana Music.name: Louisiana Music
Louisiana Music.description_short: [Genre32988] from the US state of Louisiana.

Cajun Music.name: Cajun Music
Cajun Music.description_short: Associated with the Cajun people of Louisiana where the genre was born, commonly regarded as an uptempo, accordion-driven style with a harsh, infectious beat.

New Orleans Brass Band.name: New Orleans Brass Band
New Orleans Brass Band.description_short: New Orleans' unique combination of European-styled military bands with African folklore.

Zydeco.name: Zydeco
Zydeco.description_short: Uptempo accordion-led dance style mixing Creole and Cajun folk with African American popular music influences.

Nouveau zydeco.name: Nouveau zydeco
Nouveau zydeco.description_short: Adds new elements into contemporary [Genre10074], most importantly the incorporation of [Genre255], [Genre244] and [Genre11] characteristics.

Pep Band.name: Pep Band
Pep Band.description_short: Performs at athletic events, and typically performs modified versions of [Genre36] songs.

Ragtime.name: Ragtime
Ragtime.description_short: Emerged in the 1890s; piano-led and characterized by a heavily syncopated rhythm.

Cakewalk.name: Cakewalk
Cakewalk.description_short: Typically in 2/4 time with a distinctive "oompah" rhythm, named for a dance created by enslaved Black Americans as a mockery of the social dances of white slaveholders.

Honky-Tonk Piano.name: Honky-Tonk Piano
Honky-Tonk Piano.description_short: Nostalgic revival popularised in the 1950s which is more upbeat and whimsical, with a bright and detuned piano sound.

Novelty Piano.name: Novelty Piano
Novelty Piano.description_short: Popular in the 1920s; originated in Chicago and took influence from [Genre6].

Roots Rock.name: Roots Rock
Roots Rock.description_short: Consciously and predominantly incorporates elements of its predecessors and original roots such as [Genre166], [Genre131], [Genre231], [Genre55], and [Genre31697], but also many other American traditions.

Swamp Rock.name: Swamp Rock
Swamp Rock.description_short: Incorporates influences from the musical styles and traditions of Louisiana.

Tex-Mex.name: Tex-Mex
Tex-Mex.description_short: Mixes [Genre55], [Genre131], [Genre166], and several types of [Genre519], particularly [Genre525].

Sacred Steel.name: Sacred Steel
Sacred Steel.description_short: Focused on instrumentals and played on the steel guitar.

Shaker Music.name: Shaker Music
Shaker Music.description_short: Created by the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearing, better known as Shakers, for worship.

Southern Gospel.name: Southern Gospel
Southern Gospel.description_short: Initially sung [Genre10163] by a [Genre594] quartet, sometimes with a pianist or guitar as accompaniment, with lyrics and messages primarily revolving around the teachings found within Christianity.

Texan Music.name: Texan Music
Texan Music.description_short: [Genre32988] from the US state of Texas.

Oceanian Music.name: Oceanian Music
Oceanian Music.description_short: Rooted in the traditions of the geographic region of Oceania.

Melanesian Music.name: Melanesian Music
Melanesian Music.description_short: Music of the Oceanian region of Melanesia.

Kaneka.name: Kaneka
Kaneka.description_short: New Caledonian style of popular music that draws influence from traditional Melanesian music.

Papuan Folk Music.name: Papuan Folk Music
Papuan Folk Music.description_short: [Genre10448] of the Papuan people of New Guinea.

Tolai Rock.name: Tolai Rock
Tolai Rock.description_short: Fuses the music of the Tolai people of Papua New Guinea with [Genre5].

Kantan Chamorrita.name: Kantan Chamorrita
Kantan Chamorrita.description_short: Improvised verse singing performed in the Chamorro language, traditional of the Marianas islands.

Polyphonic Chant.name: Polyphonic Chant
Polyphonic Chant.description_short: Chanting that combines two or more melodic lines that are harmonically cohesive but differ in rhythm and utilize non-parallel motion.

Prehistoric Music.name: Prehistoric Music
Prehistoric Music.description_short: Styles from the first cultural periods of the human species ([i]Homo sapiens[/i], as well as certain [i]Homo neanderthalensis[/i]). From its birth in the Paleolithic and Neolithic eras to the [Genre10057] era beginning around 2000–3000 BC.

South American Music.name: South American Music
South American Music.description_short: Rooted in the traditions of South America.

Brazilian Music.name: Brazilian Music
Brazilian Music.description_short: All forms of music with roots in Brazil.

Brega.name: Brega
Brega.description_short: Overstated, dramatic music with a romantic singing style.

Arrocha.name: Arrocha
Arrocha.description_short: Influenced by [Genre21765]'s romantic style, with further influence from [Genre544] and [Genre561], giving it a more sensual and euphoric feel.

Arrochadeira.name: Arrochadeira
Arrochadeira.description_short: Developed in the mid-2000s in Bahia by [Artist1671253], merges the electronic keyboards of [genre43326] with [genre29660] rhythms.

Bregadeira.name: Bregadeira
Bregadeira.description_short: Fuses contemporary rhythms from the Brazilian Northeast such as [genre43326], [genre29660] and [genre47495], with the electronic beats of [genre21335] and its subgenres.

Brega funk.name: Brega funk
Brega funk.description_short: Rooted in [Genre27665], features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.

Dobrado.name: Dobrado
Dobrado.description_short: Brazilian musical genre, played by military bands with wooden, brass and also percussive instruments.

Funk brasileiro.name: Funk brasileiro
Funk brasileiro.description_short: [Genre11]-influenced dance style originating from the [i]favelas[/i] of Rio de Janeiro and known primarily as "funk" in Brazil.

Arrocha funk.name: Arrocha funk
Arrocha funk.description_short: Slow and gritty [Genre590]-like drums with an emphasis on brass sections influenced by [Genre43326].

Beat bolha.name: Beat bolha
Beat bolha.description_short: Defined by its squeaky wisps and chopped bubbling samples, usually played around 130 to 170 BPM.

Beat fino.name: Beat fino
Beat fino.description_short: High pitched or sped up metallic percussion and [Genre54710] loops with little to no bass.

Funk 150 bpm.name: Funk 150 bpm
Funk 150 bpm.description_short: Fast tempos, typically reaching 150 bpm and sometimes beyond it, heightened energy and typically faster flows as well.

Funk carioca.name: Funk carioca
Funk carioca.description_short: Early scene of [Genre21335] that began in Rio de Janeiro, developed from a local take on American [Genre326].

Funk proibidão.name: Funk proibidão
Funk proibidão.description_short: Raw, aggressive style that developed in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro in the 1990s, with a name translating to "prohibited funk" that hints at its gang origin.

Funk de BH.name: Funk de BH
Funk de BH.description_short: Atmospheric, mellow and minimalistic production with sparse percussion, often featuring sound effects or filtered samples.

Funk ostentação.name: Funk ostentação
Funk ostentação.description_short: Late 2000s take on [Genre21335] from São Paulo state, featuring [Genre22] influences, having a more accessible sound.

Rasteirinha.name: Rasteirinha
Rasteirinha.description_short: Slow-paced, highly rhythmic with instrumentation derived from [Genre554] and [Genre544], and [Genre302]-inspired grooves.

Trapfunk.name: Trapfunk
Trapfunk.description_short: Heavy beats and prominent bass, common in [Genre31066], along with the energy and fast-paced funk rhythm.

MPB.name: MPB
MPB.description_short: Short for música popular brasileira; formed in the mid-1960s as a modernized version of [Genre526] and [Genre603].

Northeastern Brazilian Music.name: Northeastern Brazilian Music
Northeastern Brazilian Music.description_short: Regional styles that combines elements of indigenous, African and European traditions, historically with a focus on life of the northeastern people, such as drought, migration, the struggle for survival, love and nostalgia, and often danced in intense and accelerated movements.

Afoxé.name: Afoxé
Afoxé.description_short: Afro-Brazilian genre originating in the states of Pernambuco and Bahia, characterized by the ijexá rhythm invented by the Yoruba people.

Axé.name: Axé
Axé.description_short: Developed from a fusion of [Genre21725], [Genre619], [Genre561], [Genre144] and [Genre10154] with roots in the Salvador de Bahia carnival.

Pagodão.name: Pagodão
Pagodão.description_short: Predominance of guitar riffs, atabaques, pandeiros and drums.

Samba-reggae.name: Samba-reggae
Samba-reggae.description_short: Percussion-focused style from Bahia, Brazil, originating in the 1980s and 1990s in the Bahian carnival's afro-[i]blocos[/i].

Baião.name: Baião
Baião.description_short: Commonly performed with accordions and [i]violas caipiras[/i], and often accompanied by [i]agogô[/i] and triangle.

Coco.name: Coco
Coco.description_short: Performers usually gather in a circle which rounds the dancers, clapping and spinning according to the rhythm; influenced by cultures originating from Africa, conceived in Northeastern Brazil.

Ciranda.name: Ciranda
Ciranda.description_short: Employs a metrical scheme of quatrains, long verses, and slow pace, with lyrical themes generally limited to love.

Embolada.name: Embolada
Embolada.description_short: Focuses on the prosody of singers, who speak-sing improvised or written stanzas in fast tempos in 2/4 time, accompanied by sparse percussion.

Forró.name: Forró
Forró.description_short: Developed from [Genre546] and the dance rhythms quadrilha and xaxado, along with influences of [Genre31289] like chula and schottische ([Genre564]).

Forró eletrônico.name: Forró eletrônico
Forró eletrônico.description_short: Uses electronic elements through the inclusion of keyboards, bass, and electric guitar.

Forró de favela.name: Forró de favela
Forró de favela.description_short: Originating from the outskirts of Fortaleza, with [Genre602]-influenced lyrics and a calmer and more romantic sound.

Piseiro.name: Piseiro
Piseiro.description_short: Originated in the interior of northeast Brazil in the 2000s, characterized by the combination of electronic keyboards with vocal harmonization; typically considered a homemade style of [Genre28858].

Forró universitário.name: Forró universitário
Forró universitário.description_short: Originated in the 1990s from university students in the state of São Paulo with influences from genres like [Genre5], [Genre144], and [Genre255].

Frevo.name: Frevo
Frevo.description_short: Played in a very fast, binary tempo; originated in 1910 on the streets of the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife.

Frevo-canção.name: Frevo-canção
Frevo-canção.description_short: Versatile vocal form featuring fast tempos and [Genre60242] instrumentation.

Frevo de bloco.name: Frevo de bloco
Frevo de bloco.description_short: Slow, nostalgic form, meant to be sung by women’s choruses accompanied by orchestras featuring strings besides the usual brasses and reeds.

Frevo de rua.name: Frevo de rua
Frevo de rua.description_short: Earliest form, purely instrumental, fast-paced, and meant to be danced in the streets.

Frevo elétrico.name: Frevo elétrico
Frevo elétrico.description_short: Melodies are led by an electric guitar, instead of large groups featuring brasses and reeds; developed in Salvador, Bahia, during the 1950s

Manguebeat.name: Manguebeat
Manguebeat.description_short: Counterculture fusion of traditional [genre55605] genres with modern [Genre5] and [Genre11].

Northern Brazilian Music.name: Northern Brazilian Music
Northern Brazilian Music.description_short: Regional styles rooted in Northern Brazil, often influenced by Caribbean rhythms and instrumentations, usually with focus on romance, celebrations, the relationship between the man and the Amazon rainforest, and danced in fast and sensual movements.

Carimbó.name: Carimbó
Carimbó.description_short: Originated in rural areas in the state of Pará, danced frenetically to the beat of syncopated drums, with international recognition after its modernization.

Lambada.name: Lambada
Lambada.description_short: Agitated and sensual, with rhythms and sounds drawn from [Genre31333], [Genre10047] and [Genre561], and dance moves inherited from [Genre28323] and [Genre10299].

Guitarrada.name: Guitarrada
Guitarrada.description_short: Melodic and usually instrumental approach, centered around the electric guitar.

Rock rural.name: Rock rural
Rock rural.description_short: Brazilian [genre66] that emerged in the 1970s, incorporating elements of [genre613], [genre121], and [genre602].

Samba.name: Samba
Samba.description_short: Originated in the 19th century from a blend of various rhythmic styles of [Genre10505], forming a new sound, structure, and a dance of the same name.

Bossa nova.name: Bossa nova
Bossa nova.description_short: Conceived as a new style to perform original [Genre554], with major American [Genre6] influences.

Marchinha.name: Marchinha
Marchinha.description_short: Originating from Portuguese popular street marches ([i]marchas populares[/i]), featuring simple, joyful melodies and sometimes malicious lyrics.

Pagode.name: Pagode
Pagode.description_short: Used for [Genre554] groups whose music was performed in the suburban Cariocas parties, with romantic lyrical content and improvisation.

Pagode romântico.name: Pagode romântico
Pagode romântico.description_short: Overly romantic lyrics and [Genre36] overtones, with the addition of mainstream instruments like the prominent employment of bass, synths and drumkit alongside the traditional [i]tantã[/i], [i]repique de mão[/i] and [i]banjo[/i].

Partido alto.name: Partido alto
Partido alto.description_short: Originating from the early roots of [Genre554] primarily in Rio de Janeiro in the beginning of the 20th century, initially as a more danceable style with little or no vocals.

Samba-canção.name: Samba-canção
Samba-canção.description_short: Romantic, commercial form of [Genre554] that was popular in Brazil between the 1930s and the 1950s.

Samba-choro.name: Samba-choro
Samba-choro.description_short: Emerged in the 1930s as the result of a fusion of rhythmic elements and combining [Genre554] with [Genre559].

Samba de breque.name: Samba de breque
Samba de breque.description_short: Development of [Genre30090] characterized by sudden pauses in its syncopated rhythms.

Samba de gafieira.name: Samba de gafieira
Samba de gafieira.description_short: Emerged in the 1930s, with the influence of [genre559], [genre28323], [genre52256], and [genre315] from the the United States.

Samba de terreiro.name: Samba de terreiro
Samba de terreiro.description_short: Urban [Genre554] from the samba schools of Rio de Janeiro, with short songs about everyday topics and love.

Samba-enredo.name: Samba-enredo
Samba-enredo.description_short: Developed in the 1930s in Brazilian samba schools ([i]escola de samba[/i]) to be presented and performed at carnivals.

Samba-exaltação.name: Samba-exaltação
Samba-exaltação.description_short: Developed in the early forties, with lyrics mainly exalting the culture of Brazil.

Samba-joia.name: Samba-joia
Samba-joia.description_short: Emerged in the 1970s, featuring a strong influence from [genre10507] along with overly romantic lyrics.

Sambalanço.name: Sambalanço
Sambalanço.description_short: Popular genre in Brazil during the 1950s and 1960s, with influence of [Genre554] and [Genre6].

Samba-rock.name: Samba-rock
Samba-rock.description_short: Blends [Genre554] with influences from American genres such as [Genre5], [Genre6] and [Genre235].

Samba Soul.name: Samba Soul
Samba Soul.description_short: Brazilian genre developed in late 1960s and very successful in early 1970s with the popularization of [Genre235] and [Genre255] in Brazil plus a mixing of [Genre609] elements.

Sertanejo.name: Sertanejo
Sertanejo.description_short: Acoustic guitar-based and originated from the rural parts of Brazilian Center-South region.

Southeastern Brazilian Music.name: Southeastern Brazilian Music
Southeastern Brazilian Music.description_short: Regional styles of diverse cultural expressions rooted in Southeastern Brazil that combine elements of [Genre10505] and [Genre53511].

Choro.name: Choro
Choro.description_short: Brazilian urban genre named after the crying-like harmony generated by the very particular group of instruments used to play it: seven-string acoustic guitar, mandolin, flute, cavaquinho, and pandeiro.

Maxixe.name: Maxixe
Maxixe.description_short: Appeared in Rio de Janeiro at the end of the 19th century, compared with and influenced by [Genre10071].

Southern Brazilian Music.name: Southern Brazilian Music
Southern Brazilian Music.description_short: Traditional music originating from Southern Brazil.

Bandinha.name: Bandinha
Bandinha.description_short: Popular style of music from the Southern region of Brazil. Borrows elements from [Genre39541], [Genre618] and [Genre21765].

Música gaúcha.name: Música gaúcha
Música gaúcha.description_short: Popular music style of southern Brazil, based on the traditional [genre10136] and other European rhythms.

Vanera.name: Vanera
Vanera.description_short: Typical dance style music from Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil, and very present in the states of Paraná and Santa Catarina.

Sufi Music.name: Sufi Music
Sufi Music.description_short: Covering the various musical traditions of Sufis.

Turkic-Mongolic Music.name: Turkic-Mongolic Music
Turkic-Mongolic Music.description_short: Group of related traditions which originated among nomadic people of the Central Asian steppes (speakers of Altaic, i.e. Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic languages).

Rock.name: Rock
Rock.description_short: Typically uses a verse-chorus structure with a backbeat rhythm and the electric guitar at the forefront; generally heavier and/or faster than its predecessors.

Acoustic Rock.name: Acoustic Rock
Acoustic Rock.description_short: [Genre5] with acoustic instrumentation, as opposed to the typical electric instrumentation.

Alternative Rock.name: Alternative Rock
Alternative Rock.description_short: Performed with a less commercial sensibility, utilizing more eccentric, [genre38713]-influenced sounds, moodier or quirkier lyricism, and sometimes ample amounts of distortion, often paired with [genre36]-influenced songwriting.

Geek Rock.name: Geek Rock
Geek Rock.description_short: Emphasizes a nerdy aesthetic, incorporating synthesizers and other instrumentation less common in [Genre116] alongside quirky [Genre36]-oriented songwriting and dense, witty lyricism on unconventional topics.

Grunge.name: Grunge
Grunge.description_short: Mixes [Genre38713] and [Genre137] sensibilities into a mid-tempo approach featuring a heavy, "sludgy" guitar sound, "raspy" vocals and angsty lyricism.

Indie Rock.name: Indie Rock
Indie Rock.description_short: Associated with a less mainstream-oriented and a DIY approach while often dabbling in [Genre36]-informed melodic songwriting, eclecticism, and adopting an "authentic" or raw style.

Dunedin Sound.name: Dunedin Sound
Dunedin Sound.description_short: Emerged in Dunedin, New Zealand in the early 1980s, featuring a murky, lo-fi sound that overlaps with contemporaneous [Genre629] and [Genre221] styles.

Garage Rock Revival.name: Garage Rock Revival
Garage Rock Revival.description_short: Incorporated the raucous spirit of '60s [Genre401] into the sensibilities of [Genre116] and [Genre103]; predominant in the '00s.

Indie Surf.name: Indie Surf
Indie Surf.description_short: Reverb-drenched, nostalgic, and often lo-fi, with influences from [Genre80] and [Genre37494]; rose to popularity around 2009.

Math Pop.name: Math Pop
Math Pop.description_short: [Genre103] that incorporates clean, melodic vocals and [Genre36]-informed songwriting into the progressive and polyrhythmic instrumentation of [Genre101].

Noise Pop.name: Noise Pop
Noise Pop.description_short: Arose in the mid-1980s; blend of poppier [Genre5] songwriting and melodies with the dissonant, noisy timbres of distorted guitars and frequent use of guitar feedback.

Slacker Rock.name: Slacker Rock
Slacker Rock.description_short: Raw, noisy, and melodic, with a loose, blasé approach to performances and typically low-fidelity production.

Shitgaze.name: Shitgaze
Shitgaze.description_short: Blends extremely raw and lo-fi aesthetics, abrasive guitar tones, and typically, the ethos of raucous [Genre401], to create a sonic wall of deafening distortion evocative of [Genre98].

Slowcore.name: Slowcore
Slowcore.description_short: Characterized by its subdued, often sombre songwriting and slow tempos, while taking primarily from genres like [Genre371] and [Genre66].

Post-Grunge.name: Post-Grunge
Post-Grunge.description_short: Streamlined derivative of [Genre47] mixing crunchy guitar riffs with more accessible, hook-based structures.

Shimokita-kei.name: Shimokita-kei
Shimokita-kei.description_short: Japanese style closely related to the Shimokitazawa indie scene, featuring [Genre36]-informed songwriting, melodic guitar leads, expressive vocals, and often loud, prominent overdriven guitars.

Shoegaze.name: Shoegaze
Shoegaze.description_short: Ethereal, noisy washes of sound created by extensive usage of multiple effect pedals, such as distortion, reverb, and delay; dreamy, usually unintelligible vocals, and roaring volumes.

AOR.name: AOR
AOR.description_short: Emerged in the late 1970s and early 1980s as an amalgamation of [Genre67], [Genre630], and [Genre97]; characterized by a rich, layered sound, slick production and a heavy reliance on commercial melodic hooks.

Art Rock.name: Art Rock
Art Rock.description_short: Attempts to expand the bounds of [Genre5] within conventional structures, often using outside influences or experimentation for conceptual or thematic purpose.

Blues Rock.name: Blues Rock
Blues Rock.description_short: Relies on the chords/scales and instrumental improvisation of [Genre131].

Boogie Rock.name: Boogie Rock
Boogie Rock.description_short: Straightforward groove-oriented style influenced by [Genre55] and [Genre10180].

Christian Rock.name: Christian Rock
Christian Rock.description_short: Incorporates Christian lyrics, with topics such as faith, metaphysics, or biblical characters.

Comedy Rock.name: Comedy Rock
Comedy Rock.description_short: Roughly defined as a mix of [Genre5] or any of its subgenres with elements of [Genre10] such as [Genre358] and [Genre147], as well as concepts of [Genre426].

Deutschrock.name: Deutschrock
Deutschrock.description_short: Lyrics address German life, culture, and identity wrapped in upbeat songs, anthemic ballads, and a strong focus on the personality of the lead singer.

Experimental Rock.name: Experimental Rock
Experimental Rock.description_short: Eschews accessibility and convention, experimenting with song structures, time signatures, rhythm, dissonance, instrumentation, noise, electronics, studio manipulation, and other techniques not traditionally associated with [Genre5].

Avant-Prog.name: Avant-Prog
Avant-Prog.description_short: Focuses on highly complex, dense arrangements often featuring high amounts of dissonance and uncommon time signatures, sometimes extending towards atonality, free time, improvisation, and other avant-garde techniques.

Brutal Prog.name: Brutal Prog
Brutal Prog.description_short: Highly intense and visceral songwriting, usually featuring substantial reliance on dissonance, odd time signatures, blistering tempos, angular and mercurial rhythms, and [Genre38713]'s DIY attitude.

Zeuhl.name: Zeuhl
Zeuhl.description_short: Epic, operatic sound fusing [Genre6], [Genre97] and [Genre201] music.

Krautrock.name: Krautrock
Krautrock.description_short: Brings together elements of [Genre361] with avant-garde influences, often incorporating hypnotic rhythms, extended improvisation, and [Genre82] textures.

Folk Rock.name: Folk Rock
Folk Rock.description_short: Influenced by [Genre26677], particularly in the use of acoustic instrumentation and relatively simple arrangements; has its origins in the American [Genre209] movement of the 1960s.

Garage Rock.name: Garage Rock
Garage Rock.description_short: Raw and energetic, generally employing simple, sloppy, and fuzzbox-distorted guitar melodies in addition to frequent shouting or screaming.

Frat Rock.name: Frat Rock
Frat Rock.description_short: Early form of [Genre401] with hard [Genre231] grooves, catchy melodies, and a "fratty" focus on partying and girls.

Glam Rock.name: Glam Rock
Glam Rock.description_short: Incorporates elements of [Genre55] and [Genre156] into catchy [Genre630] melodies, usually accompanied with a strong sense of theatricality.

Hard Rock.name: Hard Rock
Hard Rock.description_short: Originated in the mid-to-late 1960s from [Genre361] and [Genre156] with a heavy sound characterized by distorted guitars and power chords.

Glam Metal.name: Glam Metal
Glam Metal.description_short: Very catchy hooks and guitar riffs, sing-along choruses, and lyrics often glamorizing the "sex, drugs and rock & roll" lifestyle.

Sleaze Rock.name: Sleaze Rock
Sleaze Rock.description_short: Raw and lurid form of [Genre439] with influences from [Genre283] and [Genre156] and back-to-basics songwriting; emerged to counter [Genre36] influences in [Genre67] in the mid-to-late 1980s.

Occult Rock.name: Occult Rock
Occult Rock.description_short: Dark and psychedelic atmosphere with lyrical references to esoteric subjects such as occultism, Satanism, fantasy, and horror; closely associated sonically and culturally with [Genre472] and its offshoots.

Heartland Rock.name: Heartland Rock
Heartland Rock.description_short: Borrows elements from [Genre66], [Genre422], and 1950s-60s [Genre55]; often characterized by its conscious, communal lyrical concerns and working-class appeal.

Jam Band.name: Jam Band
Jam Band.description_short: Arose in late 1960s America, usually performed in a live setting and combines diverse styles under the [Genre5] umbrella, often influenced by genres such as [Genre255], [Genre6], [Genre166] and [Genre131].

Jazz-Rock.name: Jazz-Rock
Jazz-Rock.description_short: Strongly influenced by [Genre6] in structure and/or instrumentation.

Jersey Shore Sound.name: Jersey Shore Sound
Jersey Shore Sound.description_short: Stylistically correlated to [genre33106], with cultural origins in coastal New Jersey; characterized by its horn-heavy mixture of 1960s [genre55], [genre231], and [genre234].

Math Rock.name: Math Rock
Math Rock.description_short: Explores complex and unconventional rhythmic patterns through unusual syncopation, stop-start structures, polyrhythms and complex time signatures, angular melodies, and technical instrumental performances.

New Wave.name: New Wave
New Wave.description_short: Agitated and busy guitar melodies, jerky rhythms, often a heavy reliance on synthesizers, and typically intricate percussive sections, closely related to [Genre332] and influenced by [Genre630] and [Genre82].

Noise Rock.name: Noise Rock
Noise Rock.description_short: Explores dissonance and distortion through unconventional playing and guitar effects, commonly augmented by lo-fi production and bursts of feedback.

Post-Rock.name: Post-Rock
Post-Rock.description_short: Emphasis on timbre, texture, and atmosphere over traditional conventions while often embracing influences from genres not usually associated with [genre5].

Progressive Rock.name: Progressive Rock
Progressive Rock.description_short: Complex harmonies, instrumental virtuosity, and usually multi-section song structures featuring a broad range of instrumentation.

Canterbury Scene.name: Canterbury Scene
Canterbury Scene.description_short: Developed in the counterculture of Canterbury in the late 1960s, emphasizing the influence of [Genre182] and [Genre75].

Neo-Canterbury.name: Neo-Canterbury
Neo-Canterbury.description_short: Movement reviving the signature style of the [Genre625], often updating it with modern influences.

Neo-Prog.name: Neo-Prog
Neo-Prog.description_short: Emerged in the early 1980s in the United Kingdom from the influence of [Genre383], utilizing a synth-driven sound that focuses on [Genre36]-informed melodicism while de-emphasizing guitar riffing.

Symphonic Prog.name: Symphonic Prog
Symphonic Prog.description_short: Incorporates [Genre27640] elements that can manifest in longer form works that deviate from traditional popular song structures, and the use of lush keyboards to replicate [Genre22197] textures.

Pub Rock.name: Pub Rock
Pub Rock.description_short: Stripped-down style developed in the United Kingdom in the early to mid-1970s, mainly as a reaction to the perceived excess and pretension of [Genre97] and [Genre62].

Rap Rock.name: Rap Rock
Rap Rock.description_short: Fusion of [Genre11] and [Genre5], often featuring the former’s rhythmic vocal delivery and the latter’s heavy, distorted instrumentation.

Reggae Rock.name: Reggae Rock
Reggae Rock.description_short: Incorporates the offbeat rhythms and staccato "skank" guitar of [Genre144].

Rock & Roll.name: Rock & Roll
