Rock & Roll.description_short: Developed in the United States and popularized in the 1950s, featuring prominent [Genre131] scales, poppy structures, and strong rhythms.

Indorock.name: Indorock
Indorock.description_short: Predominantly instrumental style influenced by [Genre166], [Genre55079], and [Genre581]; created in the late 1950s by Indo and Moluccan expatriates from Indonesia to the Netherlands.

Rockabilly.name: Rockabilly
Rockabilly.description_short: Blends the sound of [Genre166] with that of [Genre231], often accompanied by driving guitars, frantic vocals, and slap-back echo in the bass.

Rock Opera.name: Rock Opera
Rock Opera.description_short: Hybrid of rock and, sometimes, musical theatre stylings with heavily rock-tinged songs combining to tell a coherent story.

Southern Rock.name: Southern Rock
Southern Rock.description_short: Emerged from the American South in the early 1970s, blending [Genre156], [Genre67], and [Genre55] with elements of [Genre166] and [Genre209].

Surf Music.name: Surf Music
Surf Music.description_short: Evolved from late 1950s instrumental [Genre55] in the USA, particularly associated with the surfing culture in Southern California.

Surf Rock.name: Surf Rock
Surf Rock.description_short: Short instrumental songs with [Genre55] rhythms overlaid with cheerful melodies played on reverb-drenched tremolo guitar.

Zolo.name: Zolo
Zolo.description_short: Retrospective term grouping artists that fuse elements of [Genre129] and [Genre97] with a flamboyant, quirky aesthetic and often the energy of [Genre38713].

Afrofuturism.name: Afrofuturism
Afrofuturism.description_short: Movement rooted in [Genre6] and [Genre255], blending futuristic aesthetics and themes with African and Afrodiasporic culture.

Asian Underground.name: Asian Underground
Asian Underground.description_short: South Asian diasporic movement defined by musical acts, producers and DJs fusing contemporary [genre82] music with [genre10479] and other traditional styles.

Aussie Pub Rock.name: Aussie Pub Rock
Aussie Pub Rock.description_short: Straightforward [genre5] acts associated with the Australian pub circuit of the 1970s and 1980s.

Bernese Dialect Scene.name: Bernese Dialect Scene
Bernese Dialect Scene.description_short: Influential scene of artists centered in the Swiss city of Bern, featuring poetic lyrics in Bernese German.

Bloghouse.name: Bloghouse
Bloghouse.description_short: Internet-based movement from the mid-to-late-2000s which broadly distilled scenes most associated with online music blogging, mp3-sharing and remix culture, intersecting within [Genre35195] styles such as [Genre322], [Genre21082], [Genre47525] and [Genre30075] in a brash and carefree fashion.

Bosstown Sound.name: Bosstown Sound
Bosstown Sound.description_short: Short-lived [Genre361] and [Genre362] scene in Boston, Massachusetts; marketed by [Label194] as Boston’s response to the [Genre61581].

Bristol Sound.name: Bristol Sound
Bristol Sound.description_short: UK-based scene associated with Bristol's soundsystem culture and early [Genre632] within the late 1980s to late 1990s, featuring a bass-heavy, spaced-out sound largely inspired by [Genre150], [Genre235] and [Genre11].

Brno Alternative Scene.name: Brno Alternative Scene
Brno Alternative Scene.description_short: Semi-official, avant-garde scene active primarily in the the 1980s in the Czech Socialist Republic.

Brony Music.name: Brony Music
Brony Music.description_short: Fan works, created by the brony community, relating to the My Little Pony franchise.

Cascadian Black Metal.name: Cascadian Black Metal
Cascadian Black Metal.description_short: Scene hailing from the Pacific Northwest region of the United States and Canada marked by nature-centric imagery, oftentimes incorporating elements of [Genre41581].

CBGB Scene.name: CBGB Scene
CBGB Scene.description_short: Early [Genre38713] scene built around artists who frequently played at the East Village's [Venue238] club in the mid-1970s.

CCM.name: CCM
CCM.description_short: Popular music focused on Christian spirituality and faith.

Praise & Worship.name: Praise & Worship
Praise & Worship.description_short: Christian music with lyrics focused on the greatness of God.

Praise Break.name: Praise Break
Praise Break.description_short: High-energy, improvisational "break" for worshiping God in Black churches.

Urban Contemporary Gospel.name: Urban Contemporary Gospel
Urban Contemporary Gospel.description_short: Inspired by [Genre10014] music, featuring Christian lyrics adapted to contemporary rhythms and styles.

Česká alternativní scéna.name: Česká alternativní scéna
Česká alternativní scéna.description_short: Semi-official scene active during the Normalisation era in the Czech Socialist Republic.

Český underground.name: Český underground
Český underground.description_short: Antiestablishment musical counterculture active primarily in the 1970s and 1980s in the Czech Socialist Republic.

Chicago School.name: Chicago School
Chicago School.description_short: Predominantly 1990s [Genre56] scene which blends influences from [Genre103] and [Genre6] with an expanded instrumental palette and a diverse approach to sonic exploration.

Christian Hardcore.name: Christian Hardcore
Christian Hardcore.description_short: Developed in the 1990s in the United States, incorporating faith-based Christian messages into [Genre46758] music.

Clube da esquina.name: Clube da esquina
Clube da esquina.description_short: Brazilian movement from the state of Minas Gerais, mostly active in the 1960s and 1970s.

C-Pop.name: C-Pop
C-Pop.description_short: Commercialized style performed by Chinese communities across China and Taiwan, alongside its large diaspora.

Cantopop.name: Cantopop
Cantopop.description_short: Modern commercial [Genre36] music sung in the Cantonese language, usually produced in Hong Kong or adjacent regions.

Gufeng.name: Gufeng
Gufeng.description_short: Emphasizes Chineseness and an "ancient" atmosphere, and often features semi-classical lyrics.

Hokkien Pop.name: Hokkien Pop
Hokkien Pop.description_short: Modern [Genre36] music sung in Hokkien dialects, with its industry largely centered across Taiwan and Southeast Asia.

Mandopop.name: Mandopop
Mandopop.description_short: [Genre21071] in which songs are performed in Mandarin.

Demoscene.name: Demoscene
Demoscene.description_short: Computer art subculture originating in the 1980s based on the creation of demos and overcoming technical limitations.

Donosti Sound.name: Donosti Sound
Donosti Sound.description_short: Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by [Genre378], that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.

Doujin Music.name: Doujin Music
Doujin Music.description_short: Self-published Japanese works that may be either derivative or entirely original and are primarily focused on fandom interests.

Touhou Music.name: Touhou Music
Touhou Music.description_short: Stemming from doujin [Genre34443] video game franchise [i][Franchise82][/i], including original music and derivative fan arrangements of varying styles.

Düsseldorf School.name: Düsseldorf School
Düsseldorf School.description_short: [Genre58] scene which developed alongside [Genre10131] music in the early 1970s; known for its characteristic ‘motorik beat,’ as well as for playing a major role in the evolution of [Genre82] music.

East Coast Hip Hop.name: East Coast Hip Hop
East Coast Hip Hop.description_short: Highly influential [Genre11] scene that developed in New York City, particularly in the South Bronx, during the 1970s.

Bronx Drill.name: Bronx Drill
Bronx Drill.description_short: Bronx scene that popularized [Genre52048] and aggressive [Genre59060] delivery and production in the early 2020s.

Brooklyn Drill.name: Brooklyn Drill
Brooklyn Drill.description_short: Brooklyn scene that kickstarted [Genre59060] in the mid-2010s, primarily through adopted [Genre41478] production.

Emo Revival.name: Emo Revival
Emo Revival.description_short: Movement beginning in the late 2000s inspired by the styles of 1990s [genre27516], often associated with [genre101]-inflected "twinkly" style.

English Underground.name: English Underground
English Underground.description_short: Countercultural scene in the United Kingdom, centred around London clubs like UFO and Middle Earth, which peaked in 1966 and 1967.

Ladbroke Grove Scene.name: Ladbroke Grove Scene
Ladbroke Grove Scene.description_short: [Genre62865] scene which blossomed in Ladbroke Grove, London, soon after the closure of the popular West End psychedelic club Middle Earth in 1968; faded by the mid-'70s, especially following the rise of [Genre79] and [Genre38713].

Epadunk.name: Epadunk
Epadunk.description_short: Swedish party-oriented scene emerging in the early 2020s, featuring [genre31431]-leaning sound and vulgar lyrics.

Filk.name: Filk
Filk.description_short: Broad fandom-focused movement that emerged from [Genre20035] conventions in the 1950s, based around original lyrics about fannish interests set to popular melodies or original compositions in an eclectic range of genres.

Florida Fast Music.name: Florida Fast Music
Florida Fast Music.description_short: DJing and production technique originally developed in South Florida, that primarily involves speeding up [Genre11], [Genre244], and [Genre47586] records.

Fort Thunder Scene.name: Fort Thunder Scene
Fort Thunder Scene.description_short: Late '90s – early 2000s [Genre342] and [Genre405] scene that formed around an art commune in Providence, Rhode Island.

Free Noise.name: Free Noise
Free Noise.description_short: 1990s New Zealand scene consisting of [Genre5]-based groups with a focus on [Genre10239], [Genre246], and [Genre342] music.

French Hip Hop.name: French Hip Hop
French Hip Hop.description_short: [Genre11] originating from France, typically performed in the French language.

Friese bries.name: Friese bries
Friese bries.description_short: [Genre129] and [Genre38713] inspired music scene located in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands in the mid-1980s.

Greenwich Village Scene.name: Greenwich Village Scene
Greenwich Village Scene.description_short: Collective of folk singers who mainly performed in small venues (basements, bars, and coffee houses) throughout Greenwich Village from the late 1950s to mid-1960s.

Hamburger Schule.name: Hamburger Schule
Hamburger Schule.description_short: Combines traditions of the [Genre10170] based on [Genre47] with [Genre36] hooks and elements of [Genre160].

Harlem Renaissance.name: Harlem Renaissance
Harlem Renaissance.description_short: Influential 1920s and '30s cultural movement centered on the African American community in Harlem, New York.

Hauntology.name: Hauntology
Hauntology.description_short: UK-based movement that, through techniques found within [Genre84] and [Genre10439], aims to warp musical styles and broadcast media from the mid-20th century post-war era into an uncanny, lost, "haunted" atmosphere.

Hip-hopolo.name: Hip-hopolo
Hip-hopolo.description_short: 2000s Polish [Genre11] scene focused on a mainstream approach; received massive popularity and overwhelming criticism from the hip hop community.

Hoboken Sound.name: Hoboken Sound
Hoboken Sound.description_short: Predominantly 1980s New Jersey scene that blended contemporary [Genre332] and [Genre129] with [Genre631] melodicism and [Genre401] directness, becoming heavily influential to early American [Genre629] and [Genre116] as a whole.

Holy Terror.name: Holy Terror
Holy Terror.description_short: Offshoot of the Process Church of Final Judgement and The Abraxas Foundation sects, focused on the occult and demonology, as well as apocalyptic, misanthropic themes.

Japanese Hardcore.name: Japanese Hardcore
Japanese Hardcore.description_short: Bands from Japan, performing styles such as [Genre47546], [Genre335], and [Genre505].

Japanese Hip Hop.name: Japanese Hip Hop
Japanese Hip Hop.description_short: [Genre11] which is created by artists who are either based in or from Japan.

Japanese Idol.name: Japanese Idol
Japanese Idol.description_short: Contemporary Japanese singer-dancers valued mainly for their personality and charisma, often performing as groups in a cutesy and youthful style.

Alternative Idol.name: Alternative Idol
Alternative Idol.description_short: Unconventional approaches characterized by alternative music styles and often unusual public images.

J-core.name: J-core
J-core.description_short: Eclectic scene of Japanese [Genre272] heavily associated with [Genre60780].

Kansai No Wave.name: Kansai No Wave
Kansai No Wave.description_short: Late '70s to early '80s scene from the Kansai region of Japan, sharing the brash oppositional, anti-music attitude of New York City [Genre520].

LA Beat Scene.name: LA Beat Scene
LA Beat Scene.description_short: Los Angeles scene from the 2000s to mid-2010s where DJs and beatmakers added off-kilter rhythms and textures to [Genre11] and [Genre82].

Laurel Canyon Scene.name: Laurel Canyon Scene
Laurel Canyon Scene.description_short: 1960s and 1970s [Genre5] counterculture originating from the Laurel Canyon neighborhood of Los Angeles, highly influential to the development of contemporary [Genre66] and [Genre65].

Leningrad Rock Club Scene.name: Leningrad Rock Club Scene
Leningrad Rock Club Scene.description_short: Community of primarily [Genre332] and [Genre129] bands in the 1980s USSR that sprung up around the Leningrad Rock Club, the first legal venue of its kind allowed under cautious government oversight.

Little Band Scene.name: Little Band Scene
Little Band Scene.description_short: Experimental [Genre332] scene which occurred in Melbourne in 1978-1981, based around intentionally short-lived bands with a small amount of material.

Loft Jazz.name: Loft Jazz
Loft Jazz.description_short: New York based independent [Genre6] scene defined by casual performances in lofts and apartments.

Louisville Sound.name: Louisville Sound

Młoda Polska.name: Młoda Polska

New Brunswick Basement Scene.name: New Brunswick Basement Scene

New London Jazz.name: New London Jazz

New Primitivism.description_short: Cross-media movement in Sarajevo, active primarily in the 1980s and inspired by [Genre60758] and Yugoslav [Genre38713].

New Romantic.name: New Romantic
New Romantic.description_short: UK cultural movement associated with the early 1980s and defined by a distinct, flamboyant fashion sense.

New Weird America.name: New Weird America
New Weird America.description_short: Diverse movement that originated in the Northeastern United States during the late 1990s and 2000s which reshaped mid-20th century [Genre209] influences through a psychedelic and avant-garde approach.

New Weird Finland.name: New Weird Finland
New Weird Finland.description_short: Rose to prominence in the early 2000s, based around a collective of musicians living primarily in the Finnish cities of Tampere, Turku and Helsinki and with a sound primarily rooted in [Genre37294], particularly [Genre211] and its subgenres [Genre219] and [Genre220].

New York Hardcore.name: New York Hardcore
New York Hardcore.description_short: [Genre333] bands from New York City from the 1980s and onwards.

NOLA Sludge.name: NOLA Sludge
NOLA Sludge.description_short: New Orleans–based Louisiana [Genre137] scene, commonly cited as the birthplace of [Genre437].

Northern Soul.name: Northern Soul
Northern Soul.description_short: Soul popular in northern England in the late 1960s and early 1970s, consisting primarily of lesser-known American artists in the mid-1960s copying the [Genre42751].

Nova srpska scena.name: Nova srpska scena
Nova srpska scena.description_short: Serbian [Genre116] scene subject to media interest in the '00s and early '10s; influenced by the [Genre60758] and contemporary [Genre103].

Nova vanguarda paulistana.name: Nova vanguarda paulistana
Nova vanguarda paulistana.description_short: Southeastern Brazilian scene that emerged in the late 2000s based on experimentation with [Genre554] and [Genre602] styles.

Novaya scena.name: Novaya scena
Novaya scena.description_short: Diverse Ukrainian avant-garde scene which emerged in the late 1980s.

Novo Dub.name: Novo Dub
Novo Dub.description_short: Alternative [Genre82] scene incorporating various influences, predominant in France.

No Wave.name: No Wave
No Wave.description_short: Underground, avant-garde, anti-art movement and music scene based in New York City around 1976-1980; commonly incorporates elements like dissonance, atonality, and stream-of-consciousness lyrics into various genres.

Nueva canción.name: Nueva canción
Nueva canción.description_short: Latin American ([Genre30436]) and Spanish ([Genre30428]) movement during the 1960s and 1970s.

Nueva ola.name: Nueva ola
Nueva ola.description_short: Latin American movement in the late 1950s and the 1960s incorporating assorted styles of Western popular music, primarily [Genre55] and [Genre36].

NWOBHM.name: NWOBHM
NWOBHM.description_short: Acronym for new wave of British [Genre472], which occurred in the late 1970s, taking some influence from [Genre160].

Palm Desert Scene.name: Palm Desert Scene
Palm Desert Scene.description_short: Originated during the 1990s in Palm Desert, California, based in classic [Genre67], [Genre361] and the [Genre116] sounds of the era.

Pop Kreatif.name: Pop Kreatif
Pop Kreatif.description_short: Scene from Indonesia made popular in the 1970s-80s; commonly features lush melodies and progressive arrangements borrowed from modern styles of [Genre6], [Genre630] and [Genre31829].

Progg.name: Progg
Progg.description_short: Swedish movement centred around left-wing politics; emerged in the late 1960s and declined by the late 1970s due to internal divisions and the changing political climate.

Psichedelia occulta italiana.name: Psichedelia occulta italiana

Q-Pop.name: Q-Pop
Q-Pop.description_short: Glamorous, catchy pop scene that emerged in Kazakhstan in the 2010s, inspired by [Genre25271].

Queercore.name: Queercore

RABM.name: RABM

Red Dirt.name: Red Dirt
Red Dirt.description_short: Oklahoman and Texan acts descended from the Stillwater, Oklahoma independent [Genre166] scene of the 1980s.

Revolution Summer.name: Revolution Summer
Revolution Summer.description_short: Collection of bands coalesced around the goal of rejuvenating the Washington DC [Genre333] scene in the summer of 1985, creating the early foundations for [Genre49] and [Genre48] in the process.

Riot Grrrl.name: Riot Grrrl
Riot Grrrl.description_short: Underground feminist [Genre38713] movement originating in the United States in the early 1990s.

Rock barrial.name: Rock barrial
Rock barrial.description_short: Argentinian scene that started in the 1990s, inspired by [Genre55], [Genre156], [Genre422], and sometimes [Genre67], directed to a national public and dismissing modern international trends, often featuring lyrics describing the life in low-income neighbourhoods.

Rock in Opposition.name: Rock in Opposition

Rock radical vasco.name: Rock radical vasco
Rock radical vasco.description_short: [genre38713] music movement developed around 1983 by Basque Country and Navarre bands with a crude and abrasive sound and a 'radical' stance against the system, religion, the police and the 'Spanish State'.

Rock sónico.name: Rock sónico
Rock sónico.description_short: Argentinian scene emerging in the early 1990s, influenced by [Genre98], [Genre391], [Genre366], and sometimes [Genre10013] or [Genre221], defined by noisy, reverb-soaked guitars, introspective lyrics and lo-fi production.

Rock subterráneo.name: Rock subterráneo
Rock subterráneo.description_short: Peruvian artistic and countercultural movement that emerged after the return to democracy in 1980, diversifying into various [Genre38713] styles between 1983 and 1992.

Rock urbano español.name: Rock urbano español
Rock urbano español.description_short: Spanish scene originating in the mid-to-late 1970s that gained dominance with the end of the Francoist dictatorship and the end of censorship around lyrical topics like social issues.

Rock urbano mexicano.name: Rock urbano mexicano
Rock urbano mexicano.description_short: Scene born in the mid-to-late 1980s mainly in the marginal areas of Mexico City that took elements from [Genre156], [Genre67] and [Genre66].

Russemusikk.name: Russemusikk
Russemusikk.description_short: Norwegian music crafted for the country's graduate celebrations known as [i]russefeiring[/i], typically features melodic, danceable, energetic production, and party-oriented, explicit singing and rapping.

San Francisco Sound.name: San Francisco Sound
San Francisco Sound.description_short: Influential [Genre361] scene that developed out of [Genre66] in the mid 1960s; often emphasized atypical chord progressions and instrumental improvisation in the form of roving basslines and “cross-talking” guitars.

Haight-Ashbury Scene.name: Haight-Ashbury Scene
Haight-Ashbury Scene.description_short: Influential [Genre361] scene which emerged by summer 1966 in the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco and peaked in terms of notoriety by summer 1967, coinciding with a massive influx of visitors, media interest, and ensuing commercialisation.

Scottish Folk Revival.name: Scottish Folk Revival
Scottish Folk Revival.description_short: Revival of [Genre21185] which began around 1950 in Scotland and stagnated in the early 1970s.

Seapunk.name: Seapunk
Seapunk.description_short: Short-lived early 2010s internet movement associated with oceanic imagery and computer graphics, deriving into vivid fashion trends, often incorporating aquatic elements into [Genre82] styles and visual aesthetics as well as influences by prominent tropes of 1990s rave culture.

Second British Folk Revival.name: Second British Folk Revival
Second British Folk Revival.description_short: Revival of [Genre26677] music in the United Kingdom which began at the end of the Second World War, peaked in the early-to-mid 1970s, and lost wider relevance by the end of the decade.

Shibuya-kei.name: Shibuya-kei
Shibuya-kei.description_short: Eclectic scene emerging from the Shibuya district of Tokyo near the end of the 1980s; often borrows kitschy, retro-inspired aesthetics alongside diverse musical influences from [genre390], 1960s [genre36] and [genre353], [genre6], and [genre82] styles.

Siberian Punk.name: Siberian Punk
Siberian Punk.description_short: Emerged in the late 1980s, often blending the noisy, abrasive sound of [Genre392] and [Genre332] with radical anti-totalitarian lyrics drawing from British [Genre38713] influences.

SoundClown.name: SoundClown
SoundClown.description_short: Scene focused on comedic, often ironic edits of pre-existing music, popular on SoundCloud in the mid-2010s.

Southern Hip Hop.name: Southern Hip Hop
Southern Hip Hop.description_short: [Genre11] from artists based in the Southern region of the United States.

South Florida SoundCloud Rap.name: South Florida SoundCloud Rap
South Florida SoundCloud Rap.description_short: Mid-to-late 2010s [Genre11] scene noted for its use of internet platform SoundCloud to promote and distribute music, as well as lo-fi production and transgressive approaches to rapping.

Straight Edge.name: Straight Edge
Straight Edge.description_short: Developed in the early 1980s DC [Genre333] scene, promoting abstinence from the use of substances such as alcohol, tobacco, and other drugs.

Krishnacore.name: Krishnacore
Krishnacore.description_short: [Genre60826] subculture that spawned from the [Genre483] scene, promoting the Hare Krishna movement.

Vegan Straight Edge.name: Vegan Straight Edge
Vegan Straight Edge.description_short: Espouses veganism, environmentalism, and animal liberation causes.

H8000.name: H8000
H8000.description_short: Belgian [Genre46758] scene centered in West Flanders, famed for its [Genre62171] [Genre545].

Hardline.name: Hardline
Hardline.description_short: Militant outgrowth of [Genre62171] influenced by deep ecology.

Taqwacore.name: Taqwacore
Taqwacore.description_short: [Genre38713] subculture that emerged in the United States during the early 2000s, exploring Islam, its culture, and interpretations.

Teutonic Thrash Metal.name: Teutonic Thrash Metal
Teutonic Thrash Metal.description_short: Influential German [Genre140] scene originating in the early 1980s.

Texas Psychedelia Scene.name: Texas Psychedelia Scene
Texas Psychedelia Scene.description_short: Influential, pioneering [Genre361] scene active primarily in the mid- to late 1960s that grew out of the Texas [Genre401] scene.

The Wave.name: The Wave

UK82.name: UK82
UK82.description_short: UK scene that occurred during the early 1980s, consisting of developing hardcore styles such as early [Genre53403] and [Genre503] bands.

UK Hip Hop.name: UK Hip Hop

Ultra.name: Ultra

Urban Grooves.name: Urban Grooves

Vietnamese New Wave.name: Vietnamese New Wave

Visual kei.name: Visual kei

Nagoya kei.description_short: Nagoya-based scene lasting though the 1990s and early 2000s; characterized by a simpler and gloomier visual presentation along with a darker, heavy sound inspired by [Genre332], [Genre595] and [Genre472].

Soft Visual.name: Soft Visual
Soft Visual.description_short: Starting in the 1990s, featuring more toned-down "classy" and "casual"-style outfits with a natural style of makeup, along with more pop-oriented songwriting, contrasting the darkness of contemporary styles of [Genre21820].

Vixa.name: Vixa
Vixa.description_short: Polish club scene, derived from various [Genre463] subgenres and focused on bootleg remixes of popular songs

Vocaloid Scene.name: Vocaloid Scene
Vocaloid Scene.description_short: Associated with the online scene centered around use of character-focused vocal synthesis software such as Vocaloid or UTAU, marketed specifically to fans, and often accompanied by animated music videos featuring the characters.

Voëlvry Movement.name: Voëlvry Movement

V-Pop.name: V-Pop

West Coast Hip Hop.name: West Coast Hip Hop
West Coast Hip Hop.description_short: Artists who originate from the West Coast region of the United States.

Women's Music Movement.name: Women's Music Movement

Yass.name: Yass
Yass.description_short: Coined in the early 1990s by a group of Polish [Genre68] musicians to describe their cross-genre, often arrhythmic, improvised sound.

YTPMV.name: YTPMV
YTPMV.description_short: Internet-based musical remixes which sequence small samples from audiovisual material as a method of composition, usually with a humorous or memetic approach.

OtoMAD.name: OtoMAD
OtoMAD.description_short: Music-driven remixes that take heavy inspiration from Japanese internet culture.

Yugoslav New Wave.name: Yugoslav New Wave
Yugoslav New Wave.description_short: [Genre38713] and [Genre129]-influenced scene in late-1970s and early '80s Yugoslavia.

Zimdancehall.name: Zimdancehall
Zimdancehall.description_short: Zimbabwean form of [Genre302] that emerged in the 2000s.

Singer-Songwriter.name: Singer-Songwriter
Singer-Songwriter.description_short: Heavily focused on lyrics and songwriting, with musical accompaniment tending to take lower precedence.

Fairy Tales.name: Fairy Tales
Fairy Tales.description_short: Recorded for children with or without background music.

Folktales.name: Folktales
Folktales.description_short: Traditional stories passed down throughout many generations.

Guided Meditation.name: Guided Meditation
Guided Meditation.description_short: Practice wherein an instructor guides the listener through the process of meditation throughout a session.

Interview.name: Interview
Interview.description_short: Recording of a specific person/s during a formal conversation arranged for historical archiving or media broadcast, often in a question and answer format in which the interviewee shares their views and personal anecdotes with the audience.

Lectures.name: Lectures
Lectures.description_short: Oral presentation with the intention to educate the audience on a specific topic.

Poetry.name: Poetry
Poetry.description_short: Encompasses many forms of literature that use style and rhythm to evoke ideas and emotions further than the prosaic meaning of the literature itself.

Beat Poetry.name: Beat Poetry
Beat Poetry.description_short: Stream-of-consciousness [Genre141] originating with the Beats in the 1950s.

Slam Poetry.name: Slam Poetry
Slam Poetry.description_short: Developed in the US during the late 1980s and early 1990s with the growing popularity of poetry slams, a form of poetry competition in which competing performers recite poems in front of a crowd.

Radio Drama.name: Radio Drama
Radio Drama.description_short: Narrative storytelling performed by voice actors and produced for radio broadcasting or published on audio media such as tapes or CDs.

Speeches.name: Speeches
Speeches.description_short: Rhetorical acts performed publicly wherein a speaker typically monologues around a particular topic.

Sermons.name: Sermons
Sermons.description_short: Religious oral addresses delivered with the intent to uplift or educate an audience.

Stand-Up Comedy.name: Stand-Up Comedy
Stand-Up Comedy.description_short: [Genre10] where the performer speaks directly to their intended audience, with origins beginning in the late 19th century.

Ambient Pop.name: Ambient Pop
Ambient Pop.description_short: Emphasizes texture and atmosphere with a degree of structural experimentation, drawing on [Genre371], [Genre366], and [Genre56] while tending towards more minimal, repetitive arrangements which may incorporate elements of [Genre82] or [Genre58].

ASMR.name: ASMR
ASMR.description_short: Recordings intended to induce a pleasurable tingling sensation in the listener.

Audio Documentary.name: Audio Documentary
Audio Documentary.description_short: Form of documentary that uses audio to document or explore a subject or theme.

Beatboxing.name: Beatboxing
Beatboxing.description_short: Form of vocal percussion developed during the 1980s, primarily involving the art of producing drum beats, rhythm, and musical sounds using one's mouth, lips, tongue, voice, and more.

Bugle Call.name: Bugle Call
Bugle Call.description_short: Short tunes played on a bugle; used in militaries for communication.

Children's Music.name: Children's Music
Children's Music.description_short: Recorded for an intended audience of children.

Lullabies.name: Lullabies
Lullabies.description_short: Soothing, melodic songs that are typically used to help young children sleep.

Nursery Rhymes.name: Nursery Rhymes
Nursery Rhymes.description_short: Short, mostly traditional children's songs or poems with simple melodies, rhythms and words.

Comedy.name: Comedy
Comedy.description_short: Range of styles, both musical and non-musical, that always set out to make the listener laugh through humor.

Break-In.name: Break-In
Break-In.description_short: Comedy with narrator posing questions or commentary, answered with a song sample.

Musical Comedy.name: Musical Comedy
Musical Comedy.description_short: Heavily utilizes music in its delivery of humor.

Prank Calls.name: Prank Calls
Prank Calls.description_short: Practical jokes performed over the telephone, typically involving a comedian putting on a persona to make the individual on the other end of the line seem foolish.

Sketch Comedy.name: Sketch Comedy
Sketch Comedy.description_short: Performers assume a dramatic setting (rather than addressing the audience directly), often as fictional characters.

Dark Cabaret.name: Dark Cabaret
Dark Cabaret.description_short: Dark, moody style incorporating elements of [Genre10155] in a modern context, with varied instrumentation.

Darkwave.name: Darkwave
Darkwave.description_short: Expands on the dark, introspective and sorrowful atmosphere of [genre595]; borrowing aspects from [genre82] and other non-[genre5] influences.

Ethereal Wave.name: Ethereal Wave
Ethereal Wave.description_short: Atmospheric guitar and synthesizer soundscapes, effects like reverb and delay, and commonly soprano female vocals to create a surreal, otherworldly effect.

Neoclassical Darkwave.name: Neoclassical Darkwave
Neoclassical Darkwave.description_short: Combines dark and melancholic atmosphere with [Genre183].

Neue Deutsche Todeskunst.name: Neue Deutsche Todeskunst
Neue Deutsche Todeskunst.description_short: Dark themes inspired by German philosophy and poetry, typically combining [Genre82] instrumentation with neoclassical influences and an eccentric, theatrical style.

Field Recordings.name: Field Recordings
Field Recordings.description_short: Material recorded outside of a recording studio for the purpose of capturing the audible illustration of an environment.

Nature Recordings.name: Nature Recordings
Nature Recordings.description_short: Recordings of natural phenomena such as waterfalls, ocean waves, and storms, as well as [Genre41444].

Animal Sounds.name: Animal Sounds
Animal Sounds.description_short: Recordings which are done in order to capture sounds produced by animals.

Bird Sounds.name: Bird Sounds
Bird Sounds.description_short: Recordings of birds, including vocalizations (songs and calls) and mechanical sounds produced by bills, wings, or feathers.

Insect Sounds.name: Insect Sounds
Insect Sounds.description_short: Recordings that capture the sounds produced by insects.

Whale Song.name: Whale Song
Whale Song.description_short: Low-frequency, complex vocalizations produced by baleen whales.

Radio Broadcast Recordings.name: Radio Broadcast Recordings
Radio Broadcast Recordings.description_short: Recordings of transmissions sent by radio waves, used for sending communications to a wide audience.

Gospel.name: Gospel
Gospel.description_short: Arising from vocal Christian tradition often featuring emotive performances, layered accompaniments, and themes of faith and salvation.

Hanmai.name: Hanmai
Hanmai.description_short: Chinese performance style featuring a performer shouting lyrics over an upbeat backing track.

Hymns.name: Hymns
Hymns.description_short: Performed and written with the purpose of praise, adoration, and prayer, often addressed to deities or other cultural figures.

Jingles.name: Jingles
Jingles.description_short: Short, melodic phrases, traditionally used in advertisements, and later in ringtones and video games.

Mantra.name: Mantra
Mantra.description_short: Sounds, words or phrases, often repeatedly chanted, used in religions originating in the Indian subcontinent, and spiritual practices influenced by them.

March.name: March
March.description_short: Strong and regular rhythm originally written to walk in step easier or to back events like parades or marches.

Circus March.name: Circus March
Circus March.description_short: Marches composed for use in circuses, one of the most popular forms of entertainment in the early 20th century.

Funeral March.name: Funeral March
Funeral March.description_short: Slow, solemn marches usually in a minor key; meant to invoke the feeling of a funeral procession.

Marching Band.name: Marching Band
Marching Band.description_short: Covering the music of Western-derived marching bands, primarily used for entertainment, competition, military, and parade settings, typically involving large-scale orchestras featuring a variety of instruments.

Drum and Bugle Corps.name: Drum and Bugle Corps
Drum and Bugle Corps.description_short: Primarily uses drums and bugles, developed from North American military music.

Fife and Drum Corps.name: Fife and Drum Corps
Fife and Drum Corps.description_short: Derived from military field music, primarily uses fifes and drums.

Mashup.name: Mashup
Mashup.description_short: Songs created by mixing parts of two or more recordings together.

Mechanical Music.name: Mechanical Music
Mechanical Music.description_short: Generated by self-playing devices, which read and reproduce music through purely mechanical means with no major electronically controlled elements.

Parlour Music.name: Parlour Music
Parlour Music.description_short: Early form of light, sentimental popular music; popular in USA and Europe from the late 1700s to the 1870s.

Sacred Singing Circle.name: Sacred Singing Circle
Sacred Singing Circle.description_short: Phenomenon that originally began in hippie gatherings, notably beginning with the counter-culture Rainbow Gatherings of the 1970s, features loose musical jams with varied and spontaneous performances.

Sound Effects.name: Sound Effects
Sound Effects.description_short: Non-musical audio works, including recorded sounds and sounds recreated synthetically or by other means, which are either sounds of known objects or abstract noise manifestations.

Battle Record.name: Battle Record
Battle Record.description_short: Compilations of sounds, samples, and beats pressed on vinyl records for use in DJ performances.

Broadband Noise.name: Broadband Noise
Broadband Noise.description_short: Audio signals with energy distributed across a wide range of frequencies; usually split into "colours" of noise and often marketed for relaxation or as a sleep aid.

Toypop.name: Toypop
Toypop.description_short: Avant-garde, naive, and child-like; explores the sonic capabilities of toy instruments.

Worldbeat.name: Worldbeat
Worldbeat.description_short: Pairs elements from diverse sources from across the globe with contemporary, uplifting Westernised production, created primarily for a Western audience.
